	<item>
		<title>CVU Profiles</title>
		<link>http://www.videovolunteers.org/programmes/cvus/emerging-cvus/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 05 Jun 2007 12:14:38 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>nladmin</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.videovolunteers.org/?page_id=17</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h1>CVU Profiles</h1>
<strong>Our NGO partners are scattered across the nation and the Community Video Units (CVUs) they sponsor represent a myriad of languages and communitiesfrom from the largest slum in Asia to remote tribal villagesreflecting Indias incredible diversity. Video Volunteers strives to ensure that the most under-represented voices have an outlet through the CVU, and collectively, the Community Producers are 25% Dalit, 25% Muslim, and 25% Tribal. More than half of the Community Producers are women.</strong>

Though CVUs are currently spread among seven states in India, Community Producers feel connected to each other. They regroup annually at the All-CVU Meet, which is our intensive training camp. Many of them have developed deep friendships and stay in touch via SMS (text messaging).

Below are short profiles of the various CVUs alongside a highlight of the sponsor NGO that supports the CVUs core work on local community issues (as well as the NGOs own thematic areas, such as, Dalit rights, water, education, gender, and tribal rights).

<strong>
</strong>
<h3><strong><a href="http://www.cvufilms.videovolunteers.org/?page_id=42" target="_blank">Apna Malak Maa (AMM),</a> Gujarat, India:</strong></h3>
<img class="alignleft" style="margin: 5px;" title="21042009482" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2007/06/21042009482-150x150.jpg" alt="" width="120" height="120" />

This Community Video Unit is an all Dalit team. Supported by the Dalit Rights NGO<a title="Navsarjan Trust" href="http://navsarjan.org/" target="_blank">Navsarjan</a>, the CVU's mission is to create dialogue between 'upper' and 'lower' castes in an extremely caste-ridden part of Gujarat and, also, to project examples of Dalit leadership on the issues of poverty that are common to all.

<a href="http://www.cvufilms.videovolunteers.org/?custom_f[]=&amp;custom_f[]=+Navsarjan&amp;custom_f[]=&amp;s_real=&amp;search_field=9_NGO/Sponsor&amp;s=trigger_the_search&amp;cat=3" target="_blank">Click here to watch a video produced by this CVU.</a>

<strong>
</strong>
<h3><a href="http://www.cvufilms.videovolunteers.org/?page_id=18" target="_blank"><strong>Apna TV,</strong></a><strong> Mumbai, India:</strong></h3>
<img class="alignleft" style="margin: 5px;" title="Manish Training CVU Producers of Akshara" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2007/06/Manish-Training-CVU-Producers-of-Akshara1-150x150.jpg" alt="" width="120" height="120" />
This Community Video Unit is promoted by the organization<a title="Akshara" href="http://www.aksharacentre.org/" target="_blank">Akshara</a> in Mumbai. Apna TV's five young producers are working to bring the issues of Mumbai's youths in the slums and to mainstream television audiences.

<a href="http://www.cvufilms.videovolunteers.org/?custom_f[]=&amp;custom_f[]=+Akshara&amp;custom_f[]=&amp;s_real=&amp;search_field=9_NGO%2FSponsor&amp;s=trigger_the_search&amp;cat=3" target="_blank">Click here to watch a video produced by Apna TV CVU.</a>

<strong>
</strong>
<strong>
</strong>
<h3><strong><a href="http://www.projectchetana.com/projectchetana-communitytv.html" target="_blank">Chetana TV,</a> Andhra Pradesh, India:</strong></h3>
Chetana TV Community Video Unit was started in partnership with<a href="http://www.byrrajufoundation.org/" target="_blank">Byrraju Foundation</a>. Spread across over 60 villages in West and East Goadavari districts of Andhra Pradesh, Chetana TV CVU highlights issues such as Womens Empowerment and Child Development. These videos are then shown to audiences in the 2 districts through local cable TV.
<h2><strong>
</strong></h2>
<h3><a href="http://www.cvufilms.videovolunteers.org/?page_id=44" target="_blank"><strong>Hamari Awaaz,</strong></a><strong> Mumbai, India:</strong></h3>
<img class="alignleft" style="margin: 5px;" title="Manish training CVU producers at Yuva, Mumbai'2009" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2007/06/Manish-training-CVU-producers-at-Yuva-Mumbai2009-150x150.jpg" alt="" width="120" height="120" />

The mission of the CVU Hamari Awaaz, which means "our voice", is to ensure that the voice and the needs of slum residents are not left out of the discussions about the future of Mumbai, one of the fastest growing and globalizing cities on the planet. They are supported by the NGO<a title="Yuva" href="http://www.yuvaindia.org/" target="_blank">Yuva</a>, who have been working with slum dwellers for years to help them formulate their own action plans for the future of Mumbai.

<a href="http://www.cvufilms.videovolunteers.org/?custom_f[]=&amp;custom_f[]=+Yuva&amp;custom_f[]=&amp;s_real=&amp;search_field=9_NGO/Sponsor&amp;s=trigger_the_search&amp;cat=3" target="_blank">Click here to watch all videos by Hamari Awaaz CVU.</a>

<strong>
</strong>
<h3><strong><a href="http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jahh0BW0Iak" target="_blank">Hamaru Raibar,</a> Uttarakhand, India:</strong></h3>
Hamaru Raibar is sponsored by the <a href="http://www.hihtindia.org/" target="_blank">Himalayan Institute Hospital Trust</a> (HIHT) <span style="font-weight: normal;">through their Rural Development Institute. It actively functions in 25 villages that are spread across the Doiwala and Raipur block of Dehradun district, Uttarakhand. The CVU makes videos on livelihood, health, water, cultures and traditions. </span>
<a href="http://il.youtube.com/watch?v=jahh0BW0Iak" target="_blank">Click here to watch a HIHT CVU video.</a><span style="font-size: 13px;"> </span>

<strong>
</strong>
<h3><strong><a href="http://www.cvufilms.videovolunteers.org/?custom_f[]=&amp;custom_f[]=&amp;custom_f[]=+Jawa&amp;s_real=&amp;search_field=3_CVU&amp;s=trigger_the_search&amp;cat=3" target="_blank">Jawa,</a> Assam, India:</strong></h3>
<strong> <img class="alignleft" style="margin: 5px;" title="IMG_0011" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2007/06/IMG_0011-150x150.jpg" alt="" width="120" height="120" /> </strong><a href="http://jawavideo.wordpress.com/projects/">Jawa</a>, meaning "sprout", launched in partnership with ICICI Prudential Life Insurance, is the first Community Video Unit in the North-East region of India. Located in Dimakusi (A part of the Williamson Magor Group or WM group which is one of the largest producers of tea in Assam), Jawa is training tea tribal in community media and video production. This is the first ever engagement of tea tribals in community-produced video journalism.

<a href="http://www.cvufilms.videovolunteers.org/?custom_f[]=&amp;custom_f[]=&amp;custom_f[]=+Jawa&amp;s_real=&amp;search_field=3_CVU&amp;s=trigger_the_search&amp;cat=3" target="_blank">Click here to watch a Jawa CVU video.</a>

<strong>
</strong>
<h3><a href="http://www.cvufilms.videovolunteers.org/?custom_f[]=&amp;custom_f[]=+Jal+Bhagirathi+Foundation&amp;custom_f[]=&amp;s_real=&amp;search_field=9_NGO/Sponsor&amp;s=trigger_the_search&amp;cat=3" target="_blank">Jal Chitran,</a> Rajasthan, India:</h3>
<img class="alignleft" style="margin: 5px;" title="CVU producers in Jal Chitran at training" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2007/06/CVU-producers-in-Jal-Chitran-at-training-150x150.jpg" alt="" width="120" height="120" />
Jal Chitran was started in partnership with the NGO<a title="Jal Bhagirathi Foundation" href="http://www.jalbhagirathi.org/" target="_blank">Jal Bhagirathi Foundation (JBF)</a> that works on the issue of water; in an environment where women have to walk hours each day to get enough water for their families to drink. JBF also focuses on the issue of governance and the CVU fits into their strategy for expanding village-level democracy.

<a href="http://www.cvufilms.videovolunteers.org/?custom_f[]=&amp;custom_f[]=+Jal+Bhagirathi+Foundation&amp;custom_f[]=&amp;s_real=&amp;search_field=9_NGO/Sponsor&amp;s=trigger_the_search&amp;cat=3" target="_blank">Click here to watch a video by Jal Chitran CVU.</a>

<strong>
</strong>
<h3><strong><a href="http://www.cvufilms.videovolunteers.org/?page_id=39" target="_blank">Manyam Praja Video,</a> Andhra Pradesh, India:</strong></h3>
<h3><img class="alignleft" style="margin: 5px;" src="http://farm5.static.flickr.com/4042/4623977902_bcff2b1a64.jpg" alt="" width="120" height="120" /><strong> </strong></h3>
Manyam Praja Video, meaning "Forest People's Video", is promoted by the NGO <strong>Laya</strong>. This all Tribal Community Video Unit raises awareness about the Tribal cultures and rights of India's original habitants. The producers work in an extremely isolated rural area that is largely devoid of other media, be it newspapers or television or some other form of media.

<a href="http://www.cvufilms.videovolunteers.org/?custom_f[]=&amp;custom_f[]=+Laya&amp;custom_f[]=&amp;s_real=&amp;search_field=9_NGO/Sponsor&amp;s=trigger_the_search&amp;cat=3" target="_blank">Click here to watch a film by Manyam Praja Video CVU.</a>

<strong>
</strong>
<h3><strong><a href="http://www.cvufilms.videovolunteers.org/?page_id=43" target="_blank">Samvad,</a> Ahmedabad, India:</strong></h3>
<img class="alignleft" style="margin: 5px;" title="1326220274_2b75b74889" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2007/06/1326220274_2b75b74889-150x150.jpg" alt="" width="120" height="120" /><strong> </strong>
Samvad, which means "dialogue", provides critical information of basic amenities and services that are available to slum dwellers in Ahmedabad, thereby strengthening government campaigns and campaigns undertaken by its promoting NGO,<a title="SAATH" href="http://www.saath.org/" target="_blank">Saath</a>.

<a href="http://www.cvufilms.videovolunteers.org/?custom_f[]=&amp;custom_f[]=+Saath&amp;custom_f[]=&amp;s_real=&amp;search_field=9_NGO/Sponsor&amp;s=trigger_the_search&amp;cat=3" target="_blank">Click here to watch a film by Samvad CVU.</a>

<strong>
</strong>
<h3><strong><a href="http://www.cvufilms.videovolunteers.org/?page_id=45" target="_blank">Sakshi Media,</a> Gujarat, India:</strong></h3>
<img class="alignleft" style="margin: 5px;" src="http://farm2.static.flickr.com/1166/1325386687_5093b6abe8.jpg" alt="" width="120" height="120" />

<strong><span style="font-weight: normal;">Sakshi Media means "Witness" Media. The producers in this CVU were all witnesses to terrible violence in their district in 2002 when communal riots led to the deaths of more than 2000 Muslims in their state. They are supported by the NGO </span><a title="Yuvshakti" href="http://www.yuvshakti.net/" target="_blank"><span style="font-weight: normal;">Yuvashakti</span></a><span style="font-weight: normal;">, that believes this half-Hindu and half-Muslim team can build unity amongst Hindus and Muslims, by uniting them around their common development challenges.</span></strong>

<span style="font-weight: normal;"><a href="http://www.cvufilms.videovolunteers.org/?custom_f[]=&amp;custom_f[]=+Yuvshakti&amp;custom_f[]=&amp;s_real=&amp;search_field=9_NGO/Sponsor&amp;s=trigger_the_search&amp;cat=3" target="_blank">Click here to watch a film by Sakshi Media CVU.</a></span>

<strong>
</strong>
<strong>Watch all videos produced by all the CVUs <a href="http://www.cvufilms.videovolunteers.org" target="_blank">here</a>.</strong>

<strong> </strong><strong>Learn more about who the community producers are <a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/programmes/cvus/community-producers" target="_self">here</a>.</strong>
<p style="text-align: right;"><a href="http://ch19.org/" target="_blank">.</a></p>]]></content:encoded>

		<title>Donate</title>
		<link>http://www.videovolunteers.org/support-us/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 08 Jun 2007 11:42:51 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>nladmin</dc:creator>

		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2007/06/misc-161.jpg"><img class="alignleft size-medium wp-image-2114" title="misc (16)" alt="" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2007/06/misc-161-300x200.jpg" width="660" height="200" /></a>
<h1><strong>Donate</strong></h1>
Your contribution will empower the poor to earn a living through their creativity, and assist Video Volunteers in creating a global community media movement.

<strong>$2500: </strong>supports a community correspondent for one year

<strong>$1000:</strong> Sponsors 10 video stories on critical issues

<strong>$500: </strong>Recruits and trains one Community Correspondent

<strong>$250:</strong> Sponsors the Most Inspiring CC Award given to a CC whose video creates a measurable impact in their community.

<strong>$100:</strong> Buys a video-camera for a CC to capture untold stories for worldwide distribution via the online news program.

<strong>Special Donation:</strong>At the moment we're collecting funds to support Chanchal, the survivor of an acid attack. To support her please <a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/support-us/donate-for-chanchal/">CLICK HERE</a>

Please consider making a recurring monthly donation, and help us achieve our financial goals over time. Video Volunteers is a registered non-profit 501(c)(3) organization in the USA, and all contributions are 100% tax-deductible. United Kingdom citizens can now make contributions to Video Volunteers that will be tax-deductible in the UK. Donate through Global Giving UK below.

If possible, please donate through Google CheckOut. This is the only service below that does not charge a commission.

	<item>
		<title>Towards a model of community media entrepreneurship</title>
		<link>http://www.videovolunteers.org/?page_id=1704</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>nladmin</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.videovolunteers.org</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[&lt;strong&gt;Towards a Model of Community Media Entrepreneurship&lt;/strong&gt;

The bottom line - did the project succeed? Yes, in the sense that the project derived a model for a collective that would keep people working in media. This is a model that can be used by other organizations.

But what did not succeed exactly was the model of one person, one business, i.e. the community media entrepreneurs working independently on their own and getting their own clients. Video Volunteers is therefore recommending a collective model as the right model for Brazil nonprofit media NGOs. Video Volunteers hopes the findings of this project will be of use to other NGOs.

What follows on this page is a description of the results in terms of livelihood of the VCU.br project; and the two financial models  working as a collective, and working independently  that will point to some of the challenges of the collective model.

&lt;span style="text-decoration: underline;"&gt;&lt;strong&gt;The Market: the price point for video production in Sao Paolo &lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/span&gt;

&lt;table border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="7" width="638"&gt;&lt;col width="305"&gt;&lt;/col&gt; &lt;col width="305"&gt;&lt;/col&gt;

&lt;tbody&gt;

&lt;tr valign="TOP"&gt;

&lt;td width="305"&gt;&lt;span style="font-size: x-small;"&gt;&lt;span style="font-size: x-small;"&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Type   of production&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/td&gt;

&lt;td width="305"&gt;&lt;span style="font-size: x-small;"&gt;&lt;span style="font-size: x-small;"&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Price&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/td&gt;

&lt;/tr&gt;

&lt;tr valign="TOP"&gt;

&lt;td width="305"&gt;&lt;span style="font-size: x-small;"&gt;&lt;span style="font-size: x-small;"&gt;Marriage   Videography&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/td&gt;

&lt;td width="305"&gt;&lt;span style="font-size: x-small;"&gt;&lt;span style="font-size: x-small;"&gt;R$700.00   [USD 411]  R$1200 [USD 704]

(photo album R$200 extra)&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/td&gt;

&lt;/tr&gt;

&lt;tr valign="TOP"&gt;

&lt;td width="305"&gt;&lt;span style="font-size: x-small;"&gt;&lt;span style="font-size: x-small;"&gt;Corporate   function videography&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/td&gt;

&lt;td width="305"&gt;&lt;span style="font-size: x-small;"&gt;&lt;span style="font-size: x-small;"&gt;Over   R$800 [USD 470]

(photo album R$300 extra)&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/td&gt;

&lt;/tr&gt;

&lt;tr valign="TOP"&gt;

&lt;td width="305"&gt;&lt;span style="font-size: x-small;"&gt;&lt;span style="font-size: x-small;"&gt;Private   party videography&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/td&gt;

&lt;td width="305"&gt;&lt;span style="font-size: x-small;"&gt;&lt;span style="font-size: x-small;"&gt;R$500   [USD 294]  R$700 [USD 411]

(photo album R$200 extra)&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/td&gt;

&lt;/tr&gt;

&lt;tr valign="TOP"&gt;

&lt;td width="305"&gt;&lt;span style="font-size: x-small;"&gt;&lt;span style="font-size: x-small;"&gt;NGO   videography&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/td&gt;

&lt;td width="305"&gt;&lt;span style="font-size: x-small;"&gt;&lt;span style="font-size: x-small;"&gt;R$300   [USD176]  R$500 [USD 294]&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/td&gt;

&lt;/tr&gt;

&lt;tr valign="TOP"&gt;

&lt;td width="305"&gt;&lt;span style="font-size: x-small;"&gt;&lt;span style="font-size: x-small;"&gt;Miscellaneous   video clip production&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/td&gt;

&lt;td width="305"&gt;&lt;span style="font-size: x-small;"&gt;&lt;span style="font-size: x-small;"&gt;Starting   from R$500 [USD 294]&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/td&gt;

&lt;/tr&gt;

&lt;/tbody&gt;

&lt;/table&gt;

In any calculation of how much a video producer can earn, the first step is to calculate how many projects of each category a producer is likely to access and be able to complete.

&lt;span style="text-decoration: underline;"&gt;&lt;strong&gt;The Community Media Collective  A Replicable Approach&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/span&gt;

&lt;a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/11/banner-cacamba1.jpg"&gt;&lt;img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-1609" title="banner cacamba" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/11/banner-cacamba1.jpg" alt="" width="756" height="181" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;

The VCU.br community media entrepreneurs decided to constitute a new media collective called Colectivo Cacamba. Heres how it works: they are bearing 100% of their travel and salary costs. The collective members have access, free of cost, to Casa Das Caldeiras (host NGO) computers. Overheads and travel are kept low because the producers only come to the centre twice a week. Casa Das Caldeiras bears the costs of the supervisors time  about 1-2 days a week  and for incidentals like electricity. In earlier exercises, each producer said they needed to earn R$790 [USD 464] per month to do this work full time.

So what are the results? In the first six months after the end of the formal training, they earned R$10,070 [USD 5915] from six paying projects:

&lt;ol&gt;

&lt;li&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Video for a promotional event for  Sao Paolo restaurants (Mica Restaurant  Week)&lt;/strong&gt; - collective paid R$2,000.00 [USD 1,174]&lt;/li&gt;

&lt;li&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Recording of a show at a local theatre (Teatro Corinthians)&lt;/strong&gt;  collective paid R$1,000.00 [USD  587]&lt;/li&gt;

&lt;li&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Recording of a show performed by a  local teathre troupe (Beyond Life)&lt;/strong&gt;  collective paid R$1000 [USD  587]&lt;/li&gt;

&lt;li&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Recording of rehearsals and  performances of a local theater group (Tablado de Arruar)&lt;/strong&gt;   collective paid R$6,500.00 [USD 3817] for filming over four months&lt;/li&gt;

&lt;li&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Filming of monthly black culture  fair at Casa das Caldeiras&lt;/strong&gt;  collective paid R$3,500.00 [USD 2055]  for filming over six months.&lt;/li&gt;

&lt;li&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Coverage of a six day electronic  language festival (FILE) held in Sao Paolo&lt;/strong&gt;  collective paid  R$3200 [USD 1880]&lt;/li&gt;

&lt;/ol&gt;

This income was divided between the collective members to contribute towards their living costs.

There are currently four members in the collective, who spend about 25% of their time working on collective projects, and the rest is filled with studying and undertaking other work (e.g. one collective member does odd jobs and works part time as a driver).

Each collective member has earned approximately R$420 [USD 247] per month for working approximately 25% of the time. This covers 53% of their monthly expected earnings. If collective members were to work 100% of the time on collective projects they could earn more than double their desired monthly income. With this in mind, the collective presents a financially viable model.

In order to replicate this model, an NGO will need to provide the start up and training costs for a collective, which thankfully, all media groups in Brazil do. Thus, the potential to role out this model on a larger scale is quite high.

For a discussion about why the entrepreneurs are not generating their full potential income we need to ask, &lt;em&gt;does the fellows commitment to social issues compromise their ability to make money?&lt;/em&gt;

&lt;span style="text-decoration: underline;"&gt;&lt;strong&gt;One Person, One Business: The Independent Model&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/span&gt;

&lt;a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/11/Washington-no-Memorial.jpg"&gt;&lt;img class="size-medium wp-image-1610 alignright" title="Washington no Memorial" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/11/Washington-no-Memorial-300x223.jpg" alt="" width="300" height="223" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;

This model is undoubtedly more challenging than the collective model outlined above.

In this model each person needs a camera, a computer, travel and overheads to set up his or her own home business.

If equipment (camera and computer) is R$2,050 [USD 1200] and they take out a bank loan charging 20% interest to cover this initial investment then they need R$205 [USD 120] per month to pay back this debt. We have already calculated their desired monthly income to be R$790 [USD 464]. Add to this R$500 [USD 294] for initial overheads and R$50 [USD 30] per month for travel. The total monthly revenue that needs to be generated to cover all this is R$1056 [USD 620].

Based on the above project calculations it is clear that it is absolutely possible to generate this amount. It is also hugely challenging  the entrepreneurs need to market themselves effectively and balance corporate income generation with subsidized socially conscious projects. Working independently is always a greater challenge and far riskier.

It should be noted that the model of one person working independently does work in a different media model, which is at scale. This parallels Video Volunteers findings in India, where it is difficult for a CVU of 5-8 people to earn 100% of its running costs (perhaps 30% is a better goal) but where in the IndiaUnheard model, which functions at a greater scale, a much greater percentage of the costs of an independent producer are being earned.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>The Saksham Project</title>
		<link>http://www.videovolunteers.org/?page_id=1860</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 21 Jan 2011 06:44:04 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>nladmin</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.videovolunteers.org/?page_id=1860</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h1><strong>The Saksham Project
</strong></h1>
In Eastern Uttar Pradesh, one of the most underdeveloped areas in India, Video Volunteers has initiated, as part of the UNDP-IKEA large scale micro credit initiative, an ambitious and innovative communications project called Saksham. The word Saksham signifies potential. The subtle connotations also mean strength, capability and empowerment.

Under the project, enterprising women from within the self-help groups formed under the micro credit initiative are given training in photography and video production. By developing communication skills, the project intends that the women themselves be able to document and monitor the changes and empowerment in themselves, their fellow women and the community at large. The project provides the most marginalized of women with tools to participate in and influence the dialectic of social development and welfare. It inculcates in them a faculty for critical thinking, leadership and a sense of responsibility towards the functioning and results of the program.

This new program is part of a large-scale micro-credit project that is a joint venture between the United Nations Development Programme (UNDP) and IKEA to strengthen Womens Social, Economic and Political Empowerment in Eastern Uttar Pradesh.' Shefali Misra, Program Analyst at UNDP says, Our aim in this project is to ensure that women supported by the project are able to enhance incomes and effectively participate and contribute to decision-making in domestic and public spheres by 2013. We're excited to be working with Video Volunteers. Bringing media skills to poor rural women can be an important part of the empowerment process because it gives them a voice and a livelihood.'

Video Volunteers will intensively train twenty women from within the community on variety of tasks, including, how to document "Self Help Group" elections by using mobile reporting, as well as, monitor empowerment and evaluate the program of which they are a part by using video and photography. Hundreds more will participate in workshops and activities to equip them with communications skills. The aim is to further empower the women project beneficiaries in Eastern Uttar Pradesh by giving them new skills and innovative livelihood opportunities, as well as, a tangible stake in the implementation of the UNDP-IKEA womens empowerment project.

Imagine - instead of an external sub-contractor coming into a remote village in Mirzapur and trying to extract an accurate read of the programs progress, women from inside of the community will be trained to use video cameras to interview one another and generate reports on the communitys progress. The woman documenting the story is given a new sense of voice; the women in the community have a powerful sense of ownership in the results of the program.

Stalin K, Video Volunteers-India Director comments, the key aim of Video Volunteers communications plan is to ensure all documentation and monitoring of the UNDP-IKEA womens empowerment program is designed and implemented by women. We are excited to be working with UNDP in some of the poorest districts in India. By rethinking the role that poor women can play in program documentation, Video Volunteers hopes to break new ground and make the process of creating communications materials empowering in its own right. Video Volunteers aims to ensure a high level of bottom up transparency and accountability by working with women beneficiaries as evaluators and monitors; they will become the eyes and ears of their community.

Uttar Pradesh is Indias most populous state with a population of 166 million. It is also the second largest economy in the country. Nevertheless poverty is widespread - it is estimated that over 40 percent of households in the project area live below the official poverty line. UNDP and IKEA chose to work here because very few women are employed; Uttar Pradesh ranks second lowest on the Gender Empowerment Index representing high inequality between men and women. Womens subjugation and discrimination is widespread and particularly visible amongst people belonging to socially marginalized groups such as Muslims and Dalit women.

It is in this context that Video Volunteers is driven to implement this program because of the exciting opportunity to use community media to empower women, create livelihoods and improve their participation in politics and society.

<strong>Innovations</strong>

In all development projects, funders and organizations put a great emphasis on evaluation. Did the project succeed in what it set out to do? UNDPs program has a clear goal of womens empowerment, yet measuring empowerment is notoriously difficult. This is generally done by outside consultants and one of the innovations of this project is that the women will do the documentation; they will devise ways to measure program impact out using communications technology. This bottom up communications strategy ensures that even the documentation of the program is a process of empowerment as well.

Video Volunteers seeks to find new ways for community media to enable organizations to generate communications material in a powerful way. In line with this aim, all aspects of communication for this womens empowerment project will be done by women project beneficiaries; from internal evaluation and documentation to the production of fundraising and advocacy and marketing materials such as brochures, websites and reports.

About the overall UNDP-IKEA project:

It is a womens empowerment initiative aiming to:

(a) Deepen and broaden the process of social mobilization to cover 50,000 women, in 500 villages, organized in 4000 self-help groups.

(b) Expand economic opportunities and choices for women that lead to a sustainable increase in their household incomes.

(c) Enhance political participation and representation of women so that they contribute effectively in local decision-making.

<strong>About IKEA Social Initiative</strong>

The mission of the IKEA Social Initiative is to improve the rights and life opportunities of the many children - creating substantial and lasting change. IKEA Social Initiative works with UNICEF and Save the Children to promote the rights of every child to a healthy, secure childhood and access to quality education. Current IKEA Social Initiative projects will benefit an estimated100 million children.]]></content:encoded>

		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h1>Please Support Us and Our Communities!</h1>
<strong>It's amazing how much can be achieved with just a small amount of money from people like you! Your help will make a real difference to people's lives around the world and help empower community voices against injustice and discrimination.</strong>
<img class="alignleft" style="margin-top: 15px; margin-right: 20px;" src="http://farm5.static.flickr.com/4019/4665454317_6651e6cf57_m.jpg" alt="" width="240" height="180" />
<strong> </strong>
<h2>Your contribution will:</h2>
<ul>
	<li>Help Community Correspondents voice stories of marginal communities.</li>
	<li>Support Community Video Producers in rural and slum areas.</li>
	<li>Provide training support for Community Producers.</li>
	<li>Distribute community video content via the web and DVD.</li>
</ul>
<strong>
</strong>
<strong>Video Volunteers is a registered non-profit 501(c)(3) organization in the USA, and all contributions are tax-deductible. <em>United Kingdom citizens also can make make contributions to Video Volunteers that will be tax-deductible in the UK, through the Global Giving Network UK site below.</em></strong>

<td>750 Lexington Avenue, 26th Floor</td>
<td>Baga-Calangute</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>New York, NY 10022</td>
<td>Bardez, Goa - 403516</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<h3>With a little support from you, we can go a long way to empower community voices worldwide. Thank you!</h3>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

		<title>board old</title>
		<link>http://www.videovolunteers.org/?page_id=2141</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>

		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<table border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0">
<tbody>
<tr>
<td colspan="2" width="648" valign="top">
<h1><strong>Board of Directors - USA</strong></h1>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td width="147" valign="top"><a href="../../../../../wp-content/uploads/2007/06/DAVIA.jpg"></a><img class="alignleft" style="margin: 5px;" title="DAVIA" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2007/06/DAVIA1.jpg" alt="" width="130" height="140" /></td>
<td width="501" valign="top"><strong> </strong><strong>Davia Temin chairs the board of Video Volunteers. </strong>She is the Chief Executive Officer of Temin and Company, a global marketing strategy, reputation and crisis management, and C-suite coaching consultancy. Davia is a frequent television guest and public speaker on issues of crisis, reputation, rebuilding trust, resilience, women's leadership and the media. She is also a columnist for <a href="http://forbes.com/" target="_blank">Forbes.com</a> and writing a book about crisis management. A graduate of Swarthmore College and Columbia, and former Trustee of Swarthmore and The White House Project, Davia is currently First Vice Chairman of the Board of Girl Scouts USA, and on the boards of several other media organizations.</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td width="147" valign="top"></td>
<td width="501" valign="top"><hr size="2" /><strong> </strong></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td width="147" valign="top"><a href="../../../../../wp-content/uploads/2007/06/KATHY.jpg"></a><img class="alignleft" style="margin: 5px;" title="KATHY" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2007/06/KATHY.jpg" alt="" width="130" height="140" /></td>
<td width="501" valign="top"><strong> </strong><strong>Kathy Eldon</strong> is the Founder of <a href="http://www.creativevisions.org/" target="_blank">Creative Visions Foundation</a>, a global organization that supports creative activists, to use their creative talents to change the world around them. Creative Visions Foundation was the Fiscal Sponsor of Video Volunteers. Educated at Wellesley College, Kathy is a multidimensional personality who has worked as a teacher, journalist, author and film and television producer in England, Africa and the United States. She has authored sixteen books and was the Executive Producer of the Emmy nominated documentary <em>Dying to Tell the Story</em> and the PBS series <em>Global Tribe</em>.</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td width="147" valign="top"></td>
<td width="501" valign="top"><hr size="2" /><strong> </strong></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td width="147" valign="top"><a href="../../../../../wp-content/uploads/2007/06/directors_stalin_K1.jpg"></a><img class="alignleft" style="margin: 5px;" title="directors_stalin_K" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2007/06/directors_stalin_K1.jpg" alt="" width="130" height="140" /></td>
<td width="501" valign="top"><strong>Stalin K.</strong> is a media and human rights activist, with 20 years   experience pioneering new models of participatory media, such as street   theater, community radio, campaign design, documentary filmmaking, and   community video. In 1991, he co-founded Drishti, a media, arts and human   rights organization based in India and was its Director till September 2008.   Stalin is one of the leading voices to democratize Indias airwaves and has   been in the forefront of the fight for communities right to own and run   their own radio stations. He was the key trainer and strategist for the most   successful community radio project in India and was part of a team that   drafted much of the new Community Radio Policy in operation today. He was the   National Convener of the Community Radio Forum-India, a membership network of   individuals and organizations committed to community radio in India. <a href="http://stalink.wordpress.com/" target="_blank">Click here </a>to read more   about him.</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td width="147" valign="top"></td>
<td width="501" valign="top"><hr size="2" /><strong> </strong></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td width="147" valign="top"><img class="alignleft" style="margin: 5px;" title="directors_eva_haller" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/06/directors_eva_haller.jpg" alt="" width="130" height="140" /></td>
<td width="501" valign="top"><strong>Eva Haller</strong> sits on the Board of numerous international   organizations, including The University of California Santa Barbara   Foundation, The Kennedy School of Government at Harvard, Counterpart   International , and The Medici Foundation. She is currently Chairwoman of Free the Children, Sing for Hope, and   Creative Visions, and brings years of fundraising experience to Video   Volunteers.</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td width="147" valign="top"></td>
<td width="501" valign="top"><hr size="2" /><strong> </strong></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td width="147" valign="top"><a href="../../../../../wp-content/uploads/2007/06/directors_albert_maysles1.jpg"></a><img class="alignleft" style="margin: 5px;" title="directors_albert_maysles" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2007/06/directors_albert_maysles1.jpg" alt="" width="130" height="140" /></td>
<td width="501" valign="top"><strong>Albert Maysles</strong> is the Academy Award nominated director of such legendary   documentaries as Salesman, Grey Gardens, and Gimme Shelter. Albert Maysles   and his brother, David Maysles, played important roles in the development of   cinema verit documentary-making by designing highly portable cameras and   sound equipment that allowed them to record events with minimal intrusion.   His vision ensures Video Volunteer films are compelling to large audiences.</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td width="147" valign="top"></td>
<td width="501" valign="top"><hr size="2" /><strong> </strong></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td width="147" valign="top"><a href="../../../../../wp-content/uploads/2007/06/Francesaca.jpg"></a><img class="alignleft" style="margin: 5px;" title="Francesca-150x150" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2007/06/Francesaca-150x1501.jpg" alt="" width="130" height="140" /></td>
<td width="501" valign="top"><strong>Francesca Kress, Ph.D</strong> is a clinical psychologist with a private practice in New York City and Warwick, New York. She is a member of the board of the Jericho Project and the American Classical Orchestra. Francesca is also a board member of the Smithsonian's Museum of the American Indian at the Customs House in New York.</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td width="147" valign="top"></td>
<td width="501" valign="top"><hr size="2" /><strong> </strong></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td width="147" valign="top"><img class="alignleft" style="margin: 5px;" title="directors_john_n_mayberry" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/06/directors_john_n_mayberry.gif" alt="" width="130" height="140" /></td>
<td width="501" valign="top"><strong>John N. Mayberry</strong> is the Chairman of Core Asset Management Company. He is a   member of the bar of the State of New York. Jack received a BA with honors in   Greek and Latin from Swarthmore College and earned a JD from Yale Law School.   He has been a member of the board of Planned Parenthood of New York   City(PPNYC) since 1991, co-chair from 19951997 and Treasurer and Secretary   from 19971998. Since 1998, he has been a member of the investment committee,   which oversees PPNYCs endowment. From 2002 to 2009, he served as chair of that   committee. From 1994 until 2008, Jack was a member of the board of the   Spoleto Festival USA in Charleston, South Carolina, and served on the Finance   and Investment Committees.</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td width="147" valign="top"></td>
<td width="501" valign="top"><hr size="2" /><strong> </strong></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td width="147" valign="top"><img class="alignleft" style="margin: 5px;" title="directors_freeman_murray" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/06/directors_freeman_murray.jpg" alt="" width="130" height="140" /></td>
<td width="501" valign="top"><strong>Freeman Murray</strong> has worked in the high tech industry in California and India for the past 12 years. He worked in the Java group at Sun Microsystems and at a variety of startups including IUMA, Mixercast and Kendara which he co-founded and sold to Excite@Home in 2000. In 2001 he set up the Murray Internet and Education Fund through which he has provided support for numerous tech related education projects such as, Curriki.org, the Digital Studyhall, Video Volunteers and the Vigyan Ashram.</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td width="147" valign="top"></td>
<td width="501" valign="top"><hr size="2" /><strong> </strong></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td width="147" valign="top"><img class="alignleft" style="margin: 5px;" title="directors_michael_rosenblum" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/06/directors_michael_rosenblum-225x300.jpg" alt="" width="130" height="140" /></td>
<td width="501" valign="top"><strong>Michael Rosenblum</strong> is a Media Consultant and creator of the videojournalism style of news reporting. Rosenblum built the first major Video Journalism-driven local TV news operation in New York. He later went on to train Video Journalists at Voice of America, the New York Times, the BBC, German Public TV, Dutch Public TV and many other Video Journalism-driven news operations around the world. In addition to establishing NY news pioneering form of news reporting, he has trained 100s of journalists at the BBC and elsewhere. Through Video Volunteers, Mr. Rosenblum is bringing his training methods to the developing world as a tool in social change.</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td width="147" valign="top"></td>
<td width="501" valign="top"><hr size="2" /><strong> </strong></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td width="147" valign="top"><img class="alignleft" style="margin: 5px;" title="directors_martha_spanninger" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/06/directors_martha_spanninger.jpg" alt="" width="130" height="140" /></td>
<td width="501" valign="top"><strong>Martha Spanninger</strong> is a Peabody award-winning documentary producer and broadcast journalist with more than twenty-five years of experience. Her career has included assignments with PBS (<em>Now on PBS</em>), ABC (<em>20/20</em>), NBC (<em>Dateline</em>), CBS (<em>CBS Reports</em> <em>West 57th</em>), MTV, and numerous independent projects. From 2005 - 2008 she served as the Senior Supervising Producer of <em>NOW on PBS</em>. She's worked with other top correspondents including Ed Bradley, Katie Couric, Jane Pauley, Morley Safer, Diane Sawyer, and Meredith Vieira, and broadcast executives Howard Stringer, Jeff Zucker and Andrew Lack. As Senior Producer at ABC News Productions, she oversaw the editorial content and production of over 50 documentaries, winning more than 50 awards. Martha is a graduate of Swarthmore College and serves on the colleges Board of Managers.</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td width="147" valign="top"><a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2007/06/nancy-11.jpg"><img class="alignleft size-full wp-image-2124" title="nancy 1" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2007/06/nancy-11.jpg" alt="" width="130" height="140" /></a></td>
<td width="501" valign="top">

<hr size="2" />
<p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify;"><span style="font-size: 10.0pt; font-family: &amp;amp;amp;" lang="EN-US"><strong>Nancy Vick</strong> has been active in the fields of Marketing and Strategic Planning for many years.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;"> </span>A former Senior Vice President of Ammirati &amp; Puris Advertising, New York, Nancy worked on industry analysis, strategy development and competitive positioning.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;"> </span>Nancy was educated at Cornell University and received her MBA from IMD, Lausanne, consistently ranked by the Financial Times as one of the worlds top five Business Schools. <span style="mso-spacerun: yes;"> </span>During her five years in Switzerland, Nancy was a Research Assistant to the Faculty of IMD and, under their supervision, published several international cases in Marketing and Strategic Planning with the International Case Clearing House (ICCH) at Harvard Business School.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;"> </span>She helped advice MBA students on their required real-life consulting projects and presentations.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;"> </span>Nancy was also appointed as IMDs first International Director of Marketing and Communications for both the Executive Education and MBA programs of IMD.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;"> </span>Nancy is an active participant and volunteer in the Arts in NYC and serves on the Boards of The American Classical Orchestra, a period instrument orchestra, (President Emeritus), and Quill Productions, an educational, entertainment non-profit that brings history to life through story and song. Nancy has travelled widely and continues to sing with several music organizations in both New York and Connecticut.</span></p>
<strong> </strong></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td width="147" valign="top"><a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2007/06/Deb-1.jpg"><img class="alignleft size-full wp-image-2122" title="Deb 1" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2007/06/Deb-1.jpg" alt="" width="130" height="138" /></a></td>
<td width="501" valign="top"><span style="font-family: Georgia, serif;"> </span>
<p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify;"><span style="font-weight: bold;"><strong><span style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%; font-family: &amp;amp;amp; color: black; mso-ansi-language: EN-US;" lang="EN-US">Deb Feyerick</span></strong></span><strong><span style="font-size: 8.5pt; font-family: Georgia, serif; color: black;"> </span></strong><span style="font-weight: bold;"><span style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%; font-family: &amp;amp;amp; color: black; mso-ansi-language: EN-US;" lang="EN-US"> </span></span><span><span style="font-size: 10pt; line-height: 115%; font-family: Verdana, sans-serif; color: black;" lang="EN-US">is an award-winning CNN correspondent whose stories have taken her across America and overseas to cities like London and Rio de Janeiro. Feyerick specializes in international terrorism, criminal justice and law enforcement. As part of CNNs investigative team covering 9/11, Feyerick received a National Headliner Award and was nominated for an Emmy for her reporting on al Qaeda. Feyerick reports on a range of stories including international child abduction, drug trafficking on the US-Mexico border, Somali pirate attacks, the life and death of Senator Edward Kennedy &amp; earlier his nephew John Kennedy Jr., religion in the recession, genetics, and the environment. She is trained on surviving war zones and delivered a cow while on assignment covering falling milk prices.F</span></span><span><span style="font-size: 10pt; line-height: 115%; font-family: Verdana, sans-serif; color: black;">eyerick has a Bachelor of Arts in English literature from Columbia University. In her spare time, she blogs about life as a working mom<strong>.</strong></span></span><span style="font-weight: bold; font-size: 10pt; line-height: 115%; font-family: Verdana, sans-serif;"> </span></p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td width="147" valign="top"></td>
<td width="501" valign="top"><hr size="2" /><strong> </strong></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td width="147" valign="top"><img class="alignleft" style="margin-top: 5px; margin-bottom: 5px;" title="directors_jessica_mayberry" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/06/directors_jessica_mayberry.jpg" alt="" width="130" height="140" /></td>
<td width="501" valign="top"><strong>Jessica Mayberry</strong> is the Founder and Executive Director of Video Volunteers. She started the organization in September 2003, after spending a year training rural Indian women in filmmaking as a Fellow of the American India Foundation. Jessica believes that video technology can empower the poor (women especially) to find a voice. She has extensive experience on the ground in India training communities in video production, and has since evolved Video Volunteers to emphasize capacity building, sustainability and community ownership. Prior to that Jessica worked in television in New York at Court TV, the Fox News Channel, and CNN. She is a fellow of <a href="http://www.echoinggreen.org/" target="_blank">Echoing Green</a> and was recognized as an <a href="http://www.waldzell.org/aof/jessica-mayberry.html" target="_blank">Architect of the Future</a> by the Waldzell Institute of Austria. Jessica has spoken about Video Volunteers work in numerous settings, including Stanford Business School, the NYU and Berkeley Journalism Schools and Oxford and Canterbury Universities in the UK. She serves on the board of Free the Children and on the Advisory Council of Counterpart International. She received her BA in Modern History and Modern Languages from Oxford University in 1999. To read more of Jessicas work and her vision <a href="http://www.pbs.org/idealab/technology/" target="_blank">click here</a>.</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td width="147" valign="top"></td>
<td width="501" valign="top"><strong> </strong></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td width="147" valign="top"></td>
<td width="501" valign="top"><strong> </strong></td>

<tr>
<td colspan="2" width="648" valign="top">
<h1><strong>Board of Trustees - India</strong></h1>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td width="147" valign="top"><img class="alignleft" style="margin: 5px;" title="abt_vv_directors_bipib_shah" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2007/06/abt_vv_directors_bipib_shah.jpg" alt="" width="130" height="140" /></td>
<td width="501" valign="top"><strong>Bipin Shah </strong>is a publisher and the owner of Mapin Publishing located in Ahmedabad, India. This publishing house is centered around publications that promote Indian arts and culture. Bipin graduated from the Gujarat University and went on to pursue a degree in B.E. (Chemical Engineering) from the University of Wisconsin, Madison.</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td width="147" valign="top"></td>
<td width="501" valign="top"><hr size="2" /><strong> </strong></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td width="147" valign="top"><img class="alignleft" style="margin: 5px;" title="abt_vv_directors_raj_kondur" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2007/06/abt_vv_directors_raj_kondur.jpg" alt="" width="130" height="140" /></td>
<td width="501" valign="top"><strong>Raj P. Kondur</strong> is a partner at Ascent Capital, a leading private equity firm focused on India with ~$600 million under management. He previously founded and was CEO of Nirvana Business Solutions, a leading back office processing and customer care company based in Bangalore. Raj co-founded and was Managing Director of Chrys Capital, Indias largest independent private equity fund. Raj is actively involved with several non-profit organizations in India. He is a founder and Board Member of The Akshaya Patra Foundation (www.akshayapatra.org), a school-based feeding program that currently feeds over 1.2 million children every day. Raj is a former professional tennis player and attended college in the US on a tennis scholarship. He has been featured numerous times on CNBC, in <em>BusinessWeek, Time, Newsweek, Harvard Business Review,</em> and in the leading business publications in India. He has a BBA from Georgia State University, and an MBA from Harvard Business School.</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td width="147" valign="top"></td>
<td width="501" valign="top"><hr size="2" /><strong> </strong></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td width="147" valign="top"><img class="alignleft" style="margin: 5px;" title="directors_stalin_K" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/06/directors_stalin_K.jpg" alt="" width="130" height="140" /></td>
<td width="501" valign="top"><strong>Stalin K.</strong> is the Managing Trustee   of Video Volunteers - India<em>.</em> <strong><em>Scroll up for more information on   him</em></strong><em>.</em></td>

Name="Bibliography" /> <w :LsdException Locked="false" Priority="39" QFormat="true" Name="TOC Heading" /> </w> </xml>< ![endif]--><!--[if gte mso 10]> <mce :style>< !   /* Style Definitions */ &amp;amp;amp;">Martha Spanninger</span></strong><span style="font-size: 12pt; line-height: 115%; font-family: &amp;amp;amp;"> is a Peabody award-winning documentary producer and broadcast journalist with more than twenty-five years of experience. Her career has included assignments with PBS (<em>Now on PBS</em>), ABC (<em>20/20</em>), NBC (<em>Dateline</em>), CBS (<em>CBS Reports</em> <em>West 57th</em>), MTV, and numerous independent projects. From 2005 - 2008 she served as the Senior Supervising Producer of <em>NOW on PBS</em>. <span> </span>She's worked with other top correspondents including Ed Bradley, Katie Couric, Jane Pauley, Morley Safer, Diane Sawyer, and Meredith Vieira, and broadcast executives Howard Stringer, Jeff Zucker and Andrew Lack. As Senior Producer at ABC News Productions, she oversaw the editorial content and production of over 50 documentaries, winning more than 50 awards. Martha is a graduate of Swarthmore College and serves on the colleges Board of Managers.</span></mce></div>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>How to Design a Social Campaign, Workshop by Stalin K.</title>
		<link>http://www.videovolunteers.org/?page_id=2215</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 16 Aug 2011 11:15:10 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>vvadmin</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.videovolunteers.org/?page_id=2215</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<div>
<table id="Table_01" style="height: 100%;" border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" width="98%">
<tbody>
<tr>
<td colspan="2">
<div><strong><img class="sam" style="font-family: &amp;amp;amp; font-size: 24px; font-weight: bold; color: #c00; text-align: center; text-decoration: none;" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/images/invite_01.gif" alt="" width="634" height="116" /></strong></div></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td colspan="2"></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td colspan="2" align="center"><strong> </strong>

<strong> </strong>
<div>

<strong> </strong><strong> </strong>

<strong>Learn to Design an Effective Social Campaign</strong>

<strong>28th - 29th September 2011 in Goa</strong><strong> </strong>

<strong> </strong><strong> </strong>

</div></td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
</div>
<strong>
WHO CAN APPLY?</strong>

<strong> Social movements, non-profits, trade unions, social businesss and individuals who champion human rights causes. We highly recommend the NGO director or senior activist apply.</strong>

ARE YOU PLANNING TO LAUNCH A CAMPAIGN TO GATHER AND INVOLVE THE MASSES IN ISSUES YOU BELEIVE IN? DO YOU WANT TO LOBBY WITH A SPECIFIC GROUP TO ADVOCATE FOR A PARTICULAR CAUSE? ARE YOU TRYING TO FIGURE OUT WHAT WAS MISSING IN THAT LAST CAMPAIGN YOU DESIGNED?

STALIN K - ONE OF INDIA'S LEADING SOCIAL COMMUNICATORS AND MEDIA ACTIVISTS - WILL HELP YOU FIND ANSWERS TO ALL YOUR CAMPAIGN QUESTIONS AND DESIGN AN EFFECTIVE CAMPAIGN.
<div><strong><a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/DESIGNING AN EFFECTIVE CAMPAIGN form.docx" target="new"><span style="text-decoration: underline;">APPLY NOW</span></a></strong></div>
<div><strong>Please send in your applications forms by 30th August 2011 </strong></div>
<div><strong><a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/InviteI.html" target="new"><span style="text-decoration: underline;">WHAT WILL BE COVERED?</span></a></strong></div>
<div><strong>Identifying key elements and integrating diverse strategies</strong></div>
<div><strong><a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/InviteII.html" target="new"><span style="text-decoration: underline;">WHAT TO EXPECT AT THE WORKSHOP?</span></a></strong></div>
<div><strong>Critical analysis and creative solutions</strong></div>
<div><strong><a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/InviteIII.html" target="new"><span style="text-decoration: underline;">WHAT TO EXPECT AFTER THE WORKSHOP?</span></a></strong></div>
<div><strong>Let the campaign begin</strong></div>
<strong>WORKSHOP FACILITATOR :</strong>

<strong> </strong><strong> <a href="http://stalink.wordpress.com" target="new"><span style="text-decoration: underline;">Stalin K</span></a></strong>

<strong>Director of  Video Volunteers and a media and human rights activist, with 20 years  experience pioneering new models of participatory media. He is an  internationally acclaimed documentary filmmaker and a greatly admired teacher  and trainer.He is one of  Indias leading exponents of community radio, community video and has designed  more than 20 <a href="http://stalink.wordpress.com/campaign-design/" target="new"><span style="text-decoration: underline;">campaigns</span></a></strong>

<strong>Workshop Fee: Rs. 15,000</strong>

<strong>For all  expenses not including travel.<a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/InviteIV.html" target="new"> <span style="text-decoration: underline;">Click for details</span></a></strong>

<strong>For more  information, please write to <a class="sam" href="mailto:naomi@videovolunteers.org"><span style="text-decoration: underline;">naomi@videovolunteers.org</span></a></strong>

<!-- End Save for Web Slices -->]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Partnerships Manager</title>
		<link>http://www.videovolunteers.org/?page_id=2384</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 21 Oct 2011 09:13:57 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>vvadmin</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.videovolunteers.org/?page_id=2384</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<strong>Partnerships Manager</strong>

The Partnerships Manager is primarily responsible for building partnerships and developing new and exciting projects. Responsibilities include, working with senior management to strategize and manage all outreach work; communicating with partners; writing reports; handling budgets; and representing Video Volunteers at conferences and events.You will work closely with Senior Management to drive forward the depth and reach of Video Volunteers work.

<strong><span style="text-decoration: underline;">Qualifications:</span></strong>
<ul>
	<li>At least three years work experience</li>
	<li>Experience in the NGO sector</li>
	<li>Very strong communications skills - including English writing and public speaking skills</li>
	<li>Great organizational skills</li>
	<li>Networking skills</li>
	<li>Innovative and creative thinker with a passion for empowering marginalized communities</li>
</ul>
<strong><span style="text-decoration: underline;">Location:</span></strong>Goa, India

<strong><span style="text-decoration: underline;">Key Responsibilities:</span></strong>
<ul>
	<li>Bring in commissioned projects and manage their execution</li>
	<li>Develop and implement our Earned Income Strategy</li>
	<li>Handle relationships and all communications with partners</li>
	<li>Oversee the finances and maintain the budgets of all partnership projects</li>
	<li>Document all projects  write Memorandums of Understanding, Terms of References, Project Reports etc.</li>
	<li>Assist Senior Management with grant writing as and when needed</li>
</ul>
Fill the online application form<strong><a href="http://videovolunteersindia.wufoo.com/forms/video-volunteers-online-job-application/">here</a></strong>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>2384</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2011-10-21 02:13:57</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2011-10-21 09:13:57</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>closed</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>partnerships-manager</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>draft</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>1677</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type>page</wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>
		<wp:postmeta>

	<item>
		<title>old partner page</title>
		<link>http://www.videovolunteers.org/?page_id=2460</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov 2011 07:07:32 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>vvadmin</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.videovolunteers.org/?page_id=2460</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Video Volunteers is constantly seeking new, exciting collaborations and partnership opportunities. Are you an NGO looking to expand the reach of your organization? Perhaps you want training in filmmaking and communications? Or maybe you need help to design a really effective, innovative campaign? ** Note: if you are a media house curious to know how community-produced content could enhance your programming, please contact us to discuss how we can work together. You can view our other mainstream media partners we have collaborated with here. Our community network produces high quality work tailored to your needs, specifications and style. Outlined below are a number of potential ways your organization can work with Video Volunteers. If you dont see what you are looking for here, but are still interested in working with Video Volunteers, then please do not hesitate to get in touch. We are always keen to work with other interesting organizations on innovative projects. Set up a Community Video Unit (CVU) Our flagship model is the Community Video Unit (CVU). CVUs are local production entities, created by Video Volunteers in partnership with different NGOs, that are run by up to 10 community members trained in all aspects of video production and distribution. These community video producers make films on issues decided by community editorial boards, that they then screen back on widescreen projectors to thousands of people in the community. By doing so, they help expand the scale and scope of the NGO and their program. A CVU is not a onetime projectit is a long term program requiring continued support and investment from the partner NGO. It is an exciting opportunity for NGOs to increase their reach and empower people in their communities to narrate their own stories and take concrete action to right the wrongs they witness. Please click here for more details. Nominate a IndiaUnheard Community Correspondent Our IndiaUnheard program is a pioneering model that enables your organization to have a community member closely associated with your organization trained in all aspects of video storytelling. You can nominate people that are community activists to be Community Correspondents (CCs), throughout the year, for training that takes place twice yearly. These people will become the voice of your community and your organization will benefit too because the issues you have been championing can reach far and wide through our network. Please review our page on the Fellowship and Criteria Process for Community Correspondents, where you can also find links to the Frequently Asked Questions on what will be required from Community Correspondents, as well as, the Application/Nomination Form. Start an IndiaUnheard Regional Hub Video Volunteers is currently seeking NGO partners across India to establish regional hubs of IndiaUnheard. These regional hubs will co-ordinate networks of Community Correspondents, ensuring locally produced media reaches a truly global audience. By acting as a regional chapter, your organization will be actively involved in amplifying the voices of the marginalized communities you work with. This is an exciting opportunity increase our ever-expanding network of Community Correspondents  one day we aim to have a Community Correspondent in every district in India! Find out more about starting a Regional Hub here. Create an Issue-based Campaign Video Volunteers staff have years of experience designing and setting up campaigns. Does your organization campaign on a particular issue? Perhaps access to water, education or health? If so, have you ever wondered what it would be like to have access to a wide range of stories, on your particular issue, from across India? With the IndiaUnheard network of Community Correspondents this can happen. The people from the communities you serve can become the key people designing the communications for your campaign. Our Community Correspondents have strong associations with social movements and access to information that is otherwise difficult to get. They can provide your campaign with rich and varied grassroots stories  an excellent resource that ensures your campaign remains innovative and accessible. Learn more about how the process works here. Community Radio Community radio is a great way to disseminate information and empower marginalized voices and is of particular importance in remote areas where access to mainstream media is curtailed. Video Volunteers can set up a community radio station in collaboration with your NGO. The Managing Trustee of Video Volunteers, Stalin K., is a long-time leader in the community media movement, is the former convener of Community Radio Forum-India, and has been involved in designing, training and producing some of the most successful community radio programs in India. Stalin is one of the leading voices to democratize Indias airwaves and has been in the forefront of the fight for communities right to own and run their own radio stations. Video Volunteers believes in community-owned and managed radio, and has helped many organizations to set up their projects. See more details here. Film Production Video Volunteers is an organization headed by filmmakers. We have trained over 200 disadvantaged people to be filmmakers. We know about film! Whether your organization wants a sleek promotional video or really exciting content produced by our Community Producers we can provide various services to suit different budgets. You can also learn more about the background of Stalin K. (Video Volunteers' Managing Trustee) and his work on documentary productions here. Training and Consultancy Video Volunteers staff have years of experience in training and strategy design. We can provide your staff with in-depth and valuable training in communications (audio, video, photography, theatre, storytelling, etc.) and community media. We have worked with community members, teachers, students and staff members from a host of organizations. We can also design strategies and campaigns for the non-profit sector as well as perform communications audits. Learn more about some of our other past projects and also take a look at the website for Stalin K., Video Volunteers' Managing Trustee. Please note Video Volunteers does not provide free trainings or workshops. If you are interested in any of these possible partnership opportunities, or have other ideas, please write to info@videovolunteers.org with a brief summary of the work your organization does and an outline of your idea for collaboration.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Partner with Us</title>
		<link>http://www.videovolunteers.org/?page_id=2519</link>
		<pubDate>Sat, 28 Jan 2012 06:48:14 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>vvadmin</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.videovolunteers.org/?page_id=2519</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h1>Partner With Us</h1>
Video Volunteers has partnered with over 50 NGOs, foundations, media companies and documentary projects. Please write to us at info @<a href="http://videovolunteers.org/" target="_blank">videovolunteers.org</a>for more information. All money earned by Video Volunteers through such collaborations enables us to empower and support more Community Producers.

Two of the main ways wepartnerwith other groups are:
<h2><strong><span style="text-decoration: underline;">Training</span></strong></h2>
Video Volunteers trains people from marginalized communities to be Community Video Producers. We can train people in the communities where you work to report on local issues. We can then help them distribute this content both in their communities and to an international audience through online platforms and the mainstream media.

By training people from marginalized communities as Community Producers you are:
<ul>
	<li>Enabling community members to become proficient video activists who create video content and mobilize their communities to take action</li>
	<li>Providing a platform for communities to express their ideas and create sustainable solutions</li>
	<li>Bringing community voices into global discussions on important social issues</li>
	<li>Developing the intellectual capacities of community members who will gain a deep knowledge of multiple social issues</li>
</ul>
After the initial training, all participants are invited to become part of our<a href="http://indiaunheard.videovolunteers.org/" target="_blank">IndiaUnheard</a>network; a vibrant and diverse group of video activists working across India to bring change in their communities.
<h2><strong><span style="text-decoration: underline;">Campaigns</span></strong></h2>
Does your organization campaign on a particular issue? Perhaps access to water, education or health? If so, have you ever wondered what it would be like to have access to a wide range of stories, on your particular issue, from across India? Video Volunteers can make this happen for you. Our Community Producers have strong associations with social movements and access to information that is otherwise difficult to get. They can provide your campaign with rich and varied grassroots stories  an excellent resource that ensures your campaign remains innovative and accessible.<a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/programmes/indiaunheard/create-an-issue-based-campaign-with-indiaunheard" target="_blank">Learn more about how the process works here.</a>

<strong>Please write to us at info (a)<a href="http://videovolunteers.org/" target="_blank">videovolunteers.org</a>for more information.</strong>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Strategic Manager</title>
		<link>http://www.videovolunteers.org/?page_id=2592</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 20 Jun 2012 09:59:45 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>vvadmin</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.videovolunteers.org/?page_id=2592</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<strong></strong><strong>Strategic Manager </strong>

<strong></strong>The Strategic Manager is responsible for implementing the strategic plan and keeping the organization on target. You will work with staff to assign tasks, find alternate ways to reach a particular goal, and trouble-shoot. Youll be involved with all members of the VV team  ccs, outside partners, the media and especially other staff.

<strong></strong><strong>Qualifications:
</strong>
<ul>
	<li>At least six years work experience</li>
	<li>Experience in the NGO sector</li>
	<li>Very strong communications and writing skills</li>
	<li>Great organizational skills and manager</li>
	<li>Networking skills</li>
	<li>Innovative and creative thinker with a passion for empowering marginalized communities</li>
</ul>
<strong></strong><strong>Location:Goa, India</strong>

<strong></strong><strong>Key Responsibilities:
</strong>
<ul>
	<li>Work with staff on their monthly plans and to help them keep on target</li>
	<li>Oversee the organizations metrics system and be familiar with the budget</li>
	<li>Assist in hiring new staff and creating job descriptions</li>
	<li>Work with outside partners, such as NGOs and the media, to understand their needs and to shape project descriptions and launch new projects</li>
	<li>Be very involved in all aspects of organizational communications, such as funding proposals, website copy, etc.</li>
	<li>Document all projects  write Memorandums of Understanding, Terms of References, Project Reports etc.</li>
	<li>Grant-writing and researching</li>
	<li>Mentor community correspondents</li>
</ul>
Fill the online application form<strong><a href="http://videovolunteersindia.wufoo.com/forms/video-volunteers-online-job-application/">here</a></strong>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Executive Producer</title>
		<link>http://www.videovolunteers.org/?page_id=2593</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 20 Jun 2012 10:01:39 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>vvadmin</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.videovolunteers.org/?page_id=2593</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<strong></strong><strong>Executive Producer</strong>

The Executive Producer will create special projects from the stories created by the Community Correspondents. VV has a huge amount of material coming in from the field, and were starting to create additional video products. The idea is always to maintain the integrity of what the Community Correspondents produce, while packaging it for different audiences. Content produced would include web videos, special projects for TV, pilots of different shows, and new formats. The Executive Producer will also have a role in ensuring quality control on all VV videos and in evaluating and monitoring the content.

<strong></strong><strong>Qualifications:
</strong>
<ul>
	<li>At least six years work experience</li>
	<li>Able to shoot write and edit videos</li>
	<li>Fluency in Hindi and English</li>
	<li>At least four years experience in mainstream television</li>
	<li>Experience managing teams</li>
	<li>Experience in web video a plus</li>
	<li>Can show samples of videos you have shot, written and edited yourself</li>
</ul>
<strong></strong><strong>Location:Goa, India</strong>

Key Responsibilities:
<ul>
	<li>Produce a VV web show</li>
	<li>Create messaging for content online</li>
	<li>Produce pilots</li>
	<li>Evaluate videos</li>
	<li>Advise on content coming in and overseeing edits</li>
	<li>Creating the content management system</li>
	<li>Mentor community correspondents</li>
</ul>
Fill the online application form<strong><a href="http://videovolunteersindia.wufoo.com/forms/video-volunteers-online-job-application/">here</a></strong>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Forced Eviction Advocacy Manager</title>
		<link>http://www.videovolunteers.org/?page_id=2619</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 11 Jul 2012 12:26:28 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>vvadmin</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.videovolunteers.org/?page_id=2619</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h2>Forced Eviction Advocacy Manager</h2>
The <strong>Forced Eviction Advocacy Manager</strong>will join the team of a collaborative project between <a href="http://www.witness.org/">WITNESS</a>, <a href="http://videovolunteers.org">Video Volunteers</a> and the <a href="http://www.hic-net.org/">Habitat International Coalition</a> to organize the production of advocacy video to the support the objectives of existing human rights campaigns addressing housing and land rights  specifically forced evictions and land-grabbing. The contract is for 12 months and the position is based with Video Volunteers in India.

The <strong>Forced Eviction Advocacy manager</strong>will be the first point of contact and primary liaison among the partners in this collaboration.

<strong>Project Description:</strong>

The WITNESS global campaign on forced evictions in collaboration with the Habitat International Coalition is currently supporting 15 local campaigns in 5 countries. The globalcampaign seeks to use video and technology to achieve the advocacy goals outlined in each local campaign and, if strategic, leverage the emblematic local campaigns at the regional and international levels to impact key policies and decisions at these levels.

In India, WITNESS, Video Volunteers and the Habitat International Coalition  Housing and Land Rights Network are working with national and local networks, organizations and experts to integrate video and technology into existing campaigns on forced evictions and land grabbing in the country.

<strong><span style="text-decoration: underline;">Primary Responsibilities</span></strong>
<ul>
	<li>Mapcommunities at-risk of forced evictions and land-grabbing or that have already been removed from their land as well as the organizations and the networks campaigning for change</li>
	<li>Survey key networks, organizations and experts on prioritized campaigns and assess which campaigns would benefit from video advocacy</li>
	<li>Based on the mapping and research recommend campaigns and video productions to the primary three collaborators</li>
	<li>Based on the mapping and research identify communities around India that are at-risk of forced evictions and land grabbing, and recruit one Community Correspondent from each one</li>
	<li>Provide training inputs on forced eviction (and how to document it) for new Community Correspondents</li>
	<li>Supportthe Community Producers and Community Correspondents to produce videos to complement these priority campaigns</li>
	<li>Advise the Community Producers and Community Correspondents on storytelling, interviews and strategic messaging for the videos</li>
	<li>Advise organizations and networks on the strategic distribution for the video within their campaigns to reach, as a priority, the individual decision-makers relevant to each campaign</li>
	<li>Design online materialsto promote the videos and the related campaigns</li>
	<li>Inventory and curate online other existing video on forced evictions and land-grabbing in the country, including of course the video produced through this project</li>
	<li>Track news items and action alerts to monitor the development of individual campaigns and any related information for campaign planning and share them with the relevant persons in the collaboration</li>
	<li>Provide summarized monthly status reports on the progress of the projects including metrics for monitoring and evaluation (e.g., which decision-makers have received a screening, the number public screenings, the number of online views, etc.)</li>
</ul>
<strong><span style="text-decoration: underline;">Experience Required</span></strong>
<ul>
	<li>Experience with and passion for human rights with experience in housing and land rights - in particular forced evictions and land grabbing</li>
	<li>Demonstrated skills and knowledge or at least interest in using video and media for human rights</li>
	<li>Demonstrated skills and knowledge in methods to distribute media including online and offline distribution including private and independent media streams and in person screenings</li>
	<li>3-5 years developing and managing human rights campaigns at the state and national level</li>
	<li>Well-organized, detail-oriented and proven ability to meet deadlines</li>
	<li>Excellent writing, communication, computer and social media skills</li>
	<li>Intermediary English reading/writing skills</li>
	<li>Video production and editing skills a plus</li>
</ul>
<div>Apply for this position <a href=" http://videovolunteersindia.wufoo.com/forms/video-volunteers-online-job-application/">here</a>.</div>
&nbsp;]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
