	<item>
		<title>Video Producer</title>
		<link>http://www.videovolunteers.org/?page_id=2691</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 31 Oct 2012 12:11:46 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>vvadmin</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.videovolunteers.org/?page_id=2691</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h3>Video Producer</h3>
Video Volunteers is seeking a Producer to make a monthly 6-10 minute web show. The core content will be the videos made by VVs network of 100+ Community Correspondents across India. In most months, the webshow will be a round up of the best community-produced content from that month, or will focus on a particular issue that the Community Correspondents are currently exploring, such as gender, forced evictions or health.

It will be anchored most of the time by VVs director Stalin K. and will be pushed out to bloggers and VVs partners in the mainstream media. The show will become the central piece of VVs online distribution strategy, allowing us to showcase the Community Correspondents best content and to engage online audiences in a conversation about issues at the intersection of human rights, media, and community development.

It will show people the behind the scenes of producing community media and tell stories about our Community Correspondents, their lives and the issues they face.

<strong><span style="text-decoration: underline;">Qualifications:</span></strong>
<ul>
	<li>Strong experience in shooting, writing and editing your own videos</li>
	<li>Understanding of Indian socio-political issues and human rights</li>
	<li>Experience in web video best practices and online distribution a plus</li>
	<li>Sharing VVs core belief in empowering community voices</li>
</ul>
<strong><span style="text-decoration: underline;">Location:</span></strong>Goa, India

<strong><span style="text-decoration: underline;">Time Commitment:</span></strong> approximately five days per month

<strong><span style="text-decoration: underline;">Equipment:</span></strong> VV will provide the shooting equipment but the editor should come with his or her own editing set up, ideally FCP so that the edits can move onto VV office computers if need be.

<strong><span style="text-decoration: underline;">Key Responsibilities:</span></strong>
<ul>
	<li>Watch the ten best IndiaUnheard videos of the last month, as selected by the VV staff. These are three minute edited and subtitled videos that have already been seen online</li>
	<li>Decide which of those videos to feature in this months show, and create a rough structure/flow, on paper, of the video</li>
	<li>Watch the selected videos with VV staff and primarily with Stalin K., VVs director who will be the anchor</li>
	<li>Create the final script, shoot Stalins narration and pieces to camera, and edit it together</li>
</ul>
To apply, fill out the online application form<a href="http://videovolunteersindia.wufoo.com/forms/video-volunteers-online-job-application/"><strong>here</strong></a>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>2691</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2012-10-31 05:11:46</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2012-10-31 12:11:46</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>closed</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>closed</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>video-producer</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>draft</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>1677</wp:post_parent>

		<wp:post_password></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>Projects</title>
		<link>http://www.videovolunteers.org/projects-2/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 11 Jun 2007 12:59:24 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>nladmin</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.videovolunteers.org/?page_id=46</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h1>Projects</h1>
<p class="none_id"><em><strong>Video Volunteers</strong></em><strong> undertook many different kinds of 'media for development' projects before arriving at the model of the Community Video Unit. Between 2003 and 2005, 17 different NGOs invited us to give them technical assistance on media projects in six different countries, all of which helped us learn how media can be most impactful, sustainable and empowering for communities and organizations.</strong></p>
<p class="none_id"><strong>We trained NGOs in filmmaking and helped to establish NGO Media Units. </strong>In these projects, staff of NGOs were trained to produce films for training and advocacy purposes. Most of these Units continue operating today. <strong>We also sent volunteer filmmakers</strong> to make films for NGOs and advise as "executive producers" to ensure the films would meet the NGOs' goals. These projects enabled NGOs to access low-cost films for fundraising, and foreign filmmakers to learn how to tell stories about development issues. More than half the volunteers remain involved in Community Media in their current careers. Since all these projects were carried out by passionate and hard-working volunteers (including ourselves), we chose the name Video Volunteers for our organization.</p>

<table width="100%" border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="10">
<tbody>
<tr>
<td>
<h3>Media Units for Arts and Culture: Bahia, Brazil</h3>
<em>Partner Organization: </em><em>Rhythmic Uprising</em>
<p class="floatRight"><img class="alignleft" style="margin: 5px;" alt="Media Units for Arts and Culture: Bahia, Brazil" src="http://farm2.static.flickr.com/1395/1417363527_524e05549e.jpg" width="240" height="160" align="right" />Video Volunteers partnered with Rhythmic Uprising to send volunteer filmmakers to provide media training to four local NGOs in Bahia, Brazil. The local NGOs involved have received cameras and editing computers, as well as training.</p>
<p class="floatRight">Bahia is the musical capital of Brazil, and NGOs there use media, dance and music to empower and engage the local youth. Rhythmic Uprising is also producing a feature-length documentary about how a powerful grassroots movement is overcoming social and economic depression, by involving children in performing arts such as drumming, dance, capoeira and circus. Volunteer filmmakers continue to assist on that project. <a href="http://www.rhythmicuprising.org/" target="_blank"> Read more about Rhythmic Uprising</a>.</p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>
<h3>Child marriage Community video project: Andhra Pradesh, India</h3>
<em>Partner Organization: Velugu</em>
<p class="floatRight"><img alt="" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2007/06/pastprojects_sp02.jpg" width="240" height="160" align="right" />Video Volunteers conducted a video workshop with 11 rural women in South India. During the six-week training, the trainees - all married as children themselves - produced a half hour video on why child marriage must be stopped. The workshop transformed the women from a point where they believed their husbands should be allowed to beat them, to vowing on screen to educate their daughters. The video was screened in local villages, with the Producers and villagers declaring that never before had child marriage or indeed, any other women's issue been discussed in public. This project, and the intense and successful intellectual training of these rural women, led Video Volunteers and Drishti to the original idea of the Community Video Unit.<a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2007/08/april_2004.pdf" target="_blank">Read more about the Sneha Praja Video Project</a>.</p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>
<h3>NGO Media Unit for Women's Empowerment: Gujarat, India</h3>
<em>Partner Organization: </em><em><a href="http://anandi-india.org/default.aspx" target="_blank">ANANDI</a></em>
<p class="floatRight"><img class="alignleft" style="margin: 5px;" alt="" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2007/06/currentprojects_anandi.jpg" width="240" height="160" /></p>
Activists at ANANDI, an NGO working with rural and tribal women, were trained to produce advocacy and training videos that they screen in village meetings and on local cable systems. Since the 3-month Video Volunteers workshop in 2004 by filmmakers Jen and Lindsay Utz, the Media Unit at ANANDI has produced more than five documentaries on different issues that they screen regularly in the villages. The production team includes a senior ANANDI activist, the organization's computer operator, and two young women from the community: a young Muslim girl and young Tribal girl. ANANDI has developed an innovative system to market their video magazine (called UMANG VIDEO) through subscriptions and sales to other NGOs. They also screen their films on Indian national television, have created interesting collaborations with local media, and the NGO Directors use them for national and international networking. They used video very effectively during a state-wide, month-long march for Rural Employment, in which the producers made one video every day exposing the lack of services in each of the villages they visited. They screened them nightly on the local cable networks, to rally the support of the town residents for the cause of rural employment.</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>
<h3>Video Training for Environmental Campaigns, Mexico and UK</h3>
<em>Partner Organization: </em><a href="http://www.rareconservation.org" target="_blank"><em>RARE Conservation</em></a>
<p class="floatRight"><img class="alignright" style="margin: 5px;" alt="" src="http://farm2.static.flickr.com/1259/1418245140_5d3aa705b1.jpg" width="240" height="172" /></p>
Video Volunteers conducted two intensive video workshops for the DC-based environmental organization Rare Conservation. Rare Conservation develops environmental campaigns geared at local people living in ecologically sensitive areas, in partnership with local environmental activists. The Rare Pride Campaigners are trained in the communications tools of puppetry, street theater, postering and radio. Video Volunteers trained the campaigners in designing video campaigns, and created video modules for their Communications Manual, enabling future Rare Pride Campaigners to use short films to strengthen their campaigns.</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>
<h3>NGO Media Unit for Bhopal Gas Disaster Victims: Bhopal, India</h3>
<em>Partner Organization: </em><em><a href="http://www.bhopal.org/index.php?id=20" target="_blank">Sambhavna Clinic</a></em>
<p class="floatRight"><img class="alignleft" style="margin: 5px;" alt="" src="http://farm2.static.flickr.com/1310/1418245652_7dc51d2dae_m.jpg" width="240" height="160" /></p>
Health Workers at The Sambavna Clinic in Bhopal were trained to make educational videos to help people recover from diseases resulting from exposure to toxic gases. Bhopal is the site of the world's worst industrial disaster, the Union Carbide gas factory explosion in 1984 in which 22,000 people were killed. The Sambhavna Clinic decided they needed to use video to access the harder to reach victims of the disaster in the urban slums of Bhopal. Most of the organization's health training sessions on issues like TB, which is rampant amongst the victims' are conducted during the day, which makes it very difficult to reach men who are working. With video, they felt they could reach the men in the evenings at popular outdoor video screenings.
Video volunteer Joaquin Ruano worked with the health workers to produce three short health videos that were screened back to the community. The NGO continues to use video as a tool in health awareness and human rights documentation.</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>
<h3>Wedding Video Training Program: Gujarat, India</h3>
<em>Partner Organization: </em><a href="http://www.navsarjan.org" target="_blank"><em>Navsarjan Trust</em></a>
<p class="floatRight"><img class="alignright" style="margin: 5px;" alt="" src="http://farm2.static.flickr.com/1350/1418244180_aa8e7146a7_o.jpg" width="240" height="160" /></p>
Video Volunteers' first training was a joint training with two of Drishti's Gujarat-based partners, Navsjaran and Center for Social Justice. Both of these organizations have since launched Community Video Units.

During this workshop, filmmaker volunteers Chandler Griffin and Gabriella Kessler trained Navsarjan workers in video-making, which subsequently led to the creation of a wedding video production school. Navsarjan runs a job training school for young Dalits called Dalit Shakti Kendra, to help them escape from caste-based occupations such as manual scavenging. Thousands of youth have learned trades like tailoring, policing, and cell-phone repair. They now can learn wedding video production. The young people who take the course have generally succeeded in finding employment (either by launching their own business or working for a local videographer) and have raised their incomes substantially. They have realized there is a real need for wedding videographers from the Dalit community. At Dalit weddings, the 'upper'-caste videographers would not eat with the Dalit wedding party, so the wedding would have to stop while the videographers went elsewhere for a lunch paid for by the wedding-givers, adding extra expense to the whole affair.
<p class="floatRight"><img class="alignleft" style="margin: 5px;" alt="" src="http://farm2.static.flickr.com/1100/1417363039_9ac7888497_m.jpg" width="240" height="160" /></p>
A year after the Workshop, Navsarjan sent the four trainees -- all young Dalit women working in the organization -- to the US to attend a documentary workshop by<a href="http://www.barefootworkshops.org/" target="_blank">Barefoot</a>, the media NGO started by their volunteer trainer Chandler Griffin. The young women traveled to Mississippi where they made a film comparing race and caste, perhaps the first ever film to look at American race issues through the lens of caste.</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>
<h3>Human Rights Documentation Unit: Gujarat, India</h3>
<p class="none_id"><em>Partner Organization: <a href="http://www.centreforsocialjustice.net/" target="_blank">Center for Social Justice</a></em></p>
Staff from the Center for Social Justice were also trained in the first Video Volunteers workshop (described above), including the organization's driver. Center for Social Justice is a human rights organization that, among other things, trains 'barefoot lawyers' to prosecute cases against marginalized groups in rural areas, such as atrocities against Dalits, land rights violations, and violence against women. During the workshop, the trainees from Navsarjan and DSK shot footage for a court case of manual scavenging, the illegal caste-based occupation of removing human sewage with their bare hands. The CSJ videographers have continued to produce videos, including a series of video raids exposing the absence of mandatory government services in rural areas; a daily video program of highlights from a 'games for change' sporting event, broadcast daily on cable TV; and video testimony from victims of communal rioting in Gujarat.</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>
<h3>Native American Water Rights</h3>
<em>Partner Organizations: <a href="http://www.northernarapaho.com/pr/" target="_blank">Northern Arapaho Tribal Council</a> and Watershed Resources, Inc.</em>
<p class="floatRight"><img class="alignright" style="margin: 5px;" alt="" src="http://farm2.static.flickr.com/1069/1417363645_8b51680ebe_o.jpg" width="240" height="160" /></p>
Video Volunteers produced a film for the Northern Arapaho and Eastern Shoshone Tribes on their water struggle. These two Wyoming Tribes, from the Wind River Reservation, live on the continental divide and have access to the single greatest water right in the continental US. This right was recognized by the US Supreme Court over a decade ago, but the Tribe has never succeeded in developing their water, and continue to live in poverty. The Tribe's water consultant decided that one of the major things stopping the Tribe from exercising their water was lack of awareness. Because of the negative and anti-Tribal local press, most people thought they had lost the court case, not won. And very few people had any idea as to the financial value of the water. So Video Volunteers produced a film on the water issue, and designed an innovative distribution plan. Every child on the Reservation would take home a copy of the DVD from school, with an assignment to watch the film with their parents.

The DVD included a card in which people could vote for what they wanted to do with the water. Did they want to bottle it? Use it only for spiritual use? Use it for recreation and fishing? This was designed to increase people's participation in Tribal government. The video had one early victory. At the first public screening, the two Tribal governments (who are historically at opposition to each other, and were forced to share a Reservation) came together for the first time in decades and publicly promised to create a joint water board - a critical factor in winning the legal battle.
<p class="none_id"><a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2007/08/oct_2005.pdf" target="_blank">Read the newsletter about the project.</a></p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>
<h3>AIDS Prevention: Rwanda and Uganda</h3>
<em>Partner Organization: </em><em><a href="http://www.fxb.org" target="_blank">FXB</a></em>
<p class="floatRight"><img class="alignleft" style="margin: 5px;" alt="" src="http://farm2.static.flickr.com/1199/1417362737_e39d53302c_m.jpg" width="226" height="142" /></p>
<strong></strong>
Returning video volunteer Chandler Griffin and Cecily Pingree worked with FXB, an international AIDS organization, to produce a video on their work in AIDS prevention that was screened in various FXB events, including a star-studded fundraiser in New York.
<strong>
</strong>
<strong>
</strong>
<strong>
</strong>
<h3>Refugee Education: Kenya</h3>
<em>Partner Organization: </em><em><a href="http://www.filmaid.org/" target="_blank">FilmAid International</a></em>

FilmAid International uses the power of film to promote health, strengthen communities and enrich the lives of the world's vulnerable and uprooted. They are producing advocacy videos on the sexual exploitation of refugees, to be screened in refugee camps around Kenya and on Kenyan television. Video Volunteer Brahm Rosensweig assisted in the production of this video.</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>
<h3>Homelessness: New York</h3>
<em>Partner Organization:<a href="http://www.jerichoproject.org/" target="_blank">The Jericho Project</a></em>

<em><img class="alignleft" style="margin: 5px;" alt="" src="http://www.jerichoproject.org/storage/jericho/images/jericho_groundbreaking_veterans_small.jpg" width="240" height="180" /> </em>

<em></em>Two New York-based filmmakers, Andrew Ellis and Daniel Gorman, volunteered with The Jericho Project.

Jericho Project is a Harlem-based organization that offers long-term housing, job placement, and support to homeless recovering addicts. Their story-based film is aimed at a variety of audiences: funders at annual dinners, but also residents in New York's homeless shelters whom Jericho hopes to inspire to make changes in their lives.</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>
<h3>Cultural Documentation: Brazil</h3>
<em>Partner Organization: </em><a href="http://www.vivafavela.com.br/" target="_blank"><em>Viva Favela</em></a>

<img class="alignleft" style="margin: 5px;" alt="" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2007/06/pastprojects_vivafavela.jpg" width="240" height="180" />

The Rio-based organization Viva Favela runs a web-portal and internet cafes targeted at the residents of Rio's favelas, or slums. The purpose is to link the favelas with the outside world, and to raise awareness amongst middle class Brazilians of life in the Favelas.Video Volunteer Sofia Burstoff traveled to the NGO in February 2003 to help them explore how they can integrate brief video-stories and portraits into their online newspaper. Sofia also produced an outreach video to encourage schools to use the website.</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>
<h3>Blindness prevention: Madurai, India</h3>
<em>Partner Organization: </em><a href="http://www.aravind.org/" target="_blank"><em>Aravind Eye Hospital</em></a>

The Aravind Eye Hospital is one of the largest eye-care facilities in the world, having prevented blindness in hundreds of thousands of poor people throughout India. Video Volunteer Aditya Thayi shot a teaching video aimed at eye care professionals working in 170 hospitals worldwide that replicate the Aravind model. The teaching video was designed to instruct hospital managers on how they can improve their outreach into poor communities.</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>
<h3>Fundraising: Mumbai, India</h3>
<em>Partner Organization: </em><a href="http://www.akanksha.org/" target="_blank"><em>Akanksha</em></a>
<p class="floatRight"><img class="alignleft" style="margin: 5px;" alt="" src="http://farm2.static.flickr.com/1147/1418244118_a707f0cfc4_m.jpg" width="240" height="180" /></p>
"Aspiration" is a promotional video for Akanksha, a slum children's education program in Mumbai. The 15-minute video uses portraits of two children to give the viewer a glimpse of life in the slums, and shows how Akanksha transforms children's lives. Akanksha is using its film in three ways: (i) recruitment - it is shown to teachers interested in volunteering; (ii) fundraising - DVDs are included in mass mailings; and (iii) awareness - in April 2004, it was screened in front of 300 people at a fundraiser in New York. It has also been shown to school children in NYC.</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>
<h3>Advocacy: Assam, India</h3>
<em>Partner Organization: I-CARD</em>
<p class="floatRight">"People of the Flood Plains" is an advocacy video for I-CARD, an NGO that seeks to strengthen the cultural identity of the Mising, one of the poorest and most overlooked Tribes in Assam. The film tells the story of the land struggles of one particular village that exemplify the whole tribe's experience. It is screened in Mising villages so the community becomes aware of shared problems and can begin to explore solutions.</p>
<p class="floatRight">I-CARD was also trained in basic video production: Assamese youth have often turned to terrorism and violence, and I-CARD thought filmmaking could be an alternative form of expression for tribal youth seeking to be heard. I-CARD's subsequent film projects include recording disappearing traditional dances and a film version of street plays performed by tribal youth on various social problems, enabling the messages to reach a far larger audience.</p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>
<h3>Girls' health and education: Rajasthan, India</h3>
<em>Partner Organization: </em><a href="http://veerni.waidev2.com/site/" target="_blank"><em>Veerni project</em></a>

<img class="alignleft" style="margin: 5px;" alt="" src="http://veerni.waidev2.com/site/home/images/MjAwMC0tLTQxMDg2MS0tLTU1MA==.jpg?image_time=1236602230" width="240" height="180" />

The Veerni project brings health and community development services to remote villages in Rajasthan. British filmmaker Bob Edwards worked with the Veerni project to document their work on camera. Rajashtan is one of those most beautiful parts of India, and by capturing the cultural richness in images Veerni hoped to attract funders to this region.</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>
<h3>Training/Empowerment: Gujarat, India</h3>
<em>Partner Organization: <a href="http://www.sewa.org/" target="_blank">SEWA</a></em>

<em></em>"Women, Water and Work" was made for one of the most prominent Indian women's organization, the Self Employed Women's Association. This film on women-led initiatives to combat drought is being screened frequently in village training sessions to (i) encourage women to join the Water Campaign, (ii) convince women they can do traditionally male tasks, such as hand-pump repair, that the subjects of the video are completing, and (iii) help women visualize the dangers of drought in villages where problems are not yet acute. This film was a participatory video. Co-directors included a former vegetable vendor and a block printer.</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Partners</title>
		<link>http://www.videovolunteers.org/about/partners/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 11 Jun 2007 13:07:44 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>nladmin</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.videovolunteers.org/?page_id=49</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h1><strong>Partners </strong></h1>
<strong>Video Volunteers has partnered with many organizations to promote the ideals of a more democratized media and to empower grassroots communities. Below is a detailed list of all our partners to date.</strong>
<h2>India</h2>
<ul>
	<li><strong><a href="http://www.aksharacentre.org/" target="_blank">Akshara</a>, Mumbai, India: </strong>an NGO that advocates and works for the rights of women.</li>
	<li><a href="http://anandi-india.org/default.aspx" target="_blank"><strong>ANANDI</strong></a><strong>, Gujarat, India</strong><strong>:</strong> Area Networking and Development Initiative (ANANDI) works to empower marginalized rural women.</li>
	<li><strong><a href="http://www.aravind.org/hospitals/madurai.asp" target="_blank">Aravind Eye Hospital</a>, Madurai, India</strong><strong>:</strong> one of the most reputed eye care facilities in the world that was founded in 1976 by Dr. G. Venkataswamy.</li>
	<li><a href="http://beyondprofitmag.com/" target="_blank"><strong>Beyond Profit</strong></a><strong>, Mumbai, India:</strong><strong> </strong>a new social enterprise magazine that presents the stories, people and ideas behind innovative social ventures.</li>
	<li><strong><a href="http://www.byrrajufoundation.org/" target="_blank">Byrraju Foundation</a>, Andhra Pradesh, India: </strong>builds self-reliant rural communities by providing services in healthcare, sanitation, education, literacy and skills development.</li>
	<li><strong><a href="http://www.ciieindia.org/" target="_blank">CIEE at the Indian Institute of Management</a>,</strong> <strong>Ahmedabad, India: </strong>the Council on International Educational Exchange is a student exchange program through which international students are given a chance to study in India for a semester.</li>
	<li><strong><a href="http://www.centreforsocialjustice.net/" target="_blank">Centre for Social Justice (CSJ)</a>, Gujarat, India:</strong> a socio-legal organization working on human rights issues concerning women, Dalits and tribals. It is designed as an intervention to fight against discrimination and establish rule of law.</li>
	<li><strong><a href="http://www.chintan-india.org/" target="_blank">Chintan Environmental Research and Action Group</a>, New Delhi, India:</strong> an environmental action group established in December 1999 in order to address issues of sustainable consumption and environmental and social justice.</li>
	<li><strong>Dappu, Andhra Pradesh, India:</strong> an organization that works on human rights issues affecting Dalits in rural India.</li>
	<li><strong><a href="http://www.hihtindia.org/rdi%20About.html" target="_blank">HIHT-RDI</a></strong><strong>, Uttrakhand, India</strong>: the Rural Development Institute (RDI) is a rural outreach division of Himalayan Institute Hospital Trust (HIHT) that aims not only to provide people from underdeveloped areas with quality health care, but also to ensure their overall social and economic development.</li>
	<li><strong>Hind Swaraj Mandal</strong><strong>, Gujarat, India:</strong> an NGO operating in Rajkot that focuses on social welfare.</li>
	<li><strong><a href="http://www.iciciprulife.com/public/About-us/About-Us.htm" target="_blank">ICICI Prudential Life Insurance Company</a>, Mumbai, India:</strong> is a joint venture between ICICI Bank and Prudential plc and is Indias leading private life insurer.</li>
	<li><strong>I-CARD</strong><strong>, Assam, India:</strong> the Institution for Cultural and Rural Development (I-CARD) brings forward insights and solutions fitting local cultural world views for sustainable development.</li>
	<li><strong><a href="http://www.indiagoverns.org/" target="_blank">IndiaGoverns</a></strong><strong>, New Delhi, India:</strong> a research institute that collects and distributes developmental data to elected representatives.</li>
	<li><strong><a href="http://www.jalbhagirathi.org/" target="_blank">Jal Bhagirathi Foundation (JBF),</a> Rajasthan, India: </strong>focuses on the issue of governance<strong> </strong>and also works on the issue of water in an environment where women have to walk hours each day to get enough water for their families to drink.</li>
	<li><strong><a href="http://www.kolkatasanved.org/" target="_blank">Kolkata Sanved</a></strong><strong>, Kolkata, India</strong>: an organization that uses dance movement as an alternative approach to the recovery, healing and psychosocial rehabilitation of victims of violence.</li>
	<li><strong><a href="http://www.laya.org.in/default.aspx" target="_blank">Laya</a>, Andhra Pradesh, India:</strong> a NGO that works on, among other things, tribal development.</li>
	<li><strong><a href="http://www.mahita.org/" target="_blank">Mahita</a>, Hyderabad, India:</strong> a team of individuals committed to initiate development interventions in the urban slums of Hyderabad.</li>
	<li><strong><a href="http://navsarjan.org/" target="_blank">Navsarjan</a>, Gujarat, India:</strong> a leading Dalit rights organization working in the feudal heartland of Gujarat.</li>
	<li><a href="http://www.psalegal.com/home.html" target="_blank"><strong>Priti Suri Assocates</strong></a>,<strong>New Delhi India</strong>: a law firm that has serves a business niche in the Indian legal market and offers a large a number of different practice areas for this sector.</li>
	<li><strong><a href="http://www.questalliance.net/" target="_blank">Quest Alliance</a>, Bangalore, India: </strong>implements innovative educational programs that aim to improve the quality of school education for disadvantaged communities.</li>
	<li><strong>Sayhog, Ahmedabad, India: </strong>a non-profit organization which conducts informal education for school children of different age groups.<strong> </strong></li>
	<li><strong><a href="http://www.saath.org/saath/index.php" target="_blank">Saath</a>, Ahmedabad, India:</strong> a non-profit organization working to improve the quality of life for the urban poor in Gujarat.</li>
	<li><strong><a href="http://www.samhita.org/" target="_blank">Samhita.org</a>, Mumbai, India:</strong> a philanthropic initiative of the Nadathur Trust which places special focus on providing greater visibility, more resources and a support system for social organizations.</li>
	<li><strong>Sambhavna Clinic, Bhopal, India: </strong>offers the survivors of the Bhopal gas tragedy free medical care through allopathy, ayurveda and yoga.</li>
	<li><strong><a href="http://www.shramikbharti.org.in/" target="_blank">Shramik Bharti</a>, Kanpur, Uttar Pradesh, India: </strong>a NGO whose activities are primarily aimed at eradicating poverty with particular emphasis on empowering women.</li>
	<li><strong><a href="http://janvikas.in/index.html" target="_blank">Udaan-Janvikas</a></strong><strong>, Gujarat, India:</strong> an organization that incubates and builds issue-based institutions with relevance to society in response to emerging socio-eco-political realities.</li>
	<li><strong><a href="http://www.maharajajodhpur.com/trust/hh_h_veerni.htm" target="_blank">Veerni Project</a>, Rajasthan, India:</strong> aims to empower girls and women to create positive changes in their lives as well as in their communities and gain economic independence.</li>
	<li><strong><a href="http://www.westgodavari.org:8080/pip/aboutpip.html" target="_blank">Velugu Project</a>, Andhra Pradesh, India:</strong> an Andhra Pradesh Rural Development Agency project funded by the World Bank and implemented by the Society for Elimination of Rural Poverty to eliminate rural poverty.</li>
	<li><strong><a href="http://www.yuvaindia.org/" target="_blank">Yuva</a>, Mumbai, India:</strong> Youth for Voluntary Action (Yuva) is a non profit Human Rights Organization based in Mumbai.</li>
	<li><strong><a href="http://yuva-shakti.org/index.php" target="_blank">Yuva Shakti</a>, Gujarat, India:</strong> a non-profit organization working in Panchmahals, Gujarat for the rights of the youth</li>
	<li><strong><a href="http://www.genecampaign.org/">Gene Campaign:</a></strong>a research and advocacy organization working on the property rights, food &amp; livelihood security of farmers in<em>India</em><em>.</em></li>
	<li><strong><a href="http://www.breakthrough.tv/">Breakthrough:</a></strong>use media and popular culture to raise awareness on issues such as domestic violence, HIV, gender and sexuality.</li>
	<li><strong><a href="http://www.inecc.net/">India Network on Ethics and Climate Change:</a></strong> work on issues relating to climate justice and sustainable development for eco-system based communities.</li>
</ul>

<hr size="2" />

<h2>Brazil</h2>
<ul>
	<li><span style="font-weight: normal; font-size: 13px;"><strong><a href="http://www.casadascaldeiras.com.br/" target="_blank">Casa das Caldeiras</a>, So Paulo, Brazil:</strong> a cultural organization which works with youth and children. It promotes cultural cooperation and exchange of know-how between local associations and international groups.</span></li>
	<li><strong><a href="http://www.rhythmicuprising.org/" target="_blank">Rhythmic Uprising</a>, Bahia, Brazil:</strong> a documentary project that seeks to empower a movement of artists to elevate the quality of life for children in Brazil.</li>
	<li><strong><a href="http://www.vivafavela.com.br/" target="_blank">Viva Favela</a>, Rio De Janeiro, Brazil:</strong> a citizen journalism website in Brazil.</li>
</ul>

<hr size="2" />

<h2>USA</h2>
<ul>
	<li><strong><a href="http://blip.tv/" target="_blank">Blip.tv</a>, USA: </strong>the world's largest videoblogging and podcasting service which supports over 50,000 web video producers across the world.</li>
	<li><strong><a href="http://www.creativevisions.org/" target="_blank">Creative Visions Foundation</a>, Los Angeles, USA: </strong>a foundation that supports creative activists who use the power of media and the arts to create positive change in the world, and was Video Volunteers fiscal sponsor from 2003  2006.</li>
	<li><strong><a href="http://www.echoinggreen.org/" target="_blank">Echoing Green</a>, New York, USA:</strong>an organization that works toward accelerating social change and invests in, and supports, outstanding emerging social entrepreneurs to launch new organizations that deliver bold, high-impact solutions.</li>
	<li><strong><a href="http://www.fxb.org/Default.aspx?sflang=en" target="_blank">FXB International (Association Francois-Xavier Bagnoud)</a>, New York:</strong> an organization working towards fighting poverty and AIDS, and supporting the worlds orphans and vulnerable children.</li>
	<li><strong><a href="http://www.filmaid.org/" target="_blank">FilmAid International</a>, New York:</strong> provides knowledge and empowerment to millions of people suffering the effects of war, poverty, displacement or disaster through the use of films.</li>
	<li><strong><a href="http://www.thefledglingfund.org/" target="_blank">The Fledgling Fund</a>, New York, USA: a</strong> fund seeks to improve the lives of vulnerable individuals, families, and communities by supporting innovative media projects that target entrenched social problems.</li>
	<li><strong><a href="http://www.scu.edu/sts/gsbi/" target="_blank">Global Social Benefit Incubator (GSBI)</a></strong>,<strong> Santa Clara, USA</strong>:the signature program of Santa Clara University's Center for Science, Technology and Society (CSTS). It works with social entrepreneurs to empower them and their organizations and to overcome barriers to scale and impact.</li>
	<li><strong><a href="http://www.gtlaw.com/Home" target="_blank">Greenberg Traurig</a>:</strong> an international law firm with 1775 attorneys and governmental affairs professionals in 32 locations across the United States of America.</li>
	<li><strong><a href="http://www.globalfundforchildren.org/" target="_blank">Global Fund for Children</a>, New York: </strong>has a mission to advance the dignity of children and youth around the world</li>
	<li><a href="http://www.hugheshubbard.com/" target="_blank"><strong>Hughes Hubbard &amp; Reed</strong></a>: an international law firm that has a distinguished history dating back to 1888. The firm has been recognized as part of the "new elite" among "the profession's top tier," according to a survey by The American Lawyer magazine ("The A-List", July 2009).</li>
	<li><strong><a href="http://www.iyfnet.org/" target="_blank">International Youth Foundation</a>, Washington DC: </strong>a program that provides young leaders with critical thinking and practical skills to help them build the capacity of their non-profit organization.</li>
	<li><strong><a href="http://www.jerichoproject.org/" target="_blank">Jericho Project</a>, New York: </strong>provides solution to end homelessness at its roots.</li>
	<li><a href="http://www.knightfdn.org/about_knight/" target="_blank"><strong>Knight Foundation</strong></a>, USA: seeks opportunities that can transform both communities and journalism, and help them reach their highest potential.</li>
	<li><strong><a href="http://www.northernarapaho.com/pr/">Northern Arapaho Tribal Council</a>, Wyoming:</strong> the governing body of the Northern Arapaho Tribe on the Wind River Reservation in Wyoming.</li>
	<li><strong><a href="http://www.rareconservation.org/" target="_blank">RARE Conservation</a>:</strong> an organization that specializes in social marketing for the conservation of biodiversity.</li>
	<li><strong><a href="http://www.rosenblumassociates.com/" target="_blank">Rosenblum Associates,</a> New York,</strong> USA: an organization that does video and media training worldwide.</li>
	<li><span style="font-weight: bold;">Priti Suri Associates, India: </span>a law firm that has serves a business niche in the Indian legal market and offers a large a number of different practice areas for this sector.</li>
	<li><strong><a href="http://www.stern.nyu.edu/" target="_blank">Stern School of Business</a>, New York University, USA: </strong>a leading business school with undergraduate, MBA, and doctoral programs that has worked towards shaping an environment that nurtures forward-thinking leaders<strong>.</strong></li>
	<li><strong><a href="http://www.nystar.state.ny.us/incubators/newyork/tsi.htm">The Stern Incubator</a>, New York: a</strong> program at Berkley Center for Entrepreneurial Studies that supports new NYU affiliated ventures founded and run by entrepreneurial minded students and alumni.</li>
	<li><strong>Watershed Resources Incorporated, Wyoming:</strong> assists Native American tribes in securing their water rights.</li>
	<li><strong>Wiredrive, USA</strong>: provides online media production and marketing tools for the advertising and entertainment industries.</li>
	<li><strong><a href="http://www.witness.org/" target="_blank">WITNESS</a>, New York:</strong> an organization that uses video for advocacy; uses the power of video to open the eyes of the world to human rights abuses.</li>
</ul>
<h2><strong>Other Global</strong></h2>
<ul>
	<li><strong><a href="http://www.undp.org/" target="_blank">UNDP</a>:</strong> the United Nations Development Programme is a world renowned organization that works with government and people at the grassroots to help find solutions to developmental challenges.</li>
	<li><a href="http://www.unesco.org/" target="_blank"><strong>UNESCO</strong></a>:theUnited Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization encourages international peace and universal respect by promoting collaboration among nations. It also has a Communication and Information Sector.</li>
	<li><a href="http://www.itu.int/wsis/" target="_blank"><strong>World Summit on the Information Society (WSIS)</strong></a>: The ultimate objective of the United Nation's <a href="http://www.itu.int/wsis/">WSIS</a> is to formulate a common vision and understanding of the global information society. It is has adopted a Declaration of Principles and an Action Plan to facilitate the effective growth of the Information Society and to help bridge the digital divide.</li>
	<li><strong><a href="http://www.idsn.org/">International Dalit Solidarity Network:</a></strong>works on a global level for theelimination ofcaste discrimination and similar forms of discrimination based on work and descent.</li>
	<li><strong><a href="http://www.ifrc.org/">International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies:</a></strong>is the worlds largest humanitarian organization, carrying out relief operations to assist victims of disasters, and combining this with diverse development work.</li>
	<li><strong><a href="http://www.waterintegritynetwork.net/">Water Integrity Network:</a></strong>A worldwide network fighting corruption in the water sector.</li>
</ul>]]></content:encoded>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>Impact</title>
		<link>http://www.videovolunteers.org/impact/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 11 Jun 2007 13:10:22 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>nladmin</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.videovolunteers.org/?page_id=50</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h1><strong>Our Impact </strong></h1>
<strong>Video Volunteers has initiated and sustained a global community media movement, which has empowered people by giving them a voice, training them to use it, and enabled them to take action towards social change. Our training models and projects have created an impact in the following ways:</strong>
<img class="alignleft" style="margin: 20px;" title="CVU_interviewing_woman_children" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2007/06/CVU_interviewing_woman_children.jpg" alt="" width="240" height="233" />
<h3><strong>Give the poor a voice.</strong></h3>
<ul>
	<li>Enable the poor to participate in decision-making.</li>
	<li>Create platforms for constructive dialogue and discussion around screenings of their films, where people focus on solutions not problems.</li>
	<li>Change the lens of lookingfrom outsiders looking in, to insiders voicing out. This has helped in dashing dominant ideology stereotypes and offered the poor a chance to be the creators of content.</li>
	<li>Strengthened this voice by creating networks of community producers and correspondents who know and work with each other.</li>
	<li>Integrated this voice with mainstream media, allowing for the representation of the poor as producers of information.</li>
</ul>
<h3><strong>Promote community-led development, enable communities to take action on their issues, and provide critical information to people who dont have it.</strong></h3>
The first step in changing the way people behave is to change the way they think. Once people are informed, or issues are brought to the surface from within, possible solutions can be discussed and they can start to organize. It also brings awareness to people of their rights, a better understanding of the problems their communities face and different approaches to tackling issues. Examples of responses to videos produced by Community Producers and Correspondents include:
<ul>
	<li>The upper-caste employers in a village started paying the minimum wage after community members learned the exact pay they were entitled to from a community-produced film.</li>
	<li>The Bhagwati Hotel in Choraniya village was forced to reconstruct its sewage system so that it didnt empty into the villages drinking water pipes.</li>
	<li>Villagers organized clean-up rallies in three villages after watching a CVU film on cleanliness in Surendranagar district Gujarat.</li>
</ul>
[expand title="Click here to expand list"]
<ul>
	<li>Local villagers started demanding that the local moneylender charge them the proper rates.</li>
	<li>Children belonging to different communities played together for the first time after a video on equal rights.</li>
	<li>Villagers protested against the selling and consumption of alcohol; five villagers announced abstinence from alcohol and there were raids on illegal liquor shops in Jakhan village.</li>
	<li>20 people working in the unorganized sector, filled forms to start a union in the two Bombay slums of Dharavi and Malad.</li>
	<li>Villagers demanded quicker processing of malaria samples and the doctors responded.</li>
	<li>In Doramamidi, villagers staged protests regarding their lack of electricity in front of the Electric Department, and as a result got electricity.</li>
	<li>A video for IndiaUnheard resulted in horse cart drivers being given an official parking spot in Allahabad.</li>
	<li>A CVU producers father gave up alcohol addiction.</li>
	<li>Numerous calls made to NGOs to organize youth sports teams after seeing a film on womens access to public space that advocated girls sports teams.</li>
	<li>Children in a youth media workshop, organized by a CVU, took an inspirational video about playgrounds to local municipal authorities; it was then screened in schools in Ahmedebad.</li>
	<li>People urged doctors to conduct regular visits, and doctors started attending patients in 4 villages.</li>
	<li>Film on fuel and energy shown in 30 schools, raised awareness and concern amongst children.</li>
	<li>Film removed a fear of textbooks, enlightened children about rights, and gathered general knowledge about tribal culture, etc.</li>
</ul>
[/expand]
<h3><strong>Advocate for democracy and an end to corruption, encourage governments and authorities to take action.</strong></h3>
<img class="alignleft" style="margin: 10px;" title="CVU_in_school" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2007/06/CVU_in_school.jpg" alt="" width="240" height="194" />
The camera can either be a weapon, exposing corruption, or it can be a bridge-building tool to local government officials who are disconnected from residents. Therefore, community video can strengthen democracy and encourage local people to participate in governance.

The Right to Information Act (RTI) is also an important part of the training for both CVU producers and India Unheard Community Correspondentsas a result the poor and marginalized are now using their constitutional rights and demanding information in order to take action. So far, more than 10 communities have successfully used RTI to get information and subsequently take action.

As well, people who know their rights are much more likely to exercise those rights. Armed with this knowledge, citizens have the courage to lobby government with authority on their own. The government, in turn, is much more likely to carry out its functions properly and improve the quality of its services because people are watching. Often times, the government has no choice but to respond to the mounting public pressure and fix the problem.
<ul>
	<li>The government re-opened a water treatment plant and brought clean water to 3,000 people after Community Producers exposed a high level of fluorine content resulting in <em>florosis</em>. Villagers agreed to invest in the treatment plant.</li>
	<li>Slum dwellers in Mumbai, after watching a film on Right To Information act (RTI) filed an RTI to find out the details of the budget spent on garbage clearance. The RTI resulted in quick clearance of the garbage and clogged drains.</li>
	<li>Attendance at local-governance Gram Sabha meetings increased from 7 to 40 in one villagethese participative governance meetings are supposed to be composed of all villagers over the age of 18.</li>
	<li>In Ruupawati village, Dalit women expressed a desire to run for office in an election.</li>
	<li>Seven villages formed womens panchayats (local councils).</li>
</ul>
[expand title="<em>Click here to expand list.</em>"]
<ul>
	<li>Villagers demanded work under the government scheme NREGA (National Rural Employment Guarantee Act); 300 men and women got work for 100 days at Rs.50 per day.</li>
	<li>Forest Rights Recognition Act committees became active in all villages in which the video on this subject was screened.</li>
	<li>60-70 children expressed their desire to vote after a film stressing the importance of democratic voting.</li>
	<li>A video for IndiaUnheard on paying bribes for education led to the Block Officer of that area demoting the Headmaster of the school.</li>
	<li>The government suspended a corrupt official running a ration shop as a result of villagers demands.</li>
	<li>Food control officers, impressed by a film on ration cards, arranged for four Below Poverty Line ration cards to be given to deserving community members; raids resulted in more honest dealings.</li>
	<li>A community applied to the Integrated Tribal Development Agency to repair bore wells in 15-16 villages.</li>
	<li>Government paid the Samvad CVU to screen their magazine on tobacco abuse at the police headquarters.</li>
	<li>About 1200 people in Surendranagar village got toilets after villagers were informed it was their right to have proper sanitation.</li>
	<li>The government sanctioned a new road for the village Ravulapadu.</li>
	<li>Local government repaired the only road connecting several villages and allocated Rs.300,000 for further repairs.</li>
	<li>The government sent a team for an infrastructural inspection; toilets were built.</li>
	<li>In Surendranagar district, the government provided dustbins in one slum area and local people began working with rag-pickers to keep the area clean.</li>
</ul>
[/expand]
<h3><strong>Expand the scale and reach of social programs and campaigns.</strong></h3>
<img class="alignleft size-full wp-image-1808" style="margin: 5px;" title="Impact_Women_Meeting" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2007/06/Impact_Women_Meeting.jpg" alt="" width="240" height="170" />
The CVU, with its ability to spread messages to large groups of people, is an efficient parallel strategy for our NGO partners. Screenings draw large crowdson an average night between 200 and 300 people, which is sometimes the majority of a village. If a village needs drinking water, one solution would be to build a well. However, a more sustainable strategy would be to encourage 1000 people to demand clean water and get ten wells built that way.
<strong>
</strong>
Additionally, community videos and reports from the CVUs and IndiaUnheard correspondents often provide basic legal information, advice on government schemes, and even simple tips like the location of a local government agency. Many organizations have invested in our programs because they also enable them to listen to the community more closely and increase participation in their programs.
<ul>
	<li>750 villagers filed reports of land rights violations with NGO staff in response to a film made for an NGOs land rights campaign, significantly increasing the likelihood that those villages will become part of the governments land reallocation program.</li>
	<li>There was three times the amount of participation in a Mumbai water campaign against the privatization of water for slum dwellers which led to a massive turn out at a public hearing by the government. As a result, privatization efforts were halted in these slums and water supply increased in two slums.</li>
	<li>There was a 150% increase in applications for a job-training program for youth after watching a film whose call to action was to apply to an NGO for this course.</li>
</ul>
[expand title="<em>Click here to expand list.</em>"]
<ul>
	<li>The police hotline 103 was set up for sexual harassment in Mumbai, which has now extended to the entire state.</li>
	<li>20 Parents Watch committees were started for better child care in Behrampure, Satosh Nagar, Ram Rahim Tekra.</li>
	<li>Six people joined Umeed (a vocational training centre for urban poor) for a 3-month course in Customer Relationship and Sales.</li>
	<li>2000 students applied for courses run by the CVUs sponsoring NGO, HIHT, after a film creating publicity for these academic courses.</li>
	<li>YUVAs online supporter base doubled between 2007-2010 because of Hamari Awaz Community Video Unit.</li>
	<li>600 people benefited from Byrajjus bulletin on soil testing and traditional farming in Korukollu village.</li>
	<li>Education committees were formed in 5 villages to ensure special education rights to all the children of all the migrant laborers in the village.</li>
	<li>People demanded more information about drug rehabilitation programs from authorities.</li>
	<li>An Auxiliary Nurse Midwife began working properly after people warned her, as a result of a film on maternal health and immunization.</li>
	<li>Villagers started using Raitu Bazaar, a special market for farmers set up by the government.</li>
	<li>After learning about the opportunities available to them from watching Community Video Unit productions, people successfully accessed government loans.</li>
	<li>Children of migrant workers across 12 villages received migration cards, which entitled them to enroll short-term in schools in the areas where their parents were seasonal migrants, thus stopping them from dropping out of school.</li>
	<li>A video for IndiaUnheard on the dire lack of health care facilities in Manipur resulted in an NGO donating health supplies.</li>
</ul>
[/expand]
<h3><strong>Transform the community members we work with into community leaders and in turn inspire others as role models.</strong></h3>
<img class="alignleft size-full wp-image-1806" style="margin: 5px 10px;" title="CVU_screening" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2007/06/CVU_screening.jpg" alt="" width="240" height="180" />
VideoVolunteers journalism training in critical thinking, confronting authority, asking questions and researching any issue, has created a new batch of leaders, of whom more than 50% are women. In all the communities where we work, these people become the go-to-points for conflict resolution, information and assistance. They are taught to open their eyes to new information, break down issues to root causes, and work through problems their villages are facing.
<strong>
</strong>
Community Producers and Correspondents undergo a remarkable transformation that re-shapes their lives. They are not simply video journalists; they are grassroots activists using the power of a compact camera. They are shedding light on peoples harsh realities, organizing communities, and empowering locals to take action. They are well respected in their villages and slums; they are a source of motivation for their peers and inspire others within their communities to also become leaders and positive role models.
<ul>
	<li>Dalit community producers, after addressing and exposing sensitive issues like land rights, are now respected by the rest of the community as leaders and invited into upper-caste spaces.</li>
	<li>Dalit Correspondents (like Mukesh) have been participating in national consultation on creation of livelihood opportunities for Dalits.</li>
	<li>Producers approached a public health officer to reopen a closed hospital in slum.</li>
	<li>Orthodox Muslim families enquired whether their daughters can work for the Samvad Community Video Unit.</li>
	<li>Villagers got together and created a Self Help Group to protect the water in the lakes and ponds in their community and to distribute it economically.</li>
	<li>Hindus and Muslims came together in one area for the first time since the Gujarat riots, to watch a film on communal harmony, and wished each other peace and happiness, ending fear in the minds of community members.</li>
</ul>
[expand title="<em>Click here to expand list.</em>"]
<ul>
	<li>In Vasthadi, seven community women became actors for a CVU film on migration.</li>
	<li>A young Dalit musician from a slum in Bombay got a record deal after being featured in a Community Video Unit film in which he spoke about his dream of being a professional musician.</li>
	<li>CVU producers have been told by community members that they can use any house they want for their screenings.</li>
	<li>CVU producers got the head of a con-artist operation arrested.</li>
	<li>CVU producers found a rape victim, shot footage of the scene, took her to hospital and filed case. Police action was then made possible.</li>
	<li>Community Producer Neeru (of Navsarjan) was the only girl in her whole clan who, instead of having an arranged marriage, chose her own life partner (who is also a member of her CVU).</li>
	<li>Community Correspondents Rohini and Sunita broke the purdah system by becoming the first women to take up a job.</li>
</ul>
[/expand]
<h3><strong>Create sustainable solutions and new business models for the base of the pyramid.</strong></h3>
An important livelihood aspect underscores all of Video Volunteers training, and the skills learned can be applied across a lifetime. We have designed scalable and revenue-earning models for amplifying marginalized voices. The Community Video Units and IndiaUnheard correspondents have incredible market potential because they operate in areas where TV stations dont normally have reporters, they have access to great stories, offer different perspectives, and can charge less that an urban professional would. We continually research ways to create a media industry centered at the base of the pyramid.
<img class="alignleft size-full wp-image-1809" style="margin: 20px;" title="producer_camera_market" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2007/06/producer_camera_market.jpg" alt="" width="180" height="283" />
<ul>
	<li>CVU Producers earn a salary and are able to sustain themselves.</li>
	<li>IndiaUnheard Correspondents earn money for each video produced; they are also empowered to work as news stringers for the mainstream media.</li>
	<li>Our CVU Community Producers have now functioned for 4 years without the assistance of a full time trainer, demonstrating that it is possible for someone with little or no formal education to become an articulate journalist or filmmaker.</li>
	<li>The prestigious Indian Institute of Management (IIM) of Ahmedabad is collaborating with Video Volunteers<strong> </strong>to create business models, explore methods and design plans to help community media reach high levels of sustainability.</li>
	<li>Some CVUs are now earning income. Samvad earned 50% of its running costs this yearthrough revenue generating activities including making wedding videos in their spare time.</li>
	<li>Training videos have been fetching Rs.300 each.</li>
	<li>Our Brazil livelihood program enabled 8 community youth to set up a media collective through which they currently earn double their desired income level.</li>
</ul>
<h3><strong>Redefine the paradigms of news and media control, impact the mainstream media and the NGO Landscape.</strong></h3>
<img class="alignleft" style="margin: 10px;" title="CVU_very_rural_village" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2007/06/CVU_very_rural_village.jpg" alt="" width="240" height="228" />Video Volunteers believes in democratizing mainstream national and global media, although we see that much focus has been placed on funding and creating new ways for people to exchange knowledge without much investment in training community members to produce content or use these tools. New types of distribution platforms are popping up on a daily basisfrom blogs to social media networksand it is easy to assume that voices and perspectives from around the world are now flowing freely, however, many voices are still left out of the conversation. Thus, in order to further our mission of enabling communities to be the ones themselves articulating their needs, problems, and desires, we work hard to promote and distribute the media made by the communities we have given training to.

Video Volunteers also strengthens approaches to bottom-up development by enabling NGOs to listen to the voices of communities they work with and thus create more community-led development. As well, we provide NGOs with a way to achieve and complement their campaigns and assist them in spreading their ideas farther.
<ul>
	<li>Video Volunteers promotes diversity: our network of producers is  Dalit,  tribal,  Muslim and over 50% female--thus bringing needed diversity to an Indian media that is largely of the Brahmin caste.</li>
	<li>More than 300 NGOs across India, Brazil, and the rest of the world, have expressed interest in being part of our programs, and ten NGOs have collectively invested more than $400,000 in our programs.</li>
	<li>We have trained and worked with more than 40 NGOs whose work is now more participatory, who are better able to listen to communities, and have stronger processes for engaging large numbers of people at the community level.</li>
	<li>We have interacted and cooperated with mainstream media. Our content has been featured on channels such as Current TV, CNN IBN, Pangea Day, Nickelodeon, NewsX and many others, demonstrating that community-produced content can influence even middle class audiences.</li>
	<li>Community Producer Jayasheela was selected by the international film competition <em>Listen Up!</em> To produce a video on her personal water struggle in her slum in Mumbai that was screened internationally in youth media markets and on Americas Public Broadcasting System (PBS). She also talks about how strong it made her feel to realize people were interested in their water struggles around the world.</li>
</ul>
[expand title="<em>Click here to expand list.</em>"]
<ul>
	<li>We have generated significant interest in community media in India, signified by the Community Video Training Camp in Aug 2009, where there were 300 applications from NGOs, students and journalists for only 100 spaces.</li>
	<li>Video Volunteers was the past secretariat of the Community Radio Forum (CRF) and Stalin K is the former Convener of the forum. He was instrumental in the lobbying efforts, which led to the passage of the community radio broadcasting bill legalizing community radio for the first time in India, and was part of a team that drafted much of the new Community Radio Policy in operation today.</li>
	<li>Slum dwellers organized independent screenings of Community Video Unit films in their homes; politicians came to the NGO office asking for copies; it was covered in 12 major Mumbai newspapers.</li>
</ul>
[/expand]
<strong> </strong>
[expand title="<em><strong>Click here to read about how we measure our impact.</strong></em>"]
<h1><strong>Impact Assessment</strong></h1>
1) We measure the leadership development of the Community Producers and Correspondents through regular assessments of their skills and their videos.

2) We measure how communities take action in response to the videos they make and watch. Since each film ends with a concrete call to action, we can find out how many people actually followed it through.

3) We measure how the government takes action. Producers gather anecdotal impact stories related to communities and government in each village where they screened a film.

4) We measure the expansion in scale and reach of an NGOs programs. This is measurable when the NGO has good comparison data. For instance, we have found that in films where the call to action is to join an NGOs program (such as enroll in their livelihoods training program, or work with them to build toilets), enrollment has gone up by 75% in a few cases.

5) In the long term, we aim to create metrics to measure the long term impact on a community when it owns and controls its own media, though this is extremely challenging.
[/expand]]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Volunteer with Us</title>
		<link>http://www.videovolunteers.org/get-involved/intern-volunteer/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 11 Jun 2007 13:18:50 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>nladmin</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.videovolunteers.org/?page_id=53</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h1>Volunteer or Intern with Us</h1>
<strong>In recent times Video Volunteers has grown a lot through the participation of volunteers and our growth depends in part on the professionals who volunteer their skills and time with us. We therefore value the contribution of each volunteer and intern and make sure to provide a good experience.</strong>

Interning and volunteering is a great way to be a part of Video Volunteers work and is also an excellent way to learn of the community media movement and contribute to strengthen it. By interning and volunteering you will gain:
<ul>
	<li>Insight into the community media movement.</li>
	<li>Knowledge about development issues and working in a non-profit.</li>
	<li>Interact with and work with people from rural and slum communities.</li>
	<li>Increase your cross-cultural understanding.</li>
	<li>Significantly improve your communication skills.</li>
	<li>Evolve your self-reliance and teamwork skills.</li>
</ul>
<h2><strong>Here's who we need:</strong></h2>
<ul>
	<li><strong><em>Filmmakers/Videographers/Journalists</em></strong> to make films on our community video units, individual community producers/correspondents and video document our other programs and activities.</li>
</ul>
<ul>
	<li><strong><em>Filmmakers/Video Editors</em></strong> to re-edit CVU and IndiaUnheard content for other audiences like funders or TV partners.</li>
</ul>
<ul>
	<li><strong><em>Young professionals and researchers</em></strong> to help on special projects, such as research, outreach, updating our training manuals or documentation. Volunteers for New York may be able to work part-time.</li>
</ul>
<ul>
	<li><strong><em>People with business skills</em></strong> to design programs, writing impact reports, working on the business model, and look at issues like sustainability and earned income.</li>
</ul>
<ul>
	<li><strong><em>Social work or international development students</em></strong> to do impact assessment and case studies.</li>
</ul>
<ul>
	<li><strong><em>People with Indian language skills</em></strong> to help with translation of videos. This can even be done at a distance.</li>
</ul>
<h2><strong>Volunteer with an IndiaUnheard Correspondent:</strong></h2>
Video Volunteers can match filmmaker and video journalists volunteers with <a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/programmes/indiaunheard" target="_self">IndiaUnheard</a> community correspondents to create a first of its kind community media volunteer program. Through this exchange, we hope to deepen the appreciation of urban-based filmmakers for community media and the process of empowering the voices of the most marginalized, to generate interesting new films combining a north-south, or urban-rural perspective, and to give our community correspondents a chance to work with filmmakers from an entirely different background.

<img class="alignleft" style="margin-right: 5px; margin-left: 5px;" src="http://farm5.static.flickr.com/4017/4620378841_6b8334a45c.jpg" alt="" width="170" height="253" hspace="5" vspace="5" />
<h2><span style="font-weight: bold;">How to Apply:</span></h2>
Please download this <a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2007/06/Detailed-Information-On-Volunteering-With-VV.doc" target="_blank"><em>Detailed Information On Volunteering With Video Volunteers</em></a>, download and fill out the <a href="http://videovolunteersindia.wufoo.com/forms/volunteerinternship-application-form/">Application Form </a>and send this, along with your resume, to<em><strong>info@videovolunteers.org</strong></em>. Let us also know your time availability and the kind of project you would like to undertake.

Please note that in most cases (though not all), volunteers will need to cover their own expenses. Filmmaker-volunteers usually need to bring their own equipment.

<strong>You can read more about our past interns and volunteers who shared their experience of working with Video Volunteers<a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/about/internvolunteer/" target="_self">here</a>.</strong>]]></content:encoded>

By providing disadvantaged communities with journalistic and technology skills through its community video unit project, it has helped to set up various media production companies that are financially self-sustaining and locally owned and controlled."</td>

	<item>
		<title>Awards</title>
		<link>http://www.videovolunteers.org/about/awards/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 11 Jun 2007 13:22:03 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>nladmin</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.videovolunteers.org/?page_id=56</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h1>Awards</h1>
<p style="text-align: center;"><a title="News Challenge" href="http://www.newschallenge.org/video_volunteers" target="_blank"><img class="aligncenter" style="margin-top: 5px; margin-bottom: 5px; border: 0pt none;" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/06/AF_newschallenge.jpg" border="0" alt="News Challenge" width="239" height="60" /></a></p>
<p class="none_id"><strong>Knight News Challenge, 2008:</strong> Voted as one of 16 winners of one of the most prestigious awards for news and information, <em>Video </em><em>Volunteers</em> received this award to train 100 people in rural India as Community Video Producers.For more information on this award<a href="http://www.newschallenge.org/winner/video-volunteers" target="_blank">click here</a>.</p>

<hr />
<p class="none_id"><a title="Echoing Green" href="http://www.echoinggreen.org/index.cfm" target="_blank"><img class="alignleft" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2007/12/echoing_green.gif" border="0" alt="echoing green" width="84" height="55" /></a></p>
<p class="none_id"><strong>Echoing Green, 2007:</strong> Echoing Green is one of the worlds foremost Fellowships for social start-ups and social entrepreneurs. Jessica Mayberry was awarded this fellowship in 2007.For more information<a href="http://www.echoinggreen.org/" target="_blank">click here</a>.</p>
<p class="none_id"></p>
<p class="none_id"></p>

<hr />
<p class="none_id" style="text-align: center;"><a title="King Baudouin Foundation" href="http://www.kbfus.org" target="_blank"><img class="aligncenter" style="border: 0pt none;" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/06/AF_Baudouin.jpg" border="0" alt="echoing green" width="130" height="60" /></a></p>
<p class="none_id" style="text-align: left;"><strong>King Baudouin Foundation (of Belgium) International Development Prize, 2008</strong>: Video Volunteers wasone ofthe five shortlisted organizations for the King Baudouin Foundation (of Belgium) International Development Prize. For more information on this foundation <a href="http://www.kbfus.org/" target="_blank">click here</a>.</p>

<hr />
<p class="none_id" style="text-align: center;"><a href="http://www.manthanaward.org/" target="_blank"><img class="aligncenter" style="border: 0pt none;" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/06/AF_manthan.jpg" border="0" alt="Manthan Award" width="241" height="108" /></a></p>
<p class="none_id"><strong>Manthan Award South Asia, 2009:</strong> The goal of the Manthan Award South Asia is to showcase the content that already exists online and thus demonstrate the richness and diversity of content creativity to those interested in understanding and planning the Global Information Society. Video Volunteers was given an e-content awards for best practices initiatives.</p>

<hr />
<p class="none_id" style="text-align: center;"></p>
<p class="none_id" style="text-align: center;"><a title="Global Social Benefit Incubator" href="http://www.scu.edu/sts/gsbi/" target="_blank"><img class="aligncenter" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2007/06/gsbi.jpg" border="0" alt="Global Social Benefit Incubator" /></a></p>
<p class="none_id"><strong>Global Social Benefit Incubator, 2007:</strong> Video Volunteers was invited to participate in the prestigious Global Social Benefit Incubator at Santa Clara University. For moreinformation <a href="http://www.scu.edu/sts/gsbi/" target="_blank">click here</a>.</p>

<hr />
<p class="none_id"><a href="http://w4.stern.nyu.edu/berkley/bpc.cfm?doc_id=6306" target="_blank"><img class="alignleft" style="margin: 5px;" title="NYU Stern Berkeley" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2007/06/NYU-Stern-Berkeley-300x265.jpg" alt="" width="120" height="80" /></a></p>
<p class="none_id"></p>
<p class="none_id"></p>
<p class="none_id"></p>
<p class="none_id"></p>
<p class="none_id"><strong>Business Plan Competition, 2007:</strong> Video Volunteers was announced as a winner of the Business Plan Competition put on by the  NYUStern School of Business Berkley Center. This was a wonderful recognition of our model to accelerate  social change. The prize was $60,000, and access to office space and other resources through their Incubator Program. For more information <a href="http://w4.stern.nyu.edu/berkley/bpc.cfm?doc_id=6306" target="_blank">click here</a>.</p>

<hr />
<p class="none_id" style="text-align: center;"><a title="Developement Gateway Award" href="http://www.developmentgateway.org" target="_blank"><img class="aligncenter" style="margin-top: 5px; margin-bottom: 5px; border: 0pt none;" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2007/06/index_devgatewaygif.jpg" border="0" alt="Developement Gateway Award" width="229" height="100" /></a></p>
<p class="none_id"><strong>Development Gateway Award,December, 2006:</strong> Video Volunteers was announced as a finalist  in the 2006 Development GatewayAward. In 2006, the Award was focused on Youth,  and Video Volunteers was recognized for the work we and our partners have  achieved in engaging and training youthwithin our Community Video Units. For more information <a href="http://www.developmentgateway.org" target="_blank">click here</a>.</p>

<hr />
<p class="none_id" style="text-align: center;"><a title="The Tech Museum Awards" href="http://www.techawards.org/" target="_blank"><img class="aligncenter" style="border: 0pt none;" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2007/06/ta2004_icon_02.jpg" border="0" alt="The Tech Museum Awards" width="234" height="100" /></a></p>
<p class="none_id"><strong>Laureate of the Tech Museum Awards, 2006:</strong> The Tech Museum Awards is an international awards program that honors innovators from around the world who are  applying technology to benefit humanity. Video Volunteers was awarded a Tech Award in the Equality category and became a member of the Laureate network.<strong> </strong>For more information <a href="http://www.techawards.org/" target="_blank">click here</a>.</p>

<hr />
<p class="none_id" style="text-align: center;"></p>
<p class="none_id"></p>
<p class="none_id"><strong>
</strong></p>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Community Video Units (CVU)</title>
		<link>http://www.videovolunteers.org/programmes/cvus/</link>
		<pubDate>Sat, 30 Jun 2007 10:22:53 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>nladmin</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.videovolunteers.org/?page_id=117</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h1>Community Video Units (CVU)</h1>
<h2><a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2007/06/CVU.jpg"><img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-2200" title="CVU" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2007/06/CVU.jpg" alt="" width="600" height="371" /></a></h2>
<h2>What is a Community Video Unit?</h2>
A Community Video Unit (CVU) is a local production unit run by 8-10 community members who are trained in all aspects of video production. They work full-time and receive a salary. Each CVU has digital video cameras, computers for editing, a TV, and a wide screen projector and sound system for outdoor screenings. Producers are trained full-time, on-site for 12-18 months by a professional filmmaker. The CVU produces one video magazine every eight weeks on different social issues. Topics are chosen by an editorial board of community members, the CVU team and the NGO. One video magazine is screened every eight weeks month in 25 villages or <em>Bastis </em>(slums) and ends with calls for action. With an average of 200 people at each screening, the video reaches around 5000 people in community settings alone. The screenings foster participation and ownership by the community.
<h2>Establishing Community Video Units</h2>
<img class="alignleft" style="margin: 5px;" src="http://farm5.static.flickr.com/4051/4623976160_d28bb024a6_m.jpg" alt="" width="180" height="150" align="left" hspace="5" vspace="5" />
<p style="text-align: left;"><span style="font-weight: normal;">By supporting the establishment of Community Video Units (CVUs) in which the disenfranchised produce and distribute their own locally relevant video programs, we empower local communities to lead, connect and change, and then voice their issues to a global audience.</span></p>
<p style="text-align: left;"><span style="font-weight: normal;">With a five-year goal of creating a network of more than 200 Community Video Producers on four continents, we aim to transform the global media landscape by enabling those who are currently excluded to be seen and heard around the world.</span></p>

<h2><strong>Solutions-Based Media</strong></h2>
Each CVU produces a Video News Magazine every six weeks. The content of the Video Magazine is based on viewer feedback and key campaign issues decided by a Community Editorial Board consisting of community members, the CVU producers and the sponsor NGO. Different segments might include:
<ul>
	<li><strong><em>Community News</em></strong><em> </em>- the issues of poor communities, such as government schemes, local health issues and upcoming events that are not covered by the mainstream news</li>
	<li><strong><em>Opinion Polls</em></strong>  that capture community consensus and call to action on particular issues</li>
	<li><strong><em>Success Stories</em></strong><em> </em>- such as families that have found economic success through educating their girls</li>
	<li><strong><em>Short Documentaries</em></strong>  for example, stories where families speak out against alcoholism</li>
	<li><strong><em>Legal Tips</em></strong><strong> </strong>- i.e., what to do if your name is not on a voters list</li>
	<li><strong><em>Local Culture and Music</em></strong>  could be introductions to the festivals of another community/religion</li>
	<li><strong><em>Expose/video raids</em></strong>  such as short clips of closed government health services followed by an on-the-fly interview with the concerned government officials</li>
	<li><strong><em>Editorial</em></strong>  where the organization and the reporters take their stand-for-change on the issue and give follow up action points</li>
	<li><strong><em>Local humour/jokes/skits</em></strong>  because we need to make people laugh!</li>
</ul>
<h2><strong>National and International Distribution</strong></h2>
Since 2006, twelve Community Video Units have been launched by 12 leading NGOs. Video Volunteers is now working to create opportunities to leverage these voices into the mainstream media by distributing their media on the Internet and on our network's own site <a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/watch-a-video" target="_self"><em>CVU Films</em></a>. We're exploring advocacy campaigns, and starting to work with the mainstream media that is showing a growth in stories from the "bottom of the pyramid."

<strong>To watch all of our CVU films, <a href="http://www.cvufilms.videovolunteers.org" target="_blank">click here.</a></strong>

<a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/programmes/cvus/launch-a-cvu" target="_self"><strong>Click here </strong></a><strong>to launch a CVU.</strong>]]></content:encoded>
