	<item>
		<title>Take Action</title>
		<link>http://www.videovolunteers.org/get-involved/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 06 Aug 2007 07:17:48 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>nladmin</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.videovolunteers.org/?page_id=239</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h1>Take Action and Get Involved!</h1>
<strong>There are many ways to get involved with Video Volunteers' and the work accomplished. We depend on, and truly value, the interaction of our NGO and media partners, interns, volunteers, and the public. Below are a few ways you can strengthen and support community voices struggling for positive change!</strong>
<table border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0">
<tbody>
<tr>
<td valign="top" width="157"><img class="aligncenter" style="margin-top: 5px; margin-bottom: 5px;" alt="" src="http://farm5.static.flickr.com/4051/4684737786_09da9d5188.jpg" width="180" height="202" /></td>
<td valign="top" width="481">
<h2><a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/get-involved/partner-with-us" target="_self"><strong>Partner with Us</strong></a></h2>
<strong>If you are an NGO </strong>working on a particular issue, you can partner to<a href="../../../../../programmes/cvus/launch-a-cvu/" target="_self"> launch a Community Video Unit</a>. You can also create a <a href="../../../../../programmes/indiaunheard/create-an-indiaunheard-regional-hub/" target="_self">regional hub</a> for IndiaUnheard Community News Service and become a regional hub for community media, or, create a campaign with IndiaUnheard. To know more about these and all the other exciting partnership opportunities, <a href="../../../../../get-involved/partner-with-us/" target="_self">click here.</a>

<strong>If you are a media house</strong> curious to know how community-produced content could enhance your programming, please <a href="../contact-us" target="_self">contact us</a> to discuss how we can work together. Our community network produces high quality work tailored to your needs, specifications and style. <a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/about/partners/media-partnerships" target="_self">See our other media partners here.</a></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td valign="top" width="157"></td>
<td valign="top" width="481"></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td valign="top" width="157"><img class="aligncenter" style="margin-top: 5px; margin-bottom: 5px;" alt="" src="http://farm5.static.flickr.com/4056/4665507647_ffc370dd32_m.jpg" width="180" height="120" /></td>
<td valign="top" width="481">
<h2><a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/get-involved/intern-volunteer" target="_self">Volunteer with Us</a></h2>
You can make a significant impact by either as a volunteer or as an intern either inthe USA or in India. Interning and volunteering is a great way to be a part of Video Volunteers work. It is also an excellent way to learn of the community media movement and contribute to strengthen it. We look for people with all sorts of skills. <a href="http://videovolunteersindia.wufoo.com/forms/volunteerinternship-application-form/" target="_blank">Click here</a> to find out more!</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td valign="top" width="157"></td>
<td valign="top" width="481"></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td valign="top" width="157"><img class="aligncenter" style="margin-top: 5px; margin-bottom: 5px;" title="donate" alt="" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/11/donate.png" width="180" height="120" /></td>
<td valign="top" width="481">
<h2><a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/support-us" target="_self">Contribute Financially</a></h2>
You can also make a tremendous difference by making a financial contribution to Videos Volunteers work. Its amazing how much can be achieved with just a small amount of money from people like you. Your help will make a real difference to peoples lives around the world and help empower community voices against injustice and discrimination. <a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/support-us" target="_self">Donate here.</a></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td valign="top" width="157"></td>
<td valign="top" width="481"></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td valign="top" width="157"><img class="aligncenter" style="margin-top: 5px; margin-bottom: 5px;" title="IndiaUnheard-training-mar-10" alt="" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2007/08/IndiaUnheard-training-mar-10-300x217.jpg" width="180" height="120" />
<p style="text-align: center;"><a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/11/VV-logo-jpg1.jpg"><img class="aligncenter" style="margin-top: 15px; margin-bottom: 5px;" title="VV-logo-jpg" alt="" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/11/VV-logo-jpg1.jpg" width="180" height="120" /></a></p>
</td>
<td valign="top" width="481">
<h2><strong>Interact with Us</strong></h2>
<ul>
	<li><a href=" http://oi.vresp.com/?fid=4f2b9553f9" target="_blank"><strong>Sign upfor our quarterly newsletter</strong></a> which will keep you updated and informed on all the works that we do, the initiatives that we launch and the changes that we make to happen.</li>
	<li><strong><a href="http://www.facebook.com/pages/Video-Volunteers/44889911337" target="_blank">Join us on Facebook</a></strong> by clicking on the 'Like' button, and you can join our ever increasing network of online supporters and friends and help spread the word further.</li>
	<li><strong><a href="http://twitter.com/VideoVolunteers" target="_blank">Follow us on Twitter</a></strong> and Video Volunteers' tweets will bring you, on a regular basis, the most unheard news stories from across the country. We will also keep you informed on other important developments from within the Video Volunteers' growing network.</li>
	<li><strong><a href="../../../../../watch-a-video" target="_self">Watch the videos</a></strong> on our online platforms <a href="http://www.cvufilms.videovolunteers.org/" target="_blank"><em>CVU Films</em></a> and <em><a href="http://indiaunheard.videovolunteers.org/" target="_blank">IndiaUnheard</a> </em>and interact with our Community Producers and Correspondents. You can also get IndiaUnheard videos as an <a href="http://feeds.feedburner.com/VideoVolunteersIndiaUnheard" target="_blank">RSS feed</a> or <a href="http://feedburner.google.com/fb/a/mailverify?uri=VideoVolunteersIndiaUnheard" target="_blank">daily email post</a>.</li>
	<li><a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/archives/category/blog" target="_self"><strong>Read our Blog</strong></a> and follow events as they happen! You can also <a href="http://feeds.feedburner.com/videovolunteers/VideoVolunteersBlog" target="_blank">subscribe to the blog</a> in with an RSS reader.</li>
</ul>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>

Please write to us at<em><strong> info@videovolunteers.org</strong></em><strong> </strong>today, to start a conversation. You can also send message us on<a href="http://www.facebook.com/pages/Video-Volunteers/44889911337" target="_blank"><strong>Facebook</strong></a> or<a href="http://twitter.com/videovolunteers" target="_blank"><strong>Twitter</strong></a> or<a href="http://www.linkedin.com/pub/video-volunteers/22/a22/36b" target="_blank"><strong>LinkedIn</strong>.</a> <strong>We look forward to hearing from you soon and thanks for your interest in Video Volunteers' and our network for change!</strong>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Launch a CVU</title>
		<link>http://www.videovolunteers.org/programmes/cvus/launch-a-cvu/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 01 Nov 2007 09:24:46 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>nladmin</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.videovolunteers.org/?page_id=394</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h1><strong>Launch a Community Video Unit</strong></h1>
<p class="MsoNormal"><strong>Are you a Non-Government Organization (NGO) interested in starting a Community Video Unit (CVU)? </strong>Please, do contact us at <em><strong>info@videovolunteers.org</strong></em> to further discuss the process of launching a Community Video Unit (CVU) after reviewing the details below.</p>
<p class="MsoNormal"><img class="alignleft" style="margin: 5px;" src="http://farm3.static.flickr.com/2016/2095093314_1ee85400a5_o.jpg" alt="" hspace="5" vspace="5" width="270" height="174" align="left" />Video Volunteers provides guidance to NGOs in the developing world who wish to launch Community Video Units in their field areas.<span> We have assisted 12 NGOs in India to launch Community Video Units, and</span> the goal is to grow that number world-wide to over fifty Community Video Units, with fifty different NGOs.<span> </span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal"><a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/programmes/cvus" target="_self">Read <strong>here </strong>for about how the CVU works and operates</a><span> </span>and also review our <strong><a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/impact" target="_self">CVU Impact page</a></strong> for information on how a Community Video Unit directly benefits communities and NGOs.<span> </span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal">To launch a CVU typically takes between six to eight months of preparation time. The general process is as follows:</p>
<p class="MsoNormal"></p>

<ul>
	<li>You write to us expressing interest.</li>
	<li>We send you a questionnaire, a budget, and info on how the CVU works at an NGO.</li>
	<li>You organize to allocate your funds and resources and agree to launch the CVU.</li>
	<li>We come for a site visit, finalize plans, and sign a Memorandum of Understanding, committing both parties to the process.</li>
	<li>You identify 25 villages or slum areas where the CVU will work, and hire 8-10 community members as your Community Video Producers.</li>
	<li>You purchase all the equipment necessary from our equipment list.</li>
	<li>We identify a Video Trainer for your CVU, and ensure that person is trained in all aspects of community media during an intensive one-month group workshop. This person will work on-site at your NGO for 18 months.</li>
	<li>Training of Community Producers starts, and the CVU begins work!</li>
</ul>
<img class="alignleft" style="margin: 5px;" src="http://farm3.static.flickr.com/2089/2094313559_e96ec71d9e_o.jpg" alt="" hspace="5" vspace="5" width="281" height="240" align="left" />

During the first 18 months, the CVU will produce 8-10 video magazines, and reach around 10,000 people with each film.<span> </span>At the end of this 18 months innovations period, the video trainer will withdraw and the CVU will be technically proficient to produce videos on an ongoing basis within the NGO.<span> </span>Community video becomes a new program area for the NGO, until the time when the community can take over ownership of the CVU.<span> </span>

<span> </span>Video Volunteers will remain involved for years to come, providing technical support as required by the NGOs, promoting mainstream distribution and joint campaigns, coordinating the Network of NGOs and Producers, and connecting the Community Producers with international media networks we are part of.
<p class="MsoNormal"></p>
<p class="MsoNormal"></p>
<p class="MsoNormal"><strong>We hope you will join us in this exciting venture!</strong><span> </span></p>
If you are interested in starting a CVU please contact us and we will  send you detailed information on how the program works and the costs  involved. To start a conversation, email us at <em><strong>info@videovolunteers.org</strong></em> for more information or call us at <em><strong>+91-832-2281032</strong></em>.

<strong>To watch a CVU film,<a href="http://www.cvufilms.videovolunteers.org/" target="_blank"> click here.</a></strong>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Work with us </title>
		<link>http://www.videovolunteers.org/?page_id=409</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 19 Mar 2008 05:01:51 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>nladmin</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.videovolunteers.org/get-involved/work-with-our-network/</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h1>Work with us</h1>
If you are interested in working in community video, Video Volunteers can help you connect with NGOs that need people to work on their community video programs. Many of the NGOs whom we have supported in India to set up Community Video Units need video trainers and other filmmaking and program management staff. So if you are interested, please send your resume to <a title="mail to: info[at]videovolunteers.org" href="mailto:info@videovolunteers.org">info[at]videovolunteers.org</a><a title="mail to: videovolunteersindia[at]gmail.com" href="mailto:videovolunteersindia@gmail.com"></a> and we will send it on to an appropriate Community Video Unit or media organization.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>409</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2008-03-18 22:01:51</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2008-03-19 05:01:51</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>work-with-us</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>pending</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>239</wp:post_parent>

	<item>
		<title>Community Video Training Camp</title>
		<link>http://www.videovolunteers.org/projects-2/community-video-training-camp/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 03 Jul 2009 09:24:24 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>laina</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.videovolunteers.org/?page_id=501</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h1>Community Video Training Camp 2009</h1>
<strong>Video Volunteers Community Video Camp 2009 was the first ever conference in India dedicated to community video. It was held from August 11th - 14th 2009 in Goa, India, with community producers, NGOs and students from India and around the world meeting to exchange ideas.</strong>

<img class="alignleft" style="margin: 5px 10px; border: 0pt none;" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/cvcamp/group%20photo%202.jpg" border="0" alt="" width="230" height="154" />We at Video Volunteers have been bringing our community video producers together for joint training workshops for the past few years. In 2009, we wanted to widen our group of participants and test the idea of community video as a movement. The response was overwhelming: more than 250 people applied for only 130 seats. We had applications from roughly 55 NGOs from all over India, all of whom wanted to get into community video. The interest was not just limited to India-people from across the world, like the USA and the UK, Germany, Australia, Croatia, and Italy also attended.

<img class="alignleft" style="margin: 5px 10px; border: 0pt none;" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/cvcamp/MusicVid%20on%20road.jpg" border="0" alt="" width="230" height="185" align="TOP/" />

It was also an experiment in shared learning  what happens when experienced college students are in a classroom with Community Producers whose formal education level is quite basic? The students were inspired by the community video movement and it gave voice to their youthful aspirations of changing the world. The NGO workers became convinced of the potential of community video when they worked side by side with such articulate, empowered individuals. The community producers on the other hand got a chance to showcase their work, and receive feedback, most of which was very positive and confidence-bolstering. In this amazing mutually respectful environment, we all learnt better.

<img class="alignleft" style="margin: 5px 10px; border: 0pt none;" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/cvcamp/arjun%20and%20producers.jpg" border="0" alt="" width="230" height="154" align="TOP/" />

The workshops, panel discussions and the off-track events were also a part of the holistic package meant to develop critical thinking. The workshops brought out peoples creativity; panels, presentations and focus group discussions about community video and its future tickled peoples gray cells; award ceremonies recognized the social impact of community producers; open-mic events allowed people to relax and the amazing poolside areas allowed participants to socialize with the facilitators and each other.

<img class="alignleft" style="margin: 5px 10px; border: 0pt none;" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/cvcamp/students2.jpg" border="0" alt="" width="230" height="154" align="TOP/" />
<strong> </strong>
<h3><strong>To learn more:</strong></h3>
See the workshop details on our CV Camp <a href="http://videovolunteers-cvcamp.wikispaces.com/" target="_blank">wiki page</a>. All training materials and background information are here. We hope others will use these resources in their own community media trainings, or to put on similar events.
<strong>
</strong>
<strong> </strong>
<h3><strong>Read the detailed blog posts:</strong></h3>
<ul>
	<li><a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/archives/838" target="_blank">Video Volunteers Celebrates Successful Community Video Camp</a></li>
	<li><a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/archives/935" target="_blank">CV Camp update: How do college students feel about learning with Producers?</a></li>
	<li><a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/archives/898" target="_blank">CV camp update: Interview with Stalin about the creative camera workshop</a></li>
	<li><a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/archives/941" target="_blank">CV Camp Update: India Producers Skype with Brazil Producers</a></li>
	<li><a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/archives/1010" target="_blank">The Coscars: VVs First Community Video Award Ceremony</a></li>
</ul>]]></content:encoded>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.videovolunteers.org/?page_id=951</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<strong>Video Volunteers has been periodically creating toolkits that are a great resource for video trainers, film makers and community media workers. We have also published research papers and have been featured in books that can be a great resource for researchers and media professionals.</strong>
<h2><strong>Click on the links below to access these toolkits, books and papers:</strong></h2>

	<item>
		<title>Job Openings - Video Volunteers India </title>
		<link>http://www.videovolunteers.org/?page_id=995</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 04 Sep 2009 07:25:15 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>laina</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.videovolunteers.org/?page_id=995</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<strong>Openings at Video Volunteers India</strong>

Video Volunteers India, based in Goa, is looking to fill several positions to help lead our organization into the next phase. VV is a media and human rights NGO that is growing and changing along with the media and social change space in India. We need dedicated people with great ideas to join us on this journey of empowering community voices. This is the chance of a lifetime to be part of an energetic, entrepreneurial organization with a lot of passion.

The possible rewards of working with VV are huge  changing the media model as it is today.

The perfect candidate should be creative, enthusiastic and driven, and should be passionate about creating tangible and lasting solutions to the voicelessness of the disadvantaged in India.

<strong>Next Steps</strong>

Email your CV along with a thoughtful cover letter that helps us know you better. Tell us where you think Video Volunteers should be in five or ten years, and your role in getting us there. Let us know where you want to be career-wise in 5-10 years. Tell us what youre best at, what you want to learn, your salary expectations and the earliest you can join,. Applicants who dont take the time to write a cover letter will not be considered.

<strong>Money</strong>

Remuneration will be in accordance with prior work experience in related field.

Mail your applications to videovolunteersindia@gmail with the position you are applying for in the cover letter.

<em>Due to the volume of applicants anticipated, we will not be able to respond individually to each applicant and will only be contacting those applicants that we feel best meet our criteria.</em>

<strong> </strong>

<strong><span style="text-decoration: underline;">Executive Director </span></strong>

<em>Video Volunteers India is looking for an Executive Director to lead and expand our programs and organization in India. The goal is to make Video Volunteers India the leading media, human rights and social communications organization in India, that plays a key role in turning community media into a social movement. Our goal is to put the importance of community-produced content squarely onto the agenda of all those involved in social change in this country. Concretely, we wish to bring the tools of content creation to thousands of villages and to create several hundred more Community Producers, as well as transition the existing Community Video Units to viable models of community ownership. </em>

<span style="text-decoration: underline;">Key responsibilities</span>
<ul>
	<li>Partnerships expand VVs network of partners in the nonprofit, governmental and corporate sectors</li>
	<li>Fundraising  secure finances for the finances of VVs activities, that will include earned income through the mainstream media so as to lead to the creation of a financially viable media industry at the base of the pyramid.</li>
	<li>Campaigns  create campaigns on social issues in partnership with social movements and international organizations, where VV delivers community-produced content for use by many different actors</li>
	<li>Mainstream media partnerships  secure distribution/broadcast partnerships with different mainstream media channels</li>
	<li>Global expansion  Create strategies to strengthen VVs international work</li>
	<li>Policy Advocacy  carry out policy advocacy in India around such things as the Broadcasting Bill, Community Radio Policy, as well as exploring possibilities for advocacy at an international level around the importance of voice in the development process</li>
	<li>Staff Training  responsible for building a strong team , and nurturing and managing staff</li>
</ul>
<span style="text-decoration: underline;">Qualifications</span>
<ul>
	<li>Adequate experience running a nonprofit</li>
	<li>Media, arts or social communications background</li>
	<li>Amazing communications skills</li>
	<li>Management experience such as building a team, handling the finances and fundraising of an organization</li>
	<li>Strong network in the nonprofit, government and mainstream media circle</li>
</ul>
<strong><span style="text-decoration: underline;"> </span></strong>

<strong><span style="text-decoration: underline;">Senior Video Trainers</span></strong><strong><span style="text-decoration: underline;">
</span></strong><strong>
</strong><em>Video Volunteers is a non-profit organization dedicated to empowering community voices and to democratization of media. We set up community media units where poor and disadvantaged people are trained to create their own media content as a step towards finding solutions to their problems. Members of these units learn to be powerful communicators, journalists, filmmakers, and advocates and leaders in their communities. If you are video/film maker experienced in teaching/training and interested in working with the underprivileged communities in India then do read on.
</em>
<em>We are looking to employ</em> <em>Senior</em> <em>Video Trainers who are interested in being part of a growing community media movement.
</em>
<span style="text-decoration: underline;">Qualifications</span>
<ul>
	<li>Proficient in all aspects of video production--shooting, writing and non-linear editing</li>
	<li>Must have 4 to 5 years of video training experience,</li>
	<li>Candidates with experience of working in human rights or development organization will be preferred</li>
	<li>Must have shot, written and edited your own videos</li>
	<li>Must have strong creative and storytelling abilities</li>
	<li>Must have leadership qualities to motivate and lead</li>
	<li>Must have great communications skills and a desire to work with communities</li>
	<li>Must be willing to travel to remote, rural area for sizeable amounts of time</li>
	<li>Must be proficient in writing and reading English, Hindi and third language preferable</li>
	<li>Must show a reel of work you have shot, written and edited on your own</li>
</ul>
<strong><span style="text-decoration: underline;"> </span></strong>

<strong><span style="text-decoration: underline;">Program Coordinators</span></strong>

<em>The Program Coordinators manage the community video projects after they have been launched. They are very involved with the Community Video and Radio projects, and are in regular touch with the Community Video Producers and our NGO partners. The role involves trouble-shooting and problem-solving, as well as great organizational skills necessary for keeping projects on track. </em>

<span style="text-decoration: underline;"> </span>

<span style="text-decoration: underline;">Key Responsibilities</span>
<ul>
	<li>Organize training schedules for video and radio training</li>
	<li>Create progress reports on each VV project, including maintaining the quantitative data</li>
	<li>Organize events such as Training Camps and regional trainings</li>
	<li>Handle all scheduling and logistics for program activities</li>
	<li>Create projects for volunteers and interns</li>
	<li>Update training manuals and review training reports</li>
</ul>
<span style="-webkit-text-decorations-in-effect: underline;"><span style="text-decoration: underline;">Qualifications</span></span>
<ul>
	<li>Three years of work experience</li>
	<li>Academic background in social work or management</li>
	<li>Extremely organized and enjoys working with data and creating management systems</li>
	<li>Great writing skills in English</li>
	<li>Great communications skills for building relationships with community producers and partner organizations</li>
	<li>Communication skills in Hindi and English</li>
</ul>
<strong><span style="text-decoration: underline;"> </span></strong>

<strong><span style="text-decoration: underline;">Senior Administrator</span></strong>

<em>The Senior Administrator will manage the office in Goa, making sure that things run smoothly and working to maintain a smooth, professional, positive office environment. He or she will be involved in all administrative and legal issues, including supervision of accounts and audits. She will play a key role in Human Resources, such as handling initial interviews with potential staff.</em>

<em><span style="text-decoration: underline;"> </span></em>

<span style="text-decoration: underline;">Key Responsiblities</span>
<ul>
	<li>Identify and interface with key consultants/associates, such as lawyers, accountant, landlords, etc.</li>
	<li>Oversee the audit and maintain the basic accounts, such as the daily Petty Cash and Vouchers</li>
	<li>Oversee the hiring process in the office and basic HR issues such as monthly reporting and expenses of staff</li>
	<li>Manage all Office Correspondence - Letters, Emails, Telephone, etc.</li>
	<li>Manage Office Equipment, Office Space, books and video library</li>
	<li>Maintain the contacts database and mailing lists</li>
	<li>Manage Appointment Schedules, Meetings, Events/Conferences, Travel Arrangements and Logistics</li>
	<li>Undertake Governance Responsibilities , such as board meetings, minutes, etc.</li>
	<li>Manage and Update Maintenance of Common Services and Contracts</li>
	<li>Manage and Update Office and Personnel Insurances (Mediclaim and Personal Accident)</li>
	<li>Write and Send Donor Compliance Reports</li>
	<li>Purchase Office Supplies and Equipment as per Purchase Policy</li>
</ul>
<span style="-webkit-text-decorations-in-effect: underline;"><span style="text-decoration: underline;">Qualifications</span></span>
<ul>
	<li>At least three years work experience in administration or management roles</li>
	<li>Good writing and communication skills</li>
	<li>Adequate computer skills to work with data, text, and accounting</li>
	<li>Candidates with knowledge of Tally or Quickbooks will be preffered</li>
</ul>
<strong><span style="text-decoration: underline;">Video Editor</span></strong>

<em>The video editor will assist the program staff in preparing videos for distribution online and occasionally via mainstream media. Every month, video will be received from numerous community producers around the country in raw form, with scripts attached. the Video Editor will cut from this material numerous short, 3-5 minute web videos. Since most video will be for the web, the key skill needed is the ability to work efficiently, producing several short three minute videos every day. </em>

<span style="text-decoration: underline;">Key Responsibilities:</span>
<ul>
	<li>Cutting half hour community videos into seven minute subtitled videos to show at conferences and presentations</li>
	<li>Taking lots of raw footage plus scripts and creating numerous short web videos</li>
	<li>Subtitling videos into English and formatting them for the web</li>
</ul>
<span style="text-decoration: underline;">Qualifications</span>
<ul>
	<li>At least one year experience working as a video editor</li>
	<li>Mastery of Final Cut Pro, Adobe Premier, Adobe Audition, After Effects, Photoshop, compression softwares</li>
	<li>Knowledge of uploading video on the web</li>
</ul>
<strong><span style="text-decoration: underline;">Accounts Officer</span></strong>

<em>The accounts officer will maintain the office accounts.</em>

<span style="-webkit-text-decorations-in-effect: underline;"><span style="text-decoration: underline;">Key Responsibilities</span></span>
<ul>
	<li>Prepare monthly expense reports</li>
	<li>Maintain cash and bank books</li>
	<li>Prepare statutory audits</li>
	<li>Prepare financial reports</li>
	<li>Enter all data into softwares such as Tally or Quickbooks</li>
</ul>
<span style="-webkit-text-decorations-in-effect: underline;"><span style="text-decoration: underline;">Qualifications</span></span>
<ul>
	<li>At least two years work experience</li>
	<li>Degree related to accounting</li>
	<li>Knowledge of accounting softwares such as Tally or Quickbooks</li>
</ul>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Staff</title>
		<link>http://www.videovolunteers.org/about/staff/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 14 May 2010 09:29:19 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>nladmin</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.videovolunteers.org/bios-%e2%80%93-staff/</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h1>Video Volunteers' Staff</h1>
<strong>Stalin K., Managing Trustee, Video Volunteers India</strong>
<img class="alignleft" style="margin: 5px;" alt="Stalin K" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/05/stalin.jpg" width="130" height="140" />

Stalin K. is a documentary filmmaker, media trainer and human rights activist from Gujarat, India. Stalin has directed 15 documentaries and has won several international awards for hisfilms. He has produced six community radio programs, designed more than 20<a href="http://stalink.wordpress.com/campaign-design/"> rights-based campaigns</a> and conducted over 300 trainings in film making and participatoryvideo, street theatre, radio production, and development communications. As an activist, he has been deeply involved in the relief efforts of the 2002 Gujarat riots, and of the Kutch earthquake of 2001, during which time he helped to create a community radio program that was instrumental in delivering information to the victims.

Stalin was the Convener of the <a href="http://www.crforum.in/">Community Radio Forum-India</a> until 2009 and was one of the core group that drafted the legislation that made community radio legal in India. His film work on the issue of untouchability has helped bring international attention to Dalit issues, most notably his 1996 film<a href="http://stalink.wordpress.com/documentaries/lesser-humans/"> Lesser Humans</a> on manual scavenging, and his feature-length 2007 film<a href="http://stalink.wordpress.com/documentaries/india-untouched/">IndiaUntouched</a>, winner of the Mumbai International Film Festival. This film surveys the existence of untouchability across 8 states, four religions and all social classes in India. He teaches communications, film and grassroots activism at a number of the most seniorinstitutes in India and has lectured at Berkeley, Stanford and NYU, among other institutions, and also advises foundations and NGOs on their communications and participatory media strategies. One of his greatest passions is training rural men and women in leadership and in expressing themselves powerfully, and he spends as much time as possible in the field, working directly with communities. Until 2008 he ran Drishti Media in Ahmedabad, an organization he co-founded at the age of 23. You can read his personal blog<a href="http://stalink.wordpress.com/">here</a>

<strong>Jessica Mayberry, Founding Director </strong>

<a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/05/JessicaMayberry-1.jpg"><img class="alignleft size-full wp-image-2125" title="JessicaMayberry 1" alt="" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/05/JessicaMayberry-1.jpg" width="130" height="141" /></a>

Jessica Mayberry founded Video Volunteers after spending a year training rural Indian women in filmmaking as a W.J. Clinton Fellow of the American India Foundation. Jessica is a TED Fellow and a Fellow of Echoing Green, an organization that invests in social entrepreneurs with high-impact solutions. In 2009 she was recognized as an Architect of the Future by the WaldzellInstituteof Austria, and in 2010, as an Outstanding Young Person by the Junior Chamber International Osaka. In 2011, she was one of the top fifty people shortlisted for the Grinnell College Young Innovator for Social Justice Prize, out of over 1000 applicants from 66 countries. Under her leadership VV has won numerous awards, including the Knight News Challenge, the most competitive award for innovations in news and information, the NYU-Stern Business School Business Plan competition, a Tech Award, a Development Gateway Awards shortlist, and a shortlist for the King Baudouin (of Belgium) Foundation International Development Prize.

Prior to starting Video Volunteers, Jessica worked in television in New York at Court TV, the Fox News Channel, and CNN. She has served on the board of Free the Children, the worlds largest organization of Children Helping Children and on the Advisory Council of Counterpart International. She holds a degree in Modern History and Modern Languages from Oxford University, from which she graduated in 1999.

<strong>Manish Kumar, Program Manager &amp; Principal Trainer</strong>

<a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/05/manish.jpg"><img class="alignleft size-full wp-image-2564" title="manish" alt="" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/05/manish.jpg" width="130" height="140" /></a>

Manishs expertise is in documentary film-making and community video training. In his four years with Video Volunteers he has trained more than 200 community people to make films and use media to createawareness in their communities. Prior to coming to Video Volunteers, Manish served as a Program Associate at Community Enterprise Forum International.

Manish interned at Doordarshan News, where he gained experience with mainstreammedia.He has directed the film, Bahin Tonye Kahah Jathis, which focuses on the exploitation and trafficking of Tribal girls to Delhi for domestic work. Manish has aPost Graduate Diploma in Development Communication from the Mass Communication Research Center at Jamia Millia Islamia University in Delhi and a degree in masscommunicationfrom Bharti Vidya Bhava, in New Delhi.

<strong>Dina Madhani, Partnerships Director</strong>

<a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/05/Dina.jpg"><img class="alignleft size-full wp-image-1319" title="Dina" alt="" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/05/Dina.jpg" width="130" height="135" /></a>

Dina Madhani is the Development and Partnerships Director for Video Volunteers. Based in New York, Dina is focused on building awareness for Video Volunteers mission through partnerships with media organizations. She alsocollaborates on marketing, strategy and fundraising efforts.

PreviouslyDina was the Marketing Director for MTV &amp; VH1's Digital Channels at MTV Networks where sheled the brand marketing strategy and partnerships for 8 channels.Dinareceived her MBA in Marketing and Management fromNYU Stern and her BA in InternationalRelations from Tufts University.

<strong>Shobha R., Strategic Manager</strong>

<a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/05/Photo0188.jpg"><img class="alignleft size-full wp-image-2823" title="Photo0188" alt="" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/05/Photo0188.jpg" width="113" height="150" /></a>Shobha is a development professional with around ten years of work experience. She has a masters in social work from the Tata Institute of Social Sciences. She started off her career working with primitive tribal groups in Srikakulam district of Andhra Pradesh.She then worked with Oxfam in the tsunami disaster response and rehabilitation programmes for four years and subsequently in the gender justice programme in west India for two years. Among her varied interests, she would also like to build on her understanding of issues related to marginalized groups- especially vulnerability of forest dependent tribal groups leading to forced displacement and its gendered dimensions. She is also passionate about working towards community owned and community led processes for their own empowerment.<a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/05/Photo0188.jpg">
</a>

<strong>Sahana Bhattacharya, Program Manager</strong>

<strong><a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/05/sahana.jpg"><img class="alignleft size-full wp-image-2550" title="sahana" alt="" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/05/sahana.jpg" width="105" height="140" /></a></strong>

Sahana Bhattacharya is a documentary filmmaker, engaged to the cause of diverse community issues. She studied Linguistics and French language in Kolkata and later worked as a research faculty with Asiatic society on the documentation of technology of wooden bullock cart wheel. She made a couple of documentary films on indigenous practices and communities such as cart wheel makers, Chow mask makers, Gutipua dancers, midwifery etc.

Her film project  Fables of Birth  has been awarded Brouillon dun rve by SCAM (Civil Society of Art and Multimedia of France) on 2004 selection. She has also directed a film on junior artists of Bollywood titled "Extras, the identity of politics" and experienced the mainstream media thoroughly in Mumbai and France.

<strong>Aljai Singh, Executive Producer</strong>

<a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/05/Aljais.jpeg"><img class="alignleft size-full wp-image-2690" title="Aljais" alt="" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/05/Aljais.jpeg" width="150" height="99" /></a>

Aljai Singh has been producing and developing content for the IndianTelevision Industry for nine years, starting with India's first everdaily soap (Shanti) moving on to ad films and later programming forindependent shows (Road Show, MTV-U etc), co-producing Auto India Showfor BITV, and finally with Headlines Today, producing promos andspecials. She worked with WPSI ,Delhi as a program co-coordinator andat ICT, Kodaikanal, a school for village children and vocation centerdeveloping Eco-products by local women. She ran a small cafe inManali. She plays and mixes live video (real time) to live music. Sheis a Reconnective Healing Practitioner.

Her happiest job so far has been as a single mother to two children.

<strong>Siddharth Pillai, Communications Manager</strong>

<a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/05/sid-1.jpg"><img class="alignleft size-full wp-image-2129" title="sid 1" alt="" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/05/sid-1.jpg" width="130" height="138" /></a>Siddharth worked for around five years as the Joint Secretary of Bangalore Film Society where he was involved in the curation and exhibition of motion pictures and documentaries for educational purposes. During that time, he curated a package titled 'cinema of resistance' for the World Social Forum 2007 in Nairobi. He also worked in several capacities for Voices from the Waters, an international environmental travelling film festival. In 2008, he became the associate editor for Deep Focus Film Quarterly, a serious cinema journal. As a film critic he was selected for the Berlinale talent campus in 2009 and also managed to write a few articles for the local newspapers.In 2010, he briefly held the post of Treasurer for the Federation of Film Societies in India but that didn't go too well. He blogs infrequently at passionforcinema.com and for the South Asian Spaces Blog for FLEFF, Ithaca College, New York.

<strong>Tania Devaiah, Impact Manager</strong>

<strong></strong><a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/05/download-63.jpg"><img class="alignleft size-thumbnail wp-image-2639" title="download (6)" alt="" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/05/download-63-139x150.jpg" width="139" height="150" /></a>Nature lover and adventure junkie by nature and a social worker by profession, Tania has always had a keen interest in issues relating to social justice. Originally from Coorg and brought up in Bangalore, she completed her MA in Social Work from TISS, Mumbai in 2008 with a focus on Criminology and Correctional Justice.She has worked with Prerana in Mumbai and Biocon Foundation in Bangalore.

Taniahas hands on experience with issues primarily related to human trafficking and gender, primary health care and education. She loves to travel and enjoys pushing her own boundaries in whatever she does.

&nbsp;

<strong id="internal-source-marker_0.37146934773772955">Anand Hembrom, Editor- Co-ordinator, IndiaUnheard, Ranchi</strong>

<a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/05/anand-bhai.jpg"><img class="alignleft size-full wp-image-2557" title="OLYMPUS DIGITAL CAMERA" alt="" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/05/anand-bhai.jpg" width="100" height="150" /></a>

Anand is from Kasiadih village, Hazaribag district of Jharkhand. He belongs to Santhal Adivasi community. He completed M A in broadcast journalism from Delhi (NISCORT) and has worked with the group of the people named AKHRA which produce documentary films on various issues and work for the culture and communication for Adivasi community in Jharkhand.

Anand has been involved with the peoples movement to protect land, forest and water which is being taken away by corporates like TATA, CCI, Jindal etc.

&nbsp;

<strong id="internal-source-marker_0.37146934773772955">Shobha Ajay, Editor- Co-ordinator, IndiaUnheard, Bhilai</strong>

<a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/05/Shobha-3.jpeg"><img class="alignleft size-full wp-image-2686" title="Shobha 3" alt="" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/05/Shobha-3.jpeg" width="100" height="133" /></a>

Shobha is a filmmaker with over ten years of experience. Her films are from a social anthropological point of view and on diverse issues such as gender relations, the relationship between traditions and politics and health. Her documentary, Living Memory,was screened at the Kings College and the Cambridge South Asia Forum. She worked as a research assistant with the Social Anthropology Department at the LSE on a project that worked with women and children in Chhattisgarh.

For the last two years Shobha has been working as a Senior Trainer with the Mayaram Surjan Foundation on project that works with children.

<strong>Sarita Biswal, Co-ordinator, IndiaUnheard, Odisha</strong>

<a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/05/58174_152008708170121_2664592_n.jpg"><img class="alignleft size-full wp-image-2826" title="58174_152008708170121_2664592_n" alt="" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/05/58174_152008708170121_2664592_n.jpg" width="160" height="160" /></a>Sarita was a Community Correspondent from Cuttack District before she became the Odisha co-ordinator for IndiaUnheard. Born in a village where there are no schools that teach past the seventh grade, she had to struggle and persevere to get educated. As a correspondent, she made many powerful videos on the issues of gender discrimination, mining, land grabs, smuggling etc.

She is a local leader and the face of the popular anti-mining campaign in her village. She organized her people in a campaign and successfully ended timber smuggling in her area.After her marriage, she has shifted to Jamshedpur but continues to lead and participate in the grassroots movements in her native village.

<strong>Joel DSouza, Video Trainer &amp; Editor</strong>

<a style="font-weight: bold;" href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/05/Joel-1.jpg"><img class="alignleft size-full wp-image-2132" title="Joel 1" alt="" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/05/Joel-1.jpg" width="130" height="140" /></a>Joel graduated in commerce from Pune University with a major in Marketing and Advertising. He started his career in media working as copy designer for Wordsmith Communication and later his love and interest in audio took him to Radio Mirchi, Pune where he worked as a Sound Engineer and Promo Designer. Later asa Assistant Producer with CBN multimedia Pvt. Ltd. he worked on shows telecasted on Sony Television Network, India.

Joel also worked with the outreach team of the company in facilitating access to water to deprived communities across India.It was an experience that marked him and later, he joined Video Volunteers as a Video Trainer.

&nbsp;

<strong>Radhika Gupta, Program Coordinator</strong>

<strong><a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/05/273043_2259069680070_1348248013_2698451_6301197_o.jpg"><img class="alignleft size-full wp-image-2566" title="273043_2259069680070_1348248013_2698451_6301197_o" alt="" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/05/273043_2259069680070_1348248013_2698451_6301197_o.jpg" width="131" height="130" /></a></strong>

Radhikadid her Masters in Gender, Culture and Development and wrote her dissertation on changing cultures with a special focus on hippies inIndia. In University she had the opportunity to work on various audio visual projects which gave her the chance to learn about various cultures and lifestyles. Prior to her degree she worked extensively in animal welfare and taught English to underprivileged children.

She enjoys exploring new places, meeting people, learning about different cultures, reading or writing about dogs and random people for her blog. She hopes to build an animal shelter in the future.

<strong>Ayush Kapur, Project Coordinator</strong>

<a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/05/VV-website.jpg"><img class="alignleft size-full wp-image-2558" title="VV website" alt="" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/05/VV-website.jpg" width="130" height="140" /></a>
<div>Ayush completed his graduation in 2011 from Symbiosis Institute of Media and Communication with specialization in Audio Visual Production. He made a couple of web virals for Pudumjeehygiene,Pune during his final year. He worked on KBC 5 ( Kaun Banega Crorepati) as the Casting Producer and on-shoot-Assistant. He had a small stint with Media Transasia India Ltd as ad sales executive in Mumbai.</div>
<div>.</div>
<div>Traveling is his middle name. He been based out of 8 states in India till now. He is a film buff and has a passion for sports.</div>
<div></div>
<strong>Amrita Anand, Program Coordinator</strong>

<a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/05/AmritaProfilepic.jpeg"><img class="alignleft size-full wp-image-2687" title="AmritaProfilepic" alt="" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/05/AmritaProfilepic.jpeg" width="150" height="113" /></a>
<div>
<div>Soon after graduating from College, Amrita joined Swechha, a youth based NGO in Delhi. Here she worked on implementing an alternative education program for children from marginalized communities. Amrita is also a sports fanatic; she is an avid runner and a national level kickboxing gold-medalist. She is passionate about her work, traveling and reading among other things.She is experienced in project design, implementation, management, monitoring and evaluation, as well as fieldwork, social campaigning, volunteer management, communitymobilization fundraising and networking.In her free time Amrita likes to blog on her ponderings and observations about the world around her.</div>
</div>
<strong>Kayonaaz Kalyanwala, Program Coordinator</strong>

<a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/05/IMG_5103.jpg"><img class="alignleft size-full wp-image-2689" title="IMG_5103" alt="" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/05/IMG_5103.jpg" width="100" height="156" /></a>
<div>

Kayonaaz has a Masters in Media and International Development from the University of East Anglia. Her final dissertation examined the efficacy of AIDS awareness posters as tools of development communication. Before returning to India she worked at the Commonwealth Broadcasting Association where she did research on Public Service Broadcasting and the News Media in India as well as helped manage an online film initiative, YourWorldView.

Kayonaaz has now lived in four cities in the world and hopes to add many more to the list.

</div>
<div></div>
<div>.</div>
<div><strong>Poornima Damade, Editor and Media Trainer</strong></div>
<div></div>
<div><a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/05/IMG_188011.jpg"><img class="alignleft size-full wp-image-2825" title="IMG_1880[1]" alt="" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/05/IMG_188011.jpg" width="113" height="150" /></a>Poornima graduated from Symbiosis Institute of Media and Communication with specialization in Audio Visual production. She has worked with DISHA(hiv/aids services), a project under Deep Girha Society, a Pune based ngo. She has also worked with Smile foundation working for education of small girl child and interned with Lighting Fish games as a motion editor. She likes reading fictional novels, watching movies, listening to music, travelling, exploring mostly hilly areas and meeting new people. She is kind of an introvert but gets comfortable with time.</div>
<div>

She loves editing.

</div>
<div>.</div>
<div><strong>Kinshuk Srivastava, Media Trainer</strong></div>
<a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/05/download-4.jpg"><img class="alignleft size-thumbnail wp-image-2640" title="download (4)" alt="" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/05/download-4-150x150.jpg" width="150" height="150" /></a>

Kinshuk holds a degree in English Literature from the University of Delhi as well as a postgraduate diploma in Television &amp; Video Production from the Symbiosis Institute of Mass Communication, Pune. In Mumbai, he joined Famous Studios as a Line Producer for their Digital Intermediate department working on various Bollywood film projects. Later he has worked with Prana Studios, Mumbai for the Walt Disney Produced Film Tinker Bell. As an editor Kinshuk has worked onthe Behind the Scene documentary for the feature film Delhi Belly.

He has also been on the production team for shows like Ice Road Truckers and the Amazing Race.For the past year he has been making corporate and music videos, developing documentary projects along with writing fiction feature length scripts.

<strong>Prakash Phondekar, Accounts &amp; Finance</strong>

<a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/05/p1.jpg"><img class="alignleft size-full wp-image-2563" title="p" alt="" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/05/p1.jpg" width="129" height="140" /></a>

Prakash Phondekar was born in Morjim, Goa. He has spent all his life in and around this idyllic town and he wishes that it would so for the rest of his life. He completed hisgraduationin Saraswat Vidyalaya, Mapusa and wishes to rejoin his studies in the near future to pursue the much coveted ICWAI. He enjoys a game of football with friends and finds his work with Video Volunteers to be a new and learning experience.

&nbsp;

.

<strong>Kanhaiya Maurya,Assistant Video Trainer</strong>
<a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/05/download-5.jpg"><img class="alignleft size-full wp-image-2635" title="download (5)" alt="" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/05/download-5.jpg" width="130" height="141" /></a>Kanhaiya Maurya graduated from Kashi Vidyapeeth completing his Bachelors of Arts in 2010. During college, he underwent training in computers and graphic designing and has been actively teaching courses at a computer institute for the past three years. He also worked part-time, video-editing at Globe Studios, Varanasi.

He volunteers and works with handicapped children at Kiran Shelter, an Ngo and organizes cultural programs. Currently, he is employed as the assistant video trainer in the Saksham Project of Video Volunteers.

.

<strong>Kamini Menon, Consultant</strong>

<strong><a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/05/download1.jpg"><img class="alignleft size-full wp-image-2560" title="download" alt="" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/05/download1.jpg" width="140" height="93" /></a></strong>

Kamini joined Video Volunteers initially as an intern for the IndiaUnheard program. Shehas a Masters in Global Communications from the American University of Paris and wrote her final dissertation on 'the power of story to inculcate social progress' using a miniseries produced by MTV and a sample of forty urban youth respondents.While doing her Master's, she focused on NGO communications and film production, and made a documentary entitled 'The Dying Trades of the Fez Medina' in Morocco.Prior to that she worked in PR and edited a bi-monthly marketing publication for a recreationalcentercalled the Village Market in Nairobi and simultaneously worked for an online national student website.

<strong>Mehul Makwana, Program Director, Community Radio</strong>

<a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/05/mehul-1.jpg"><img class="alignleft size-full wp-image-2142" title="mehul 1" alt="" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/05/mehul-1.jpg" width="130" height="140" /></a>

Mehul is based in Ahmedabad, Gujarat and manages all community radio programming, training andpartnerships for Video Volunteers. He is also the head of all CVU programming in Gujarat.

Mehul is a development media professional with a background in journalism, and a decade of rich experience working in the development sector. He has commendable flair and skill for creative writing, theatre, radio programming, filmmaking, designing advocacy campaigns and training.

<strong>
</strong>

<strong>Arun Paswan, Office Assistant </strong>

<strong><a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2013/03/24012013167-e1363083630796.jpg"><img class="size-full wp-image-2975 alignleft" alt="24012013167" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2013/03/24012013167-e1363083630796.jpg" width="130" height="98" /></a></strong>Arun is the glue that holds the office together; his tea and infectious laugh keep us going on long days. Originally from Nepal, he has lived in India for nearly 20 years. He speaks Nepali, Gujarati, Hindi and a spot of Konkani.

Arun's philosophy in life is to keep laughing, no matter how complicated things get.

&nbsp;

	<item>
		<title>Programs</title>
		<link>http://www.videovolunteers.org/programmes/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 14 May 2010 10:01:34 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>nladmin</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.videovolunteers.org/?page_id=1146</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h1>Programs</h1>
<a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/05/action.jpg"><img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-2202" title="action" alt="" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/05/action.jpg" width="625" height="363" /></a>
<strong>Since 2003, Video Volunteers has been creating programs and projects that empower poor and marginalized communities with a voice to address poverty, inequality and injustice. Its mission is to empower the worlds poorest citizens to right the wrongs they witness by becoming players in the global media revolution. </strong><strong>Below is an overview of Video Volunteers' main programs and projects; more details can also be found on their specific web pages.</strong>
<strong>
</strong>
<h3><a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/programmes/cvus" target="_self"><strong>Community Video Units</strong></a></h3>
<img class="alignleft" style="margin: 5px;" alt="" src="http://farm2.static.flickr.com/1166/1325386687_5093b6abe8_m.jpg" width="240" height="160" />Community Video Units (CVUs) create platforms for communities to dialog and find solutions, and empower people to take action on local issues. CVUs are local production entities, created by Video Volunteers in partnership with different NGOs, that are run by up to 10 community members trained in all aspects of video production and distribution.

These <em>community video producers</em> make films on issues decided by community editorial boards, that they then screen back on widescreen projectors to thousands of people in the community. Thousands of people have taken action on their issues after seeing these films, and <strong><a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/impact" target="_self">you can read about the impacts here</a></strong>. There are currently ten Community Video Units, who have organized more than 3000 screenings in over 300 villages which have been seen by more than 250,000 people.

<strong> You can watch a CVU film <a href="http://www.cvufilms.videovolunteers.org" target="_blank">here </a> or learn about starting your own CVU<a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/programmes/cvus/launch-a-cvu" target="_self"> here.</a></strong>
<strong>
</strong>
<h3><strong><a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/programmes/indiaunheard/" target="_self">IndiaUnheard</a></strong></h3>
<img class="alignleft" style="margin: 5px;" alt="" src="http://farm2.static.flickr.com/1297/4665151985_19a8a9ab35_m.jpg" width="240" height="200" />IndiaUnheard is a network of more than 31 Community Correspondents from 24 states and union territories across India. These Community Correspondents represent Indias most marginalized communities, such as Dalits, tribal people, religious, lingual and sexual minorities.

The video reports filed by the Community Correspondents are on issues of utmost importance to these communities that are not reported by the mainstream media. The powerful combination of new media approachesvideo journalism, SMS reporting and social media networkingallows them to engage with both a national and international audience in a truly innovative way.

<strong>Watch an IndiaUnheard video<a href="http://indiaunheard.videovolunteers.org/" target="_blank"> here</a> or start an IndiaUnheard regional hub<a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/programmes/indiaunheard/create-an-indiaunheard-regional-hub" target="_self"> here.</a></strong>
<strong>
</strong>
<h3><strong><a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/programmes/brazil-livelihood-program-%E2%80%93-vcu-br" target="_self">VCU.br -- Video for Livelihood in Brazil</a></strong></h3>
<a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/05/PROJECT-BRAZIL.jpg"><img class="alignleft size-thumbnail wp-image-1780" style="margin: 5px;" title="PROJECT BRAZIL" alt="" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/05/PROJECT-BRAZIL-150x150.jpg" width="240" height="177" /></a>Based in Brazil, out of Sao Paulo, VCU.br is a Video Volunteers project whose main focus is on the livelihoods and building of entrepreneurial skills for Brazilian youth from slums by training them on how to make a living through videos. So, they are taught not just about how to shoot or write a script, but also about how to sell the videos that they make. This is why the trainees are also learning how to pitch story ideas to TV industry and other clients. These young people are learning how to develop their entrepreneurial skills by using their difficult background as an asset. <a href="http://www.cvufilms.videovolunteers.org/?custom_f[]=&amp;custom_f[]=+VV+Brazil&amp;custom_f[]=&amp;s_real=&amp;search_field=9_NGO/Sponsor&amp;s=trigger_the_search&amp;cat=3" target="_blank"><strong>Click here</strong></a><strong> to watch films produced by Brazil VCU producers.</strong>
<strong>
</strong>
<h3><strong><a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/programmes/community-radio/" target="_self">Community Radio
</a></strong></h3>
<a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/05/COMMUNITY-RADIO.jpg"><img class="alignleft size-medium wp-image-1783" style="margin: 5px;" title="COMMUNITY RADIO" alt="" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/05/COMMUNITY-RADIO-300x225.jpg" width="240" height="160" /></a>Video Volunteers programs have created great impact and have helped local communities find solutions to their specific problems, and we continue to find ways to empower more communities to raise their voices and lead, connect and change, to not only better their lives but also to make this world a better place for all. As a member, and past secretariat, of the <strong><em>Community Radio Forum</em> (CRF)</strong>, Video Volunteers believes in the power of community radio and is committed to democratization of Indias airwaves. Video Volunteers is currently designing the strategy for Shramik Bharti, an NGO in Kanpur, Uttar Pradesh, which is setting up community radio programs and training 20 people, and the Managing Trustee of Video Volunteers, Stalin K., designed and trained two of the earliest community radio stations in the countryKMVS and Dang.
<strong>
</strong>
<h3><strong><a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/programmes/videoshala/" target="_self">Videoshala E-CVUs</a></strong></h3>
<a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/05/Manish-Kumar-training-Videoshala-producers.jpg"><img class="alignleft size-thumbnail wp-image-1781" style="margin: 5px;" title="Manish Kumar training Videoshala producers" alt="" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/05/Manish-Kumar-training-Videoshala-producers-150x150.jpg" width="240" height="160" /></a>The Videoshala (literally 'videoschool') project is a unique and innovative intervention that trains local community members to produce educational videos and screen them to students across their marginalized communities. Launched in in Gujarat during 2007 with our partner NGOsDrishti Media Arts and Human Rights and Udaan (Education Resource Centre)the initiative is funded by the QUEST Alliance and the International Youth Foundation (IYF). Through the establishment of these Education Community Video Units (E-CVUs), Videoshala works towards a sustainable model of using community-produced videos as classroom tools to enrich education and empower the community by inculcating values of diversity and inclusion within classrooms.

Each E-CVU has a team of six Producers, two-to-five Classroom Facilitators, one Trainer, and one Coordinator. The producers are trained in video film making, editing, scriptwriting, shooting, storytelling, creating creative content, instructional design, educational pedagogy, learning from songs, dramas and illustrations, classroom facilitation, and values of diversity and democracy. The classroom facilitators are trained on classroom facilitation and teaching techniques, on how children learn, administering worksheets, carrying out student activities and involving teachers in the video screening process.
<strong>
</strong>
<h3></h3>
<h3><strong><a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/programmes/global-fund-for-children/" target="_self">Videoactive Girls</a></strong></h3>
<a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/05/Mahita-girls.jpg"><img class="alignleft size-medium wp-image-1782" style="margin: 5px;" title="Mahita girls" alt="" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/05/Mahita-girls-300x225.jpg" width="240" height="160" /></a>Under this program, Video Volunteers partnered with The Global Fund for Children(GFC), The Nike Foundation, and local NGOs Kolkata Sanved and Mahita, to train adolescent girls the process of video production, teaching them to capture their stories and share their stories with a wider audience. The Videoactive Girls initiative focused on education in the art of digital storytelling, video production, and video-sharing skills, with the goal of helping the participating girls cultivate greater self-confidence and self-empowerment through the learning process.

An extensive toolkit was also designed to enable other NGOs to create and achieve their own video training projects that nurture, inspire, and motivate adolescent girls to play a part in building their communities into places in which they would like to live. It provides step-by-step instructions on how to begin such a project, including implementation, follow-through, and how to use it to create positive change in girls lives and communities. The kit is also intended to help media literacy organizations, policy makers, funding agencies, social-media scholars, and other media practitioners understand the ideas, concepts, implementation, logistics, and assessment of media projects for girls.
<strong>
</strong>
<h3></h3>
<h3><a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/programmes/videos-for-livelihood" target="_self">Sustainable Community Media Research Program</a></h3>
<img class="alignright" alt="" src="http://farm5.static.flickr.com/4001/4665180595_922220ec28_m.jpg" width="240" height="161" />Video Volunteers is working to devise business models that will help community media reach high levels of sustainability, including earning revenue through partnering with the mainstream media and via collaborations with other NGOs. Presently, Video Volunteers has joined forces with the Indian Institute of Management (IIM), based in Ahmedabad, to develop a business model which can be followed by various community video units (CVUs) to attain financial sustainability.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Community Producers</title>
		<link>http://www.videovolunteers.org/programmes/cvus/community-producers/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 14 May 2010 10:07:23 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>nladmin</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.videovolunteers.org/?page_id=1147</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h1>Community Producers</h1>
<strong>Video Volunteers Community Video Unit (CVU) producers are a true group</strong><strong> of barefoot journalists with a strong commitment to their communities and a passion to bring social change. Each of the producers also has a unique socio-cultural background and has borne witness to several wrongdoings within his/her community. Now, through their videos, the producers are determined to raise community voices against those wrongs.</strong>

<img class="alignleft" style="margin: 5px;" src="http://farm4.static.flickr.com/3310/4626314928_0f3104bcf2.jpg" alt="" width="325" height="211" />
<p style="text-align: center;"></p>
The Community Producers come from some of the most disadvantaged backgrounds. They used to be boxmakers, rickshaw drivers, diamond polishers, farm laborers, housewives and students. Today, they are film producers are selected by the field workers of the NGO that is starting the CVU.

Fieldworkerswill spread the word in the villages where the CVU will work, by telling all their local contacts in the village that a new job is being offered and when the interview dates are. Sometimes, up to 100 people will come for the interview.

Producers dont need literacy or any experience. Rather, we look for a 'spark', personality, confidence and, most importantly, a commitment to social change. All these Community Producers have these qualities in spades, as you will see while watching some of the videos they have scripted themselves.

<img class="alignleft" style="margin: 7px;" src="http://farm4.static.flickr.com/3331/4626314882_67026265c4.jpg" alt="" width="250" height="200" />
<strong>Click below to view the details of some of the Community Producers that are working with our partner NGOs.</strong>

Akshara:<a href="http://www.cvufilms.videovolunteers.org/?cat=5&amp;phpMyAdmin=riNM8aFtCzUE-tSIv%2CFODZaOix0" target="_blank"> Apna TV - "Our TV"</a>
ICICI Prudential Insurance: <a href="http://www.cvufilms.videovolunteers.org/?custom_f[]=&amp;custom_f[]=&amp;custom_f[]=+Jawa&amp;s_real=&amp;search_field=3_CVU&amp;s=trigger_the_search&amp;cat=3" target="_blank">Jawa - "Proud"</a>
Laya: <a href="http://www.cvufilms.videovolunteers.org/?cat=10&amp;phpMyAdmin=riNM8aFtCzUE-tSIv%2CFODZaOix0" target="_blank">Manyam Praja - "Forest Peoples' Video"</a>
Navsarjan: <a href="http://www.cvufilms.videovolunteers.org/?cat=9&amp;phpMyAdmin=riNM8aFtCzUE-tSIv%2CFODZaOix0" target="_blank">Apnaa Malak Maa - "In Our Land"</a>
Saath: <a href="http://www.cvufilms.videovolunteers.org/?cat=6&amp;phpMyAdmin=riNM8aFtCzUE-tSIv%2CFODZaOix0" target="_blank">Samvad - "Dialog"</a>
Yuva: <a href="http://www.cvufilms.videovolunteers.org/?cat=8&amp;phpMyAdmin=riNM8aFtCzUE-tSIv%2CFODZaOix0" target="_blank">Hamari Aawaz - "Our Voice"</a>
Yuvashakti:<a href="http://www.cvufilms.videovolunteers.org/?cat=7&amp;phpMyAdmin=riNM8aFtCzUE-tSIv%2CFODZaOix0" target="_blank"> Sakshi Media - "Witness Media"</a>

<strong>
</strong>
<div><strong><a href="http://www.cvufilms.videovolunteers.org" target="_blank">CLICK HERE </a>to watch all the videos made by these Community Video Unit producers!</strong></div>
<div><strong>
</strong></div>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Videoactive Girls </title>
		<link>http://www.videovolunteers.org/programmes/global-fund-for-children/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 14 May 2010 10:23:03 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>nladmin</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.videovolunteers.org/?page_id=1149</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h1>Videoactive Girls</h1>
<div id="_mcePaste">

<strong><em> </em></strong>

<strong><em> </em></strong>

<strong><em> </em></strong>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span style="font-family: Georgia, serif;"><strong><em> </em></strong></span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal"><strong><em><strong><em><span style="font-family: &amp;amp;amp; color: black;">Project for the Global Fund for Children</span></em></strong></em></strong></p>
<p class="MsoNormal"><strong><em><strong><em><span style="font-family: &amp;amp;amp; color: black;"><a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/05/Vactiv.jpg"><img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-2201" title="Vactiv" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/05/Vactiv.jpg" alt="" width="634" height="450" /></a>
</span></em></strong></em></strong></p>
<strong><em> </em></strong><strong><em> </em></strong><strong><em> </em></strong>

</div>
<div><strong>In the year 2009, Video Volunteers partnered with Global Fund for Children(GFC) in a pilot project called Videoactive Girls. Under the project, which was a learning initiative of The Nike Foundations Brain Trust of Practitioners, VV developed a toolkit on how community-based organizations and the adolescent girls they serve can harness, produce and use the power of the visual media to amplify their voices and tell their stories</strong>.</div>
<img class="alignleft" style="margin: 10px 20px;" src="http://farm3.static.flickr.com/2392/4513962210_7072e408f9_m.jpg" alt="" hspace="6" vspace="6" width="240" height="180" align="right" />The training imparted by Video Volunteers to the young girls      was focused on these three factors:
<ul>
	<li>How to learn the art of digital      storytelling.</li>
	<li>Developing video production and      video-sharing skills.</li>
	<li>How to instill and cultivate      greater self confidence and self-empowerment in each participant through      the learning process.</li>
</ul>
The project was located in two places: Kolkata where the girls trained came from a local NGO called Sanved and in Hyderabad where the participants were associated with the NGO Mahita.

In both cases the girls had come from a difficult socio-economic background and had experienced several personal tragedies and traumas. It was a tough challenge for the Video Volunteers trainer to train these girls the intricacies of video production and prepare them to venture outdoor with cameras and shoot news videos.

However, a specially designed training module was capable of helping restore the girlss self -confidence. So,despite the difficult situations and challenges, these girls made several videos on issues like child marriage, gender bias, the problems of working women, etc. At the completion of the project the participants said, Our fear is gone now!

<img class="alignleft" style="margin: 5px;" src="http://farm3.static.flickr.com/2178/4513315771_5c58ca92c3_m.jpg" alt="" width="180" height="240" />The project at Kolkatta Sanved, which involved formerly trafficked girls, Video Volunteers developed youth media models specifically targeting the needs of underprivileged girls in the developing world. Through Video Volunteers training and the use of video, the girls learned self-expression.

<strong><a href="http://www.projectinggirlpower.org/?p=1452" target="_blank">GFC Project Toolkit </a></strong>

Video Volunteers has also created a toolkit for the Girl Powered Video project, which will be distributed widely this year by the Global Fund for Children and the Nike Foundation-the two organizations promoting the GFC program. The toolkit includes videos, training guides, and documentation of lessons learned from the entire project.We hope this will benefit other organizations in future andinspire the creation of many other youth media projects. To read and download the toolkit, <a href="http://www.projectinggirlpower.org/?p=1452" target="_blank"><strong>click here.</strong></a>

<a href="http://www.cvufilms.videovolunteers.org/?custom_f[]=&amp;custom_f[]=+Global+Fund+For+Children&amp;custom_f[]=&amp;s_real=&amp;search_field=9_NGO/Sponsor&amp;s=trigger_the_search&amp;cat=3" target="_blank"><strong>To watch the films made by the video active girls trained by Video Volunteers, click here.</strong></a>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>1149</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2010-05-14 03:23:03</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2010-05-14 10:23:03</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>closed</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>closed</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>global-fund-for-children</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>publish</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>1146</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>7</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type>page</wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>Sustainable Community Media Research Program</title>
		<link>http://www.videovolunteers.org/programmes/videos-for-livelihood/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 14 May 2010 10:23:49 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>nladmin</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.videovolunteers.org/?page_id=1150</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h1>Sustainable Community Media Research Program</h1>
<strong>Video Volunteers, in collaboration with Indian Institute of Management (IIM), Ahmedabad - the most prestigious business school in India, has undertaken a project to meet the biggest challenge for community video units (CVUs) - Financial Sustainability.</strong>

<img class="alignleft" style="margin: 7px;" src="http://farm2.static.flickr.com/1179/1325311257_4e473d8d42.jpg" alt="" hspace="5" vspace="5" width="300" height="172" />
<strong></strong>
Under the project, IIM's Center for Innovation, Incubation and Entrepreneurship or CIIE and Video Volunteers are working together to create business models, explore methods and design plans to help community media reach high levels of sustainability. Once devised, the self-sustainable model will be implemented on experimental basis nationwide.
<strong>
</strong>

The project also aims to explore the possibility of generating revenue through the mainstream media and via collaborations with other NGOs. Another area that the projects aims to explore is how such community video businesses can be supported by micro credit lending.

Financial sustainability will mean the CVU will no longer be dependent on outside funders. This, in turn, will minimize outside influence in editorial content. Solid financial status will also enable CVUs to expand. For instance, a CVU with significant revenue can take on new producers, start community radio programs or get new equipments.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>1150</wp:post_id>

		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>videos-for-livelihood</wp:post_name>

			<wp:comment_id>592</wp:comment_id>

		<title>Media Partnerships</title>
		<link>http://www.videovolunteers.org/about/partners/media-partnerships/</link>

		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h1>Mainstream Media Collaborations</h1>
<strong>Video Volunteers vision of empowering the poor to bring about meaningful change in their lives is not only proving to be scalable, it also creates engaging content the world has never seen. Video Volunteers has partnered with big names in the media industry like CNN, Current TV, and MTV Networks to bring interesting and unique content, produced by the marginalised, to an audience that is hungry for new perspectives, ideas and solutions.</strong>

<strong>If you are a media house curious to know how community-produced content could enhance your programming, please <a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/contact-us" target="_self">contact us</a> to discuss how we can work together. Our community network produces high quality work tailored to your needs, specifications and style. Some of our current and former partners include:</strong>
<table border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0">
