<h2 style="text-align: center;"><strong>CNN-IBN</strong></h2>
</td>
<td valign="top" width="481"></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td valign="top" width="130"><a href="http://ibnlive.in.com/" target="_blank"><img class="size-full wp-image-1310 alignleft" style="margin-top: 5px; margin-left: 30px;" title="CNN IBN" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/05/vv_mainstream4.jpg" alt="CNN-IBN" width="100" height="100" /></a></td>
<td valign="top" width="481">The Indian CNN affiliate, CNN-IBN, a leader in participatory journalism, features a program where the common person can tell his or her story. For this initiative Video Volunteers shot impact pieces where our producers developed stories including one on sexual harassment that led to the city of Mumbai creating a helpline for women who are being harassed and another on trash collection which led to trash bins being introduced to the slums of Bombay.</td>
</tr>

<tr>
<td valign="top" width="130">
<h2 style="text-align: center;">MTV Iggy</h2>
</td>
<td valign="top" width="481"></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td valign="top" width="130"><a href="http://www.mtviggy.com/kashmir" target="_blank"><img class="size-full wp-image-1309 aligncenter" style="margin-top: 5px; margin-left: 30px; margin-right: 30px;" title="MTV Iggy" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/05/vv_mainstream3.jpg" alt="" width="100" height="100" /></a></td>
<td valign="top" width="481">Video Volunteers, in partnership with MTV Iggy, brought uncensored access to Kashmiri voices from the refugee camps of Jammu and Kashmir. Kashmiri youth spoke directly of their shocking experiences: Sunil walks us through daily life in the Jammu refugee camps, Mohan explains how religious tensions led to the slaughter of his entire family, and Deepika tells us about her childhood in a refugee camp. We were pleased to partner with MTV Iggy to help raise awareness in Kashmir by including a key group in the discussion  the unheard voices of the displaced poor. As a result of this partnership, media produced by some of the worlds most disadvantaged communities was delivered to a global audience. These videos received the most views of the entire campaign, really resonating with the youth audience.</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td valign="top" width="130"></td>

<tr>
<td valign="top" width="130">
<h2 style="text-align: center;">Nickelodeon</h2>
</td>
<td valign="top" width="481"></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td valign="top" width="130"><a href="http://news.nick.com/" target="_blank"><img class="size-full wp-image-1307 alignleft" style="margin-top: 5px; margin-left: 30px;" title="Nickelodeon" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/05/vv_mainstream1.png" alt="" width="100" height="100" /></a></td>
<td valign="top" width="481">Nickelodeon collaborated with Video Volunteers on their news special, <em>The Untouchable Kids of India</em>. Here Nick News shared with American kids, Whats it like to be a Dalit kid? and offered a first-hand look into the world of the Dalits, highlighting how many are now refusing to be victims. Neeru, a Video Volunteers community video producer, discussed her efforts to educate both Dalits and non-Dalits through her films, many of which are designated controversial and banned, though it hasnt stopped her from continuing to make films. As quoted in the Nick News piece, Neeru says, When I see the work which is being done, I am proud about it. Even I can do something. I am worth something.</td>
</tr>

</td>
<td valign="top" width="481"></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td valign="top" width="130"><a href="http://www.pangeaday.org/index.php?vid=3" target="_blank"><img class="size-full wp-image-1308 alignleft" style="margin-top: 5px; margin-left: 30px;" title="Pangea Day" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/05/vv_mainstream2.jpg" alt="" width="100" height="100" /></a></td>
<td valign="top" width="481">Video Volunteers Community Producers shot cell phone videos that were broadcast all over the world via the internet, television, digital cinemas, and mobile phones as part of Pangea Day, a four hour global television broadcast, for peace and inspiration, airing from Cairo, Kigali, London, Mumbai, and Rio de Janeiro. Pangea Day donated 40 Nokia cell phones to Video Volunteers, with which the producers made videos on different universal themes such as love, friendship and hope.</td>

	<item>
		<title>Best Impact stories </title>
		<link>http://www.videovolunteers.org/impact/in-depth-impact-stories/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 14 May 2010 10:45:52 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>nladmin</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.videovolunteers.org/?page_id=1152</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h1>Impact stories From CVUs</h1>
Each film that a Community Video Unit produces, addresses a local community problem. The film is a serious effort to find the solution to that problem through community participation. Since 2006 there have been over 50 impacts that the various CVUs films have brought at local level. Some of these impacts stand out as great examples of community taking action and video activism joining hands. This page will bring you stories of those impacts from all across India.
<h3><strong>Jawa CVU, Assam. </strong></h3>
<strong>Partner: ICICI Prudential Pvt Ltd</strong>

The CVU Jawa was launched in partnership with ICICI Prudential Pvt Ltd in March'2010. The name Jawa means sprouts. It indicates the awakening of the asleep. If we look from a community angle, it also indicates the realization of the unrealised or revelation. This impact story is a reflection of this.

There are 5 community video producers in Jawa. One of them is Bipson. Bipson grew up in the tea garden where alcoholism and lack of education are two big challenges before his community. These two problems are also interlinked. Men become alcoholics and spend all their earnings on buying drinks. So their children do not go to school as there is no money to send a child to go to school.

Bipson's father was also an alcoholic for years. This created a lot of trouble in his family. As a result, Bipson had a tough childhood.

But in June this year, when JAWA CVU - of which he is a part - started producing videos, the team made several small 2 min videos for public awareness as a part of the team's training. One of them was on alcoholism and it's dangers. When Bipson was shooting this video, he discussed the video with his father. Soon, his father gave up drinking.
<h3><strong>CVU: Apna Malak Ma, Gujarat</strong></h3>
<strong>Partner: Navsarjan</strong>

Here is one such impact from the CVU Apna Malak Maa in Gujarat, launched in partnership with the NGO.

In  2008-2009, CVU Apna Malak Maa screened 3 films in 42 villages under Limdee  Taluka of Gujarats Surendrednagar district. Following the screening, women in  seven villages decided to collectively fight for their basic rights such as  water and sanitation. As a result seven villages saw formation of a special  womens group called Mahila Panch. The Villages are Chaurania, Chowki,  Siyani, Bhojpora, Ratorki, Nana Shahpura, Parali.

In Feb2010, all the members  of the mahila panch in Nana Shahpur village organized a sit-in protest at the  district collectors office. A month later, on March 15th , district  administration released a grant of Rs 7 lakh to provide water to 150 families.  The village also got toilets for 25 families while 20 more are expecting it  soon.
<h3><strong>CVU: SAMVAD</strong></h3>
<strong>Partner NGO: Saath</strong>

<strong>State: Gujarat</strong>

<strong>Video:Chokdi (Anti-tobacco addiction video), 2010</strong>

<strong>Impact: <span style="font-weight: normal;">The Chief Health Officer, Ahemedabad watched this video and found it so informative, he ordered a screening of this film in each of the 40 primary and middle schools run by the state government of Gujarat in the city. For each screening, the CVU was paid Rs 500. Through these screens, over five thousand students learnt of tobacco addiction and how it affects human health. </span> </strong>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Web, TV and Radio</title>
		<link>http://www.videovolunteers.org/media-collaborations/press-and-resources/web-articles/</link>

In this episode we look at some of these unusual filmmakers - their stories as well as the stories they tell.</span></span></span></td>

Countless people have to live in degrading conditions, children are unable to go to school, employment avenues are closed, and even education does not open bigoted minds. <a href="http://www.satyamevjayate.in/issue10/">Click here to watch</a>.</span></span></td>

They need public awareness campaigns to end untouchability in same way that government campaigns have been successful at raising awareness about other things, like family planning and domestic violence.</span></span></td>

Community Video makes it possible for their voices to be included."</span></span></td>

</tr>
<tr>
<td align="right" valign="middle"><a style="line-height: 19px;" href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/05/afp_logo.gif"><span style="color: #333333; font-family: Georgia, 'Times New Roman', 'Bitstream Charter', Times, serif; font-size: small;"><img class="alignleft size-full wp-image-2650" title="afp_logo" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/05/afp_logo.gif" alt="" width="74" height="40" /></span></a></td>

</tr>
<tr>
<td align="right" valign="middle"><a style="line-height: 19px;" href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/05/download-12.jpg"><span style="color: #333333; font-family: Georgia, 'Times New Roman', 'Bitstream Charter', Times, serif; font-size: small;"><img class="alignleft size-full wp-image-2649" title="download (12)" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/05/download-12.jpg" alt="" width="150" height="41" /></span></a></td>
<td align="left" valign="middle"><span style="color: #333333; font-family: Georgia, 'Times New Roman', 'Bitstream Charter', Times, serif; font-size: small;"><span style="line-height: 19px;"><a href="http://www.unimondo.org/Notizie/Giornalismo-dal-basso-voci-dall-India-inascoltata-133124">Journalism From Below: Unheard Voices in India</a>Dotare, entro cinque anni, ciascuno degli oltre seicento distretti dellIndia di unreporter di comunit, in grado di portare allo scoperto le questioni reputate pi importanti dalla gente del posto e facilitare in questo modo un processo capillare di cambiamento dal basso. E lambizioso obiettivo delliniziativa di giornalismo partecipativo<a href="http://indiaunheard.videovolunteers.org/abut/" target="_blank">IndiaUnheard</a>(IU), che oggi, dopo due anni di rodaggio, conta su quarantotto corrispondenti dislocati in ventiquattro Stati.</span></span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td align="right" valign="middle"><a style="line-height: 19px;" href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/05/TakePart_logo_.jpg"><span style="color: #333333; font-family: Georgia, 'Times New Roman', 'Bitstream Charter', Times, serif; font-size: small;"><img class="alignleft size-full wp-image-2412" title="TakePart_logo_" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/05/TakePart_logo_.jpg" alt="" width="80" height="80" /></span></a></td>
<td align="left" valign="middle"><span style="color: #333333; font-family: Georgia, 'Times New Roman', 'Bitstream Charter', Times, serif; font-size: small;"><span style="line-height: 19px;"><a href="http://www.takepart.com/article/2011/10/24/video-volunteers">Video Volunteers: India's Newest Journalists shed light on Hunger</a>For one, community people have access that outside professionals don't. Even the best documentary filmmakers can often only spend a short period of time in a community. By contrast, a community member lives there all the time and has incredible knowledge and access that an outsider doesn't, no matter how sensitive that outsider is.</span></span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td align="right" valign="middle"><a style="line-height: 19px;" href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/05/images.jpg"><span style="color: #333333; font-family: Georgia, 'Times New Roman', 'Bitstream Charter', Times, serif; font-size: small;"><img class="alignleft size-thumbnail wp-image-2226" title="images" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/05/images-150x150.jpg" alt="" width="80" height="80" /></span></a></td>
<td align="left" valign="middle"><span style="color: #333333; font-family: Georgia, 'Times New Roman', 'Bitstream Charter', Times, serif; font-size: small;"><span style="line-height: 19px;"><a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/press-and-resources/web-articles">Shaping in Action: Jessica Mayberry, Video Star</a>She spent nine months training rural women in the art of film-making. "I remember writing in my journal," What if this is the beginning of a new direction in my life?," recalls the 33 year old Native New Yorker," What if I fall in love with India and stay forever?"</span></span>
<h2><span style="font-weight: normal;"><span style="color: #333333; font-family: Georgia, 'Times New Roman', 'Bitstream Charter', Times, serif; font-size: small;">

<td align="left" valign="middle"><span style="color: #333333; font-family: Georgia, 'Times New Roman', 'Bitstream Charter', Times, serif; font-size: small;"><span style="line-height: 19px;"></span></span></td>

<td align="right" valign="middle"><a style="line-height: 19px;" href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/05/kf-logo-for-twitter_144px_bigger.jpg"><span style="color: #333333; font-family: Georgia, 'Times New Roman', 'Bitstream Charter', Times, serif; font-size: small;"><img class="alignleft size-full wp-image-2212" title="kf-logo-for-twitter_144px_bigger" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/05/kf-logo-for-twitter_144px_bigger.jpg" alt="" width="73" height="73" /></span></a></td>
<td align="left" valign="middle"><span style="color: #333333; font-family: Georgia, 'Times New Roman', 'Bitstream Charter', Times, serif; font-size: small;"><span style="line-height: 19px;"><a href="http://www.knightfoundation.org/blogs/knightblog/2011/8/9/4-insights-and-4-lessons-knight-news-challenge/">4Insights and 4 Lessons:Knight News Challenge</a>"For projects that rely on user-generated content, training can be a powerful tool for getting more people involved. The trainees enjoy the skill development, and it often inspires them to stick with the project. For example,<a href="http://mediamobilizing.org/">Media Mobilizing Project</a> and<a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/">Video Volunteers</a>, two citizen media efforts, effectively used training in Philadelphia and India to build relationships with the community and ensure people had the skills to produce content."</span></span></td>
</tr>

<td align="right" valign="middle"><a style="line-height: 19px;" href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/05/DINESH2.jpg" target="_blank"><span style="color: #333333; font-family: Georgia, 'Times New Roman', 'Bitstream Charter', Times, serif; font-size: small;"><img class="alignleft size-full wp-image-1817" title="DINESH2" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/05/DINESH2.jpg" alt="" width="100" height="100" /></span></a></td>
<td align="left" valign="middle"><span style="color: #333333; font-family: Georgia, 'Times New Roman', 'Bitstream Charter', Times, serif; font-size: small;"><span style="line-height: 19px;"><a href="http://simplwrds.wordpress.com/2011/01/10/what-if-the-poorest-half-a-billion-people-of-india-has-their-voice-it%E2%80%99s-possible-by-innovative-journalism/" target="_blank">"simplwrds" blog by Media Researcher Dinesh Kumar, January 2011: What if the poorest half a billion people of India has their voice - its possible by innovative journalism</a>"IndiaUnheard is the first ever community news service launched by VV. In this initiative, VV trains some volunteers from poor communities in India as community reporters. These reporters are trained with basic journalistic skills, and media training including the video training."</span></span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td align="right" valign="middle"><a style="line-height: 19px;" href="http://blog.samhita.org/2010/09/video-volunteers-telling-untold.html" target="_blank"><span style="color: #333333; font-family: Georgia, 'Times New Roman', 'Bitstream Charter', Times, serif; font-size: small;"><img class="size-thumbnail wp-image-1491 alignnone" title="Samhita" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/05/Samhita1-150x85.gif" alt="" width="100" height="100" /></span></a></td>

</tr>
<tr>
<td align="right" valign="middle"><a style="line-height: 19px;" href="http://thehoot.org/web/home/story.php?storyid=4594&amp;mod=1&amp;pg=1&amp;sectionId=3&amp;valid=true" target="_blank"><span style="color: #333333; font-family: Georgia, 'Times New Roman', 'Bitstream Charter', Times, serif; font-size: small;"><img src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/06/WA_thehoot.gif" alt="" width="100" height="100" border="0" /></span></a></td>
<td align="left" valign="middle"><span style="color: #333333; font-family: Georgia, 'Times New Roman', 'Bitstream Charter', Times, serif; font-size: small;"><span style="line-height: 19px;"><a href="http://thehoot.org/web/home/story.php?storyid=4594&amp;mod=1&amp;pg=1&amp;sectionId=3&amp;valid=true" target="_blank">The Hoot, June 2010: Community Media - Varsha breaks the silence</a>"Hi, I am Varsha. Three days after I was married, my husband beat me unconscious." Not a conventional opening line -- but then, Varsha is not a conventional reporter."</span></span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td align="right" valign="middle"><a style="line-height: 19px;" href="http://www.stanford.edu/group/sdg/cgi-bin/dev/liber/?q=node/373" target="_blank"><span style="color: #333333; font-family: Georgia, 'Times New Roman', 'Bitstream Charter', Times, serif; font-size: small;"><img src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/06/WA_stanford.png" alt="" width="100" height="100" border="0" /></span></a></td>
<td align="left" valign="middle"><span style="color: #333333; font-family: Georgia, 'Times New Roman', 'Bitstream Charter', Times, serif; font-size: small;"><span style="line-height: 19px;"><a href="http://www.stanford.edu/group/sdg/cgi-bin/dev/liber/?q=node/373" target="_blank">Stanford University, May 2010: India Unheard: Video Journalism for Marginalized</a>"Video Volunteers has launched a network of community journalists in India, each trained to tell their own stories in the form of video journalism. IndiaUnheard is the first-ever nationwide community video news service of its kind."</span></span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td align="right" valign="middle"><a style="line-height: 19px;" href="http://globalvoicesonline.org/2010/05/29/india-video-giving-a-voice-to-marginalised-communities/" target="_blank"><span style="color: #333333; font-family: Georgia, 'Times New Roman', 'Bitstream Charter', Times, serif; font-size: small;"><img src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/06/WA_globalvoice.gif" alt="" width="100" height="100" border="0" /></span></a></td>

<tr>

The country is launching the first community news service that will empower locals, as well as bridge the gap between production and distribution.</span></span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td align="right" valign="middle"><a style="line-height: 19px;" href="http://mizoramexpress.com/index.php/2010/05/christy-raj-meet-indias-first-trans-gender-journalist/" target="_blank"><span style="color: #333333; font-family: Georgia, 'Times New Roman', 'Bitstream Charter', Times, serif; font-size: small;"><img src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/06/WA_mizoram.gif" alt="" width="100" height="100" border="0" /></span></a></td>

I have no ration card and no photo identity. Because I am neither male nor female. Official forms here do not have a clause for other gender. I dont get to apply for anything. And so, I dont get anything, says Christy.</span></span></td>
</tr>
<tr>

<tr>
<td align="right" valign="middle"><a style="line-height: 19px;" href="http://thehoot.org/web/home/story.php?storyid=4531&amp;pg=1&amp;mod=1&amp;sectionId=3&amp;valid=true" target="_blank"><span style="color: #333333; font-family: Georgia, 'Times New Roman', 'Bitstream Charter', Times, serif; font-size: small;"><img src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/06/WA_thehoot.gif" alt="" width="100" height="100" border="0" /></span></a></td>

	<item>
		<title>Videoshala</title>
		<link>http://www.videovolunteers.org/programmes/videoshala/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 19 May 2010 11:35:39 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>laina</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.videovolunteers.org/?page_id=1170</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h1>Videoshala</h1>
<img class="alignleft" style="margin: 5px;" src="http://farm3.static.flickr.com/2166/4513427985_40ecdfabdc.jpg" alt="" hspace="5" vspace="5" width="200" height="200" align="left" />
<div id="_mcePaste">

<strong>Videoshala is a unique and innovative program that trains community members to produce educational videos. It combines a powerful visual medium with a strong pedagogy to address Hard Spots in the curriculum, while simultaneously incorporating the values of democracy, diversity and citizenship in the video kits. Locally trained producers from community produce educational videos and screen them in schools.</strong><span style="font-family: &amp;amp;amp; mso-bidi-font-family: &amp;amp;amp; color: black; mso-bidi-language: AR-SA;"> </span>

Research in education has shown that despite having sufficient number of teachers and a good infrastructure, schools around the country have been witnessing increasing rate of dropouts and low learning levels among students. Videoshala was developed as an attempt to tackle these problems.

Videoshala was started in 2007 as a joint project by Video Volunteers and two Gujarat-based NGOs, Drishti and Udaan. There are four Educational Community Video Units (E-CVUs) in Gujarat run by four different NGOs. These are Udaan-Meghdhanush, Sahyog, Hind Swaraj Mandal and Navsarjan. The E-CVUs also have, as supporting partners, USAID, Quest Alliance and International Youth Foundation.

Each of the ECVUs has a team of a trainer, coordinator, producers and classroom facilitators. Producers of each team are trained in video production, pedagogy and childrens unique learning needs, to produce the films which accompany elements of the curriculum children find challenging.

So far, 24 videos have been produced about various topics, including plants, democracy, religions and nutrition.While each ECVU chooses its own topics for its videos, nonetheless each video is based on the key pedagogical strategies:
<ul type="disc">
	<li>to approach the hard spots chosen from the lens of the values of inclusion and diversity</li>
	<li>to target a dual audience of students and teachers</li>
	<li>to make learning entertaining, interesting and fun</li>
	<li>to model instructional guidance for teachers by demonstrating examples of teaching methods</li>
</ul>
<img class="alignleft" style="margin: 10px 7px;" title="VIDEOSHALA" src="http://farm3.static.flickr.com/2277/4513425027_3e55d9e04c_m.jpg" alt="" width="240" height="160" />
Each of these Videoshala films is seen through the prism of citizenship, diversity and democracy. After completing the video, the Producers develop workbooks and games to accompany it. The films are screened to children in 200 schools throughout the state. Teachers have reported that children are now more engaged and have more fun in the classroom as a result of the program.

</div>
<strong><a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/05/videoshala-new-01-screen.pdf" target="_blank">Click Here to Know more of Videoshala.</a></strong>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>1170</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2010-05-19 04:35:39</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2010-05-19 11:35:39</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>videoshala</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>publish</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>1146</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>6</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type>page</wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password></wp:post_password>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>Community Radio</title>
		<link>http://www.videovolunteers.org/programmes/community-radio/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 19 May 2010 11:45:34 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>laina</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.videovolunteers.org/?page_id=1172</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h1>Community Radio</h1>
<strong>
</strong>
<h2>Community Radio Forum</h2>
<img class="alignleft" style="margin: 5px;" title="Stalin, crf" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/05/Stalin-crf-300x225.jpg" alt="" width="240" height="172" /><strong> </strong>
Video Volunteers was the secretariat of the <a href="http://www.crforum.in/" target="_blank">Community Radio Forum (CRF)</a> from September 2008 to February 2010, and Stalin K, the Managing Trustee of Video Volunteers, is the former Convener of the forum. He was instrumental in the lobbying efforts, which led to the passage of the community radio broadcasting bill legalizing community radio for the first time in India. He was part of a team that drafted much of the new Community Radio Policy in operation today.
<strong>
</strong>
The Community Radio Forum-India is a registered association of community radio broadcasters, researchers and advocates in India. CRF members have played a significant role in shaping and drafting the new community radio policy currently in place. CRF believes in the power of community radio, is committed to democratization of Indias airwaves and works to enable community organizations to set up their own Community Radio Station. The CRF, being a membership-based organization, is the only representative body of community radio practitioners in India.
<h2><strong>Community Radio Training</strong></h2>
<img class="alignleft" style="margin: 5px;" src="http://blog.indicorps.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/04/pooj-project1-300x225.jpg" alt="" width="240" height="158" />
<strong> </strong>

Our Managing Trustee, Stalin K., has been involved in <a href="http://stalink.wordpress.com/community-radio/" target="_blank">designing, training and producing</a> some of the most successful community radio programs in India. He also helped to setup two of the earliest community radio stations in the country<a href="http://www.indiatogether.org/stories/awardkutch.htm">KMVS</a> and Dang.

Video Volunteers is designing the strategy for <a href="http://www.shramikbharti.org.in/">Shramik Bharti</a>, an NGO in Kanpur, Uttar Pradesh, which is setting up community radio programs and training 20 people.
<strong>
</strong>
<strong> </strong>
<strong>If you are an NGO, with a plan to set up a community radio station and looking for collaboration and partnership opportunities, please write to us about your current work and a sketch of your plan at: </strong> <strong><em>info@videovolunteers.org</em></strong>.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>1172</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2010-05-19 04:45:34</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2010-05-19 11:45:34</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>community-radio</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>publish</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>1146</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>4</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type>page</wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_edit_last</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[1]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>IndiaUnheard</title>
		<link>http://www.videovolunteers.org/programmes/indiaunheard/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 19 May 2010 12:46:58 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>laina</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.videovolunteers.org/?page_id=1174</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h1 style="text-align: left;">IndiaUnheard: Video Volunteers' Community News Service</h1>
IndiaUnheard is the first ever community news service launched by Video Volunteers. This new initiative is constituted of a network of community correspondents who are trained to tell unique stories; stories about their own communities; stories which are otherwise left untold. By feeding this community-produced content to national and international outlets, such as mainstream television channels and social networking sites, IndiaUnheard links rural communities with a truly global audience. Through bridging these worlds, IndiaUnheard empowers communities to create real change on real issues affecting their lives.

<object width="600" height="366" classid="clsid:d27cdb6e-ae6d-11cf-96b8-444553540000" codebase="http://download.macromedia.com/pub/shockwave/cabs/flash/swflash.cab#version=6,0,40,0"><param name="src" value="http://blip.tv/play/h7EVgseTUwA" /><param name="wmode" value="transparent" /><param name="allowfullscreen" value="true" /><embed width="600" height="366" type="application/x-shockwave-flash" src="http://blip.tv/play/h7EVgseTUwA" wmode="transparent" allowfullscreen="true" /></object>

<strong>The Network</strong>

<a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/05/CC1.jpg"><img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-1414" style="margin: 5px;" title="CC1" alt="" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/05/CC1-300x209.jpg" width="240" height="180" /></a>IndiaUnheard is comprised of a network of 45 Community Correspondents (CCs) spread across 27 Indian states. These Community Correspondents represent Indias most marginalized perspectives, including Dalits and tribal people, as well as religious, lingual and sexual minorities. They are trained in all manner of documentation, compelling storytelling and video journalism. They are also well versed in using social media as a reporting tool. The powerful combination of these new media approachesvideo journalism, SMS reporting and social media networking allows them to engage with both the national and international audience in a truly innovative way.

Through IndiaUnheard, Video Volunteers offers the global audience a clear window into the real India. Every day, video reports on key issues such as caste, conflict, identity and education are gathered from across the country. Imagine a situation where a tribal woman reports on how displacement is affecting childrens right to education in the Northeast, or a Dalit man discusses Dalit political representation in local elections and government. Not only does IndiaUnheard provide critical insights into these underreported perspectives, it does so on a national scale, making it the first program of its kind.<strong> </strong>

<strong>Distribution</strong>

<strong> </strong><a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/05/cc2.jpg"><img class="alignleft size-medium wp-image-1415" style="margin: 5px;" title="cc2" alt="" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/05/cc2-300x225.jpg" width="240" height="180" /></a>IndiaUnheard video reports are available online and in January 2011 VV launched a 30-minute, weekly news program with News X, an English-language television channel in India. There are many 'firsts' to celebrate here -- the first time a news station is recognizing the poor as legitimate news producers; the first time the poor are being paid for their news reports by a TV station; and, most importantly, the first time these communities will voice their issues directly to a national audience.

The reports are featured on the IndiaUnheard web-series, where viewers watch videos by issue and learn how to take action. Viewers are also able to share their thoughts on the videos produced and even submit ideas for future stories. The videos are also distributed through social media sites such as Facebook, Youtube, Twitter and Blip TV. This enables community voices to be heard on a new, wider scale which, in turn, leads to a greater impact. Video Volunteers is currently building partnerships with nonprofits, social movements and international organizations to continue this process of leveraging content onto a global scale. We are also utilizing our pan-India network of Community Correspondents to partner with NGOs to build innovative and dynamic campaigns on issues ranging from climate change to gender equality. Read more <a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/programmes/indiaunheard/create-an-issue-based-campaign-with-indiaunheard">here</a>.

<strong>The Purpose</strong>

India is the worlds largest democracy; however, policies are often put in place without this information flowing to the poor majority. Most people dont know their rights; one reason many laws are not enforced is because the poor are excluded from the media. Simultaneously, the government and the mainstream media cannot easily access the knowledge and perspectives of the poor; perspectives which provide a window into what is actually happening in marginalized communities in India. If information flowed upwards, we could better tackle issues like rural corruption or gender inequality.

<strong>Impact</strong>

<a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/05/2010-8-19_impacthealth_daniel_thumb.jpg"><img class="size-medium wp-image-1441 alignright" style="margin: 5px;" title="2010-8-19_impacthealth_daniel_thumb" alt="" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/05/2010-8-19_impacthealth_daniel_thumb-300x237.jpg" width="240" height="220" /></a>IndiaUnheard has started having direct impact on the communities in which it is made. Our videos are inspiring viewers to take action and reach out to communities to address specific problems such as lack of healthcare, livelihood opportunities and corruption in local governance.

For example, one of our Community Correspondents from Manipur made video about lack of medical facilities in a local village. A Manipuri India Unheard viewer living in Bangalore saw the film and wanted to help. Video Volunteers connected him with our Manipuri Community Correspondent  Daniel. The viewer then introduced Daniel to a local NGO and together they organized the distribution of medicines in the local area. <strong>You can watch a film about this impact story <a href="http://indiaunheard.videovolunteers.org/daniel/iu-impactvillage-gets-healthcare/" target="_blank">here</a>.</strong>

&nbsp;

<strong>To watch the IndiaUnheard video reports, <a href="http://indiaunheard.videovolunteers.org/" target="_blank">click here</a>.</strong>

<strong>To volunteer with one of the Community Correspondents, <a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/programmes/indiaunheard/volunteer-with-an-iu-correspondent/" target="_blank">click here to find details</a></strong><strong>.</strong>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Our Interns and Volunteers </title>
		<link>http://www.videovolunteers.org/about/internvolunteer/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 25 May 2010 06:24:36 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>nladmin</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.videovolunteers.org/?page_id=1294</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h1>Interns and Volunteers</h1>
<strong>At Video Volunteers, we make a real effort to find every volunteer a project that suits his/her individual skills and interests. Since 2003, more than 40 people have volunteered with Video Volunteers; each one has made an enormous contribution for which we are extremely grateful and many continue to be involved with our work today. Some of them are profiled below.</strong>
<h3>James Hotham, UK</h3>
<table border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0">
<tbody>
<tr>
<td valign="top" width="146"><a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/05/cph5.jpg"><img class="alignleft size-full wp-image-2827" title="cph5" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/05/cph5.jpg" alt="" width="150" height="100" /></a></td>
<td valign="top" width="494">
<p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0.0001pt; margin-left: 0px; text-align: justify; line-height: normal;"><span style="font-size: x-small;">JamesHothamwas born in England and moved to Hong Kong after completing his university education in the U.K (undergraduate and post-graduate degrees in psychology and organisational psychology, respectively). Influenced by the journalists he encountered in Hong Kong he began to travel and photograph in the Asia region. The lure of photography for James is in its use as a means to document the oppression of specific groups within society. In the last year James has produced a series of stories focussed on the caste system in India and the destruction of historic neighbourhoods in China (<a href="http://www.jameshotham.com/" target="_blank">www.jameshotham.com</a>). His interest in Video Volunteers is based on VVs position at the forefront of community media, as well as their skillful use of photography and video as a means to document and monitor the changes taking place within society.</span></p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td colspan="2" valign="top" width="639">
<h3>Vishnu Tenkayla, India</h3>
</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
<tbody>
<tr>
<td valign="top" width="146"><a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/05/download-3.jpg"><img class="alignleft size-full wp-image-2633" title="download (3)" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/05/download-3.jpg" alt="" width="103" height="166" /></a></td>
<td valign="top" width="494">
<p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0.0001pt; margin-left: 0px; text-align: justify; line-height: normal;"><span style="font-size: xx-small;">Vishnu is pursuing his 3<sup>rd</sup>year in chemical engineering from Ramaiah Institute, Bangalore. His interests though mostly lie in the creative fields. He has been editing short films which have traveled in the college film festival circuit. The films he has worked on have won several awards including one for the best short films in the state.</span></p>
</td>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0.0001pt; margin-left: 0px; text-align: justify; line-height: normal;"><span style="font-size: xx-small;">During her days as a Political Science student, Dixie developed an interest in documentaries centered on social issues and human rights. Since 2 years ago, she has been volunteering for a sex worker's rights group in Singapore, and has produced short films centered on this issue. Her most recent work included an art installation at The Substation, Singapore's first independent contemporary arts centre. She hopes to deepen her knowledge of film making and produce films that can inspire people to be more active in social issues.</span></p>

It was a great experience for me. It taught me a great deal about the numerous issues in India that go unnoticed."</span></em></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0.0001pt; margin-left: 0px; text-align: justify; line-height: normal;"><span style="font-size: x-small;">
</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0.0001pt; margin-left: 0px; text-align: justify; line-height: normal;"><span style="font-size: x-small;">Nikita is currently doing her postgraduate diploma in Television and Print Journalism from the World Media Academy, Delhi. In the last couple of years she has started traveling to various places and realized how much she loves it. After her graduation she aspires to be a travel writer.</span></p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td colspan="2" valign="top" width="639">
<h3>Julia Lechner, Germany</h3>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td valign="top" width="146"><a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/05/online.jpg"><img class="alignleft size-full wp-image-2561" title="online" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/05/online.jpg" alt="" width="150" height="179" /></a></td>
<td valign="top" width="494">
<p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0.0001pt; margin-left: 0px; text-align: justify; line-height: normal;"><em><span style="font-size: x-small;">"VideoVolunteers, I feel, is a leading organization in building a global network of community media as a trustworthy source of information directly from the persons concerned. Remarkable is, that the community produced contents are successfully implemented on a wide choice of media applications on a regional, national and international level. I see a high potential for further developments with the efforts of VideoVolunteers and I want to use my skills to support these efforts."</span></em></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0.0001pt; margin-left: 0px; text-align: justify; line-height: normal;"><span style="font-size: x-small;">
</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0.0001pt; margin-left: 0px; text-align: justify; line-height: normal;"><span style="font-size: x-small;">Julia Lechner has previously studied and worked in Communications and Media in London and Berlin. During her work she specialised in audiovisual contents and produced short documentaries for cultural institutions, a national television channel in Germany and DANIDA Foundation of Denmark. With the support from the German DAAD Fund she came to VideoVolunteers to pursue part of her Master degree of "Modern South- and South-east Asian studies"in India. She is very happy to work on a community media project as a volunteer for social media gaining valuable insights into the use of media as a tool of empowerment.</span></p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td colspan="2" valign="top" width="639"></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td colspan="2" valign="top" width="639">
<h3>Parthib Dutta, India</h3>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td valign="top" width="146"><a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/05/parthib.jpg"><img class="alignleft size-full wp-image-2528" title="parthib" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/05/parthib.jpg" alt="" width="150" height="200" /></a></td>
<td valign="top" width="494">
<p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0.0001pt; margin-left: 0px; text-align: justify; line-height: normal;"><em><span style="line-height: 12px;">"Particularly impressive is how the Community Correspondents fight so hard to get their voices heard through the video reports. To be in </span><span style="line-height: 12px;">touch with them has been deeply inspiring and I hope to continue doing my own films with the same ambition and humanity as they do."</span></em></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0.0001pt; margin-left: 0px; text-align: justify; line-height: normal;">.</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0.0001pt; margin-left: 0px; text-align: justify; line-height: normal;">Parthib Dutta is an aspiring filmmaker from West Bengal. He graduated from L.V.Prasad TV and Film Academy in Chennai. In his films he is particularly interested to investigate the intentions of filmmakers and how these influence the final film. In his own films he explores the construction of a film as he gives the main character of his documentary space to portray himself on camera. In the edit the personal perspective then collides with the filmmakers view to deconstruct the intentions of the filmmaker himself. At VV Parthib has been editing reports from the Community Correspondents.</p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td colspan="2" valign="top" width="639">
<h3>Janna Vogl, Germany</h3>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td valign="top" width="146"><a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/05/yana.jpg"><img class="alignleft size-thumbnail wp-image-2504" title="yana" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/05/yana-150x150.jpg" alt="" width="150" height="150" /></a></td>
<td valign="top" width="494">
<p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0.0001pt; margin-left: 0px; text-align: justify; line-height: normal;"><em>"My time at Video Volunteers was short but intense. I like the idea that everybody can participate in creating news and I often recognize how narrow-minded and biased the mainstream media is. Video Volunteers can help to change this."</em></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0.0001pt; margin-left: 0px; text-align: justify; line-height: normal;">Janna Vogl is a sociology student at University of Potsdam, Germany. She worked with women's rights organisations in Tamil Nadu and conducts research on NGOs in Goa and Tamil Nadu. She helped Video Volunteers develop a metrics system to evaluate the performance of IndiaUnheard. Janna is interested in the role of media in society and possibilities of participation in this important opportunity of voicing concerns about developments in society.</p>
</td>
</tr>

In addition to his freelance and documentary work, Gregory regularly volunteers his skills as a camera operator and editor at <a href="http://www.stonesoupfilms.org/">Stone Soup Films</a> in Washington, DC. He is a graduate of Towson University with a Bachelor's degree in Electronic Media and Film.</span> </span></p>

<h3>Tracy Wares, United States of America</h3>
</td>

I have a profound respect for what they do and the risks they take to speak out about injustices in their local communities. They are the vanguard of the future of investigative journalism and technology based social activism." </span></em></p>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span class="apple-style-span"><span style="font-size: 8.5pt; line-height: 115%; mso-bidi-font-family: Calibri; mso-bidi-theme-font: minor-latin; color: black; mso-bidi-font-style: italic;">Trac</span></span><span style="font-size: 8.5pt; line-height: 115%;">y Wares is a television and feature documentary producer from Los Angeles, CA, USA. Awarded the William J Clinton Fellowship from the American India Foundation for 10 months of service in India, she comes to Video Volunteers to share her experience in broadcast television. Having previously lived in India from 1999-2000 while pursuing her BA in Anthropology at UC Berkeley, she is excited to experience India again with fresh eyes and volunteer her skills with an organization that produces media to impact social change.</span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0.0001pt; margin-left: 0px; text-align: justify; line-height: normal;"><em><span style="color: black;">"My time at Video Volunteers has been a blast. Can't wait to immerse myself in this sphere."</span></em></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0.0001pt; margin-left: 0px; text-align: justify; line-height: normal;"><em><span style="color: black;">"P.S: Living in Goa is awesome!"</span></em></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0.0001pt; margin-left: 0px; text-align: justify; line-height: normal;"><span style="mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-bidi-font-family: Calibri; mso-bidi-theme-font: minor-latin; color: black; mso-fareast-language: EN-IN;">
</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style="line-height: normal; margin: 0px;"><span style="mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-bidi-font-family: Calibri; mso-bidi-theme-font: minor-latin; color: black; mso-fareast-language: EN-IN;">Rajyashri is from Pune, Maharashtra. After completing her Bachelor's degree in Sociology from Fergusson College, she decided to spend a year volunteering with various NGOs doing inspiring work. She loves photography and writing, and is interested in understanding the significance of media in transforming communities and mindsets. At Video Volunteers, Rajyashri writes daily articles for IndiaUnheard videos, and she also did a photo-documentation of the 3<sup>rd</sup> IndiaUnheard Training Camp.</span></p>

<td colspan="2" valign="top" width="639">
<h3>Shawna Russo, United States of America</h3>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td valign="top" width="146"><a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/05/IMG_1318.jpg"><img class="alignleft size-thumbnail wp-image-2313" title="IMG_1318" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/05/IMG_1318-150x150.jpg" alt="" width="150" height="150" /></a></td>
<td valign="top" width="494">
<p class="MsoNormal" style="mso-margin-top-alt: auto; mso-margin-bottom-alt: auto; text-align: justify; line-height: normal;"><em><span style="font-size: 9.0pt; mso-ascii-font-family: Calibri; mso-ascii-theme-font: minor-latin; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-hansi-font-family: Calibri; mso-hansi-theme-font: minor-latin; mso-bidi-font-family: Calibri; mso-bidi-theme-font: minor-latin; color: black; mso-ansi-language: EN-IN; mso-fareast-language: EN-IN;">"I have been wanting to live and work in India for a long time. As a person of Indian descent, it has been important for me to experience India on my own terms. Although this is my sixth trip to India, I have learned so much more about the country as a result of living on my own than I ever had during my previous visits. Additionally, having the opportunity to research the Naxalite insurgency while living and working here in Goa seemed like the perfect opportunity for me to accomplish several of my long-held goals." </span></em></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style="mso-margin-top-alt: auto; mso-margin-bottom-alt: auto; text-align: justify; line-height: normal;"><span style="font-size: 9.0pt; mso-ascii-font-family: Calibri; mso-ascii-theme-font: minor-latin; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-hansi-font-family: Calibri; mso-hansi-theme-font: minor-latin; mso-bidi-font-family: Calibri; mso-bidi-theme-font: minor-latin; color: black; mso-ansi-language: EN-IN; mso-fareast-language: EN-IN;">Shawna Russo graduated in 2009 from Tufts University and earned a B.A. in International Relations with a concentration in Global Conflict, Cooperation, and Justice. Shawna's main academic interest at Tufts was political violence, including terrorism, insurgency, and civil wars. At Video Volunteers, Shawna is conducting preliminary background research for a planned documentary on Naxalites in the Red Corridor of India. She is also working on expansion strategies into the Northeast and Red Corridor for VV's IndiaUnheard program. After her time in India, Shawna hopes to earn her masters in Security Studies and work in counter-terrorism policy making and analysis.</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style="mso-margin-top-alt: auto; mso-margin-bottom-alt: auto; text-align: justify; line-height: normal;"></p>
</td>
</tr>

<td colspan="2" valign="top" width="639">
<h3></h3>
<h3>Grace Anderson, United Kingdom</h3>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td valign="top" width="146"><a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/05/IMG_9914.jpg"><img class="alignleft size-thumbnail wp-image-2315" title="IMG_9914" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/05/IMG_9914-150x150.jpg" alt="" width="150" height="150" /></a></td>
<td valign="top" width="494">
<p class="MsoNormal"><em><span lang="EN-GB">"I still can't quite believe that I'm here. The more time I spend here the more excited I get about being a part of this. Everyone has been warm and incredibly helpful. Most of all, they are passionate about what they're doing. A conversation feels like a full-blown internship in its self. I am learning that self-expression is a vital aspect of social change and the responses triggered by the daily videos appears to re-affirm this. I am inspired by the bravery of the Community Producers and Correspondents." </span></em></p>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span lang="EN-GB">Grace is currently studying International Development Studies at the University of East Anglia. Throughout her undergrad, she spent 10 months in India; travelling, volunteering and attempting to learn Hindi. Last year she has participated in Creating YourWorldView, an online forum for discussions around the discourse of documentaries with the Common-Wealth Broadcasting Association and carried out training by BBC Voices in documentary making. Around studying, Grace works as a carer at a Residential home.</span></p>
</td>
</tr>

<td colspan="2" valign="top" width="639">
<h3>Tonia Crosby, United States of America</h3>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td valign="top" width="146"><a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/05/IMG_3995.jpg"><img class="aligncenter size-thumbnail wp-image-2149" title="IMG_3995" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/05/IMG_3995-150x140.jpg" alt="" width="150" height="140" /></a></td>
<td valign="top" width="494">
<p class="MsoNormal" style="font-style: italic; text-align: justify;"><em><span style="font-size: 8.5pt; mso-bidi-font-size: 12.0pt; font-family: &amp;amp; quot; mso-fareast-font-family: &amp;amp; quot; color: black; mso-fareast-language: EN-IN;" lang="EN-US">"Video Volunteers is an organization that represents my world view. I am thrilled to have an opportunity to explore community media and grassroots movement for change. Agency and voice are imperative and VV is making that possible. I look forward to taking what I learn here and applying it to my work in the future."</span></em></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify;"><span style="font-size: 8.5pt; font-family: Georgia, serif; color: black;">Tonia is completing her Master of Arts at the University of San Diego's Joan B. Kroc School of Peace Studies and writing her thesis on the power of community media to generate agency and voice for marginalized populations. She is the founder of a start-up non-profit called the Urban Expression Project, which aims to engage youth with social justice knowledge through creative expression and digital media networking. She is an aspiring filmmaker and is in the process of creating a film about grassroots peace work in the Denver Hip Hop community. She is an activist, an outdoor athlete and an avid traveller.</span><em></em></p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td colspan="2" valign="top" width="639">
<h3>Jackie Sawiris, Jordan</h3>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td valign="top" width="146"><a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/05/jack.jpg"><img class="alignleft size-thumbnail wp-image-2332" title="jack" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/05/jack-150x150.jpg" alt="" width="150" height="150" /></a></td>
<td valign="top" width="494">
<p class="MsoNormal" style="font-style: italic; text-align: justify;"><em><span style="font-size: 8.5pt; mso-bidi-font-size: 12.0pt; font-family: &amp;quot; georgia&amp;quot;,&amp;quot;serif&amp;quot;; mso-fareast-font-family: &amp;quot; times new roman&amp;quot;; color: black; mso-fareast-language: EN-IN;" lang="EN-US">"Birthday promise to self: arrive in favourite place in the world in time for sunset on my birthday. So I returned for the sixth </span></em><em></em><em><span style="font-size: 8.5pt; mso-bidi-font-size: 12.0pt; font-family: &amp;quot; georgia&amp;quot;,&amp;quot;serif&amp;quot;; mso-fareast-font-family: &amp;quot; times new roman&amp;quot;; color: black; mso-fareast-language: EN-IN;" lang="EN-US">time to India, headed straight to Goa, and was early enough to catch sunrise as well. I arrived with a few things I wanted to do, including volunteering at that magical somewhere which turned out to be Video Volunteers. It's been a great exchange so far  of skills, information, creativity, food, stories, laughs, music, movies, positive provocation, and how to survive the heat by sticking your head in the freezer for 30 seconds, man and I can't wait to see what else is out there in the VV world."</span></em></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify;"><span style="font-size: 8.5pt; font-family: Georgia, serif; color: black;" lang="EN-GB">Jackie Sawiris is a half Jordanian, half Egyptian, Libyan-born, American-raised, Jordan-based writer, filmmaker, and actor. She discovered how truly powerful film can be when she initiated objecDEFY Harassment, an </span><span style="font-size: 8.5pt; font-family: Georgia, serif; color: black;">Arab world-based, self-perpetuating initiative that empowers people of all gender identities to combat harassment and regain agency over their bodies and spaces. She volunteered her copywriting/editing skills at Video Volunteers in exchange for learning how to make the perfect cup of chai  and ended up with a whole lot more.</span><em></em></p>
</td>
</tr>

<td valign="top" width="494">
<div style="text-align: justify;">
<p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; display: inline !important;"><em><span style="font-size: 8.5pt; mso-bidi-font-size: 12.0pt; font-family: &amp;amp; amp; mso-fareast-font-family: &amp;amp; amp; color: black; mso-ansi-language: EN-IN; mso-fareast-language: EN-IN;">"I have always been interested in media and dreamt of travelling to India. She's passionate about media, information and journalism. She's especially keen on citizens and alternative media and their role in development and social changes. During her time at Video Volunteers' Goa office, Elsa has been working on strengthening Video Volunteers' presence on various social media platforms.</span>

<tr>
<td colspan="2" valign="top" width="639">
<h3 style="text-align: left;">Kamini Menon, Kenya</h3>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td valign="top" width="146">
<p style="text-align: center;"><img class="aligncenter" style="font-weight: bold;" title="KAMINI3" src="../wp-content/uploads/2010/05/KAMINI3-150x150.jpg" alt="" width="126" height="140" /></p>
</td>
<td valign="top" width="494">
<p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify;"><em><span style="font-size: 8.5pt; mso-bidi-font-size: 12.0pt; font-family: &amp;amp; quot; mso-fareast-font-family: &amp;amp; quot; color: black; mso-ansi-language: EN-IN; mso-fareast-language: EN-IN;">"Video Volunteers amalgamates my professional qualifications and a deep-seated desire for social change. Their IndiaUnheard program is a revolutionary concept and I feel honoured to be a part of it."</span></em></p>
&nbsp;
<p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; display: inline !important;"><span style="font-size: 8.5pt; font-family: Georgia, serif; color: black;">Kamini Menon grew up in Nairobi, Kenya. A post graduate in Corporate Communications, Kamini is passionate about editing. Whilst volunteering in Goa, she edited video reports for IndiaUnhearda program she finds truly fascinating. The videos, covering previously unheard issues, are helping her discover the real India.</span></p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="text-align: right;" colspan="2" valign="top" width="639">
<h3 style="text-align: left;">Huge Ma, United States of America</h3>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td valign="top" width="146"><img class="aligncenter" style="font-weight: bold;" title="intern_huge_ma" src="../wp-content/uploads/2010/05/intern_huge_ma-120x150.jpg" alt="" width="120" height="140" /></td>
<td valign="top" width="494">
<p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify;"><em><span style="font-size: 8.5pt; mso-bidi-font-size: 12.0pt; font-family: &amp;amp; quot; mso-fareast-font-family: &amp;amp; quot; color: black; mso-ansi-language: EN-IN; mso-fareast-language: EN-IN;">"An internship at Video Volunteers is not something I'd call an 'internship.' It's really more of a life experiencethere's nothing I can think of that's quite like it."</span></em></p>
&nbsp;
<p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; display: inline !important;"><span style="font-size: 8.5pt; font-family: Georgia, serif; color: black;">Huge Ma is a senior at the University of Pennsylvania majoring in Economics and minoring in International Relations. He spent the summer of 2010 at Video Volunteers, not only broadening his global perspectives, but developing a greater understanding of social entrepreneurship. At Video Volunteers, he researched mainstream Indian media trends as well as exploring new marketing strategies for Video Volunteers Community News Service 'IndiaUnheard'.</span></p>
</td>
</tr>

<td colspan="2" valign="top" width="639">

<td valign="top" width="494">
<p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify;"><em><span style="font-size: 8.5pt; mso-bidi-font-size: 12.0pt; font-family: &amp;amp; quot; mso-fareast-font-family: &amp;amp; quot; color: black; mso-ansi-language: EN-IN; mso-fareast-language: EN-IN;">"Life is good as an intern at Video Volunteers. I run on Baga Beach every morning, but in my spare time it's fun to see other less crowded beaches. As for the work, I have been assigned a job that is interesting and allows me to watch and learn more about Video Volunteers. Through creative writing and promoting, I hope to bring awareness to the videos being produced by the CVU's of Video Volunteers and the CCs of IndiaUnheard."</span></em></p>
&nbsp;
<p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; display: inline !important;"><span style="font-size: 8.5pt; font-family: Georgia, serif; color: black;">William Watt is a student of Visual Communications at the University of Evansville, USA. William is passionate about many aspects of life including athletics, the fine arts, food and traveling. William spent 2 months interning with Video Volunteers where his work focused on promoting the videos made by IndiaUnheard Community Correspondents and CVU producers.</span></p>

	<item>
		<title>Our Ambassadors</title>
		<link>http://www.videovolunteers.org/about/ambassador/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 02 Jun 2010 09:35:57 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>laina</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.videovolunteers.org/?page_id=1331</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h1 style="text-align: left;">Meet Our Ambassadors</h1>
<h1 style="text-align: left;">Stephen Lang, Actor</h1>
You may know celebrity actor Steven Lang as the villainous colonel Quaritch in Avatar, but in reality he believes the camera is a stronger weapon than the gun. Hes become a champion of using cinema for the empowerment of the most disadvantaged, and has recently made a video endorsing the global media organization Video Volunteers. Says Steven Lang,"Video Volunteers is creating a kind of grassroots Reuters. They have created an alternative media in places that dont have cinemas or TV or even regular electricity. As an actor, it is amazing to see people who have so little producing such interesting media. Watch the endorsement video here:<p> <iframe title="YouTube video player" width="640" height="390" src="http://www.youtube.com/embed/aZn90mVOZR0" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

</p><p>To know more about the life and work of  Stephen Lang, <a href="http://www.imdb.com/name/nm0002332/bio" target="_blank">click here</a>
<h1 style="text-align: left;">Abhay Deol, Actor</h1>
<em>Acclaimed as the finest of the young Indian actors, Abhay Deol studied arts in Los Angeles before making his debut with the Hindi film </em><em>Socha Na Thain 2005</em>. He signed on as the Ambassador of Video Volunteers in 2010. Since then he has been working with the Video Volunteers team to promote the work of the organization along with taking time to meet and interact with the Community Video Units and Community Correspondents.</p><p>

Watch Abhay telling Zoom tv why he supports Video Volunteers.</p><p><iframe title="YouTube video player" width="480" height="390" src="http://www.youtube.com/embed/gLbKkZdJf5I" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>
</p><p><strong><a href="http://www.facebook.com/pages/Abhay-Deol/105259520314" target="_blank">Click here to visit Abhay's official page</a></strong></p><p>

Also visit our<a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/press/" target="_self">Press and Resources Page </a> and our <a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/2010/01/27/abhay-deol-%E2%80%93-video-volunteers%E2%80%99-cause-envoy/" target="_self"> Blog</a> to read media reports on VV and its ambassadors. Visit our <a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/videovolunteers/sets/72157623836584510/" target="_blank">Flickr album</a> and <a href="http://www.facebook.com/album.php?aid=172538&amp;id=44889911337" target="_blank">Facebook page</a> to see photos of Abhay Deol attending various events organized by Video Volunteers.</p>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Work with us</title>
		<link>http://www.videovolunteers.org/about/work-with-us/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 09 Dec 2010 08:34:10 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>nladmin</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.videovolunteers.org</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h1><strong>Working with Video Volunteers-India</strong></h1>
<div>Video Volunteers is a media and human rights NGO that is growing and changing along with the media and social change space in India. If you are dedicated and have great ideas for our organization, join us on this journey of empowering community voices. This is the chance of a lifetime to be part of an energetic, entrepreneurial organization with a lot of passion. The rewards of working with Video Volunteers are huge  changing the media model as it is today.</div>
<div>

If you are creative, enthusiastic, energetic, and passionate about creating tangible and lasting solutions to the voicelessness of the disadvantaged in India, contact us now.

We are currently seeking to fill the following positions to start as soon as possible:

<strong><a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/about/work-with-us/advocacy-coordinator-various-locations/">Advocacy Coordinator (Chhattisgarh, Jharkhand, Maharashtra, Bihar, Madhya Pradesh, Uttar Pradesh)</a></strong>

<strong><a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/about/work-with-us/coordinator-training-and-mentoring/">Coordinator (Training and Mentoring), Goa</a></strong>

<strong><a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/about/work-with-us/video-editor">Video Editor</a></strong>

<strong><a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/about/work-with-us/regionalstate-video-editor-various-locations/">Regional/State Video Editor (Bihar, Chhattisgarh, Madhya Pradesh, Odisha, Uttar Pradesh)</a></strong>
<div>-</div>
<div></div>
<div><strong>Apply<a href=" http://videovolunteersindia.wufoo.com/forms/video-volunteers-online-job-application/">online</a>for all positions</strong></div>
<div>-</div>
<div>Renumeration is in accordance with prior work experience. Only Indian citizens with PAN cards may apply. All positions are based in either Goa or Varanasi.Even if you dont see the perfect position for you listed above, contact us via the online application and we can explore other options for you.We create spaces for people who come in with the right skill sets and interests.</div>
<div><strong>
</strong></div>
<div><em>Due to the volume of job-related emails we receive, we are not able to respond individually to each applicant and only contact those applicants that we feel best meet our criteria.</em></div>
</div>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Video Editor</title>
		<link>http://www.videovolunteers.org/about/work-with-us/video-editor/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 09 Dec 2010 08:53:29 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>nladmin</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.videovolunteers.org</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<strong></strong><strong>Video Editor</strong>

The primary role of the video editor is to edit the videos of the community producers. The main video format is viewable on<strong></strong><strong><a href="http://www.indiaunheard.videovolunteers.org/">www.indiaunheard.videovolunteers.org</a>.</strong>

<strong>Qualifications
</strong>
<ul>
	<li>At least two years of work experience as video editor (submit show reel)</li>
	<li>Should be well versed with Final Cut Pro and Adobe Premiere</li>
	<li>Should be good with After Effects, Photoshop and audio correction softwares</li>
	<li>Speaks Hindi and English</li>
</ul>
<strong>Location: Goa, India</strong>

<strong>Key Responsibilities<a href="http://videovolunteersindia.wufoo.com/forms/video-volunteers-online-job-application/">
</a></strong>
<ul>
	<li>Manage raw footage shot by community producers</li>
	<li>Edit the videos shot by the community producers</li>
	<li>Repackage videos for mainstream media and other clients</li>
	<li>Create special videos that showcase the work of Video Volunteers to other organizations</li>
	<li>Train community producer in video editing</li>
</ul>
Fill the online application form<a href=" http://videovolunteersindia.wufoo.com/forms/video-volunteers-online-job-application/"></a><strong><a href="http://videovolunteersindia.wufoo.com/forms/video-volunteers-online-job-application/">here</a><a href=" http://videovolunteersindia.wufoo.com/forms/video-volunteers-online-job-application/"></a></strong>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>1686</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2010-12-09 01:53:29</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2010-12-09 08:53:29</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>closed</wp:comment_status>

		<wp:post_name>video-editor</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>publish</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>1677</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>1</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type>page</wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_edit_last</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[30]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
	</item>
	<item>
		<title>Project Overview</title>
		<link>http://www.videovolunteers.org/programmes/brazil-livelihood-program-%e2%80%93-vcu-br/project-overview/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 09 Dec 2010 08:58:22 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>nladmin</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.videovolunteers.org</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h1>Project Overview: Brazil Livelihood Program  VCU.br</h1>
<strong>Imagine a situation where young, talented youth use their creative energy to build careers in media. They are professionals, rooted firmly in their communities  a favela in So</strong><strong> Paolo, a village in rural India, a shanty town in Johannesburg.</strong>

The Brazil livelihood program (VCU.br) is part of Video Volunteers drive to build a financially sustainable community media scene. The program gave an eight-month fellowship to ten favela youth in So Paolo; providing the support and resources they needed to establish themselves as media professionals. By rethinking their disadvantaged backgrounds, these youth were able to see their distinctive advantage in Brazils competitive media marketplace; as favela residents, they are uniquely positioned to tell the stories of these overlooked but crowded areas of society.
<span style="text-decoration: underline;"><strong>
</strong></span>

<img class="size-medium wp-image-1659 alignleft" style="margin: 10px 20px;" title="community media entrepreneurs 2" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/12/community-media-entrepreneurs-21-300x225.jpg" alt="" width="240" height="203" />
<h2><strong>About VCR.br</strong></h2>
VCU.br is a result of Video Volunteers and So Paolo-based Casa Das Caldeiras shared desire to build a more democratic and sustainable global media landscape. The goal of VCU.br is for each fellow (also referred to as community media entrepreneurs) to develop a one-year career plan enabling them to create meaningful documentaries in a way that would financially support them. This should lead to a long term media career path for youth from disadvantaged backgrounds. The ultimate aim is to enable these youth to develop a sustainable career in videography and media production.

In the first year pilot, the entrepreneurs received a fulltime salary to enable them to focus on the VCU.br program. They were given access to mentors, advanced training workshops and support in marketing videos to distribution platforms. The mentoring component of the program focused on helping the entrepreneurs launch careers as freelance filmmakers.
<h2><strong>Why Brazil?</strong><span style="text-decoration: underline;"><strong>
</strong></span></h2>
The desire to expand programming to Brazil came from seeing an already rich community media base throughout the country, coupled with an acute need for financial sustainability.

While Brazil has one of the most vibrant and thriving community media environments in the world, individual programs are often short-lived. After the conclusion of these programs, individuals and organizations often go separate ways. Participants go back to their jobs (or unemployment) and life continues much as it did before. The architecture for ongoing financially sustainable options needed to be built.

Read more about the media landscape in Brazil <a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/programmes/brazil-livelihood-program-%E2%80%93-vcu-br-2/why-brazil/" target="_self">here</a>.
<h2><strong>Who is Involved?</strong><span style="text-decoration: underline;"><strong><img class="size-medium wp-image-1658 alignleft" style="margin: 10px 20px;" title="photo 162" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/12/photo-1621-300x197.jpg" alt="" width="240" height="159" />
</strong></span></h2>
After designing the program and receiving a grant from Art Action Fund, Video Volunteers surveyed Brazilian media NGOs and selected Casa Das Caldeiras as the local implementing partner. Casa Das Caldeiras is a well-known and highly-regarded local arts center in So Paulo. It manages a fantastic array of artist-in-residency programs and community youth media programs, in areas such as graffiti art, hip hop and many others.

Casa Das Caldeiras is based in a converted 1920s factory; it is an absolutely beautiful community space. Revenue generated from renting it out for events (its one of the prime party venues in the city) is used to fund Casa Das Caldeiras community projects. As an important So Paulo cultural hub, Casa Das Caldeiras connects Video Volunteers and VCU.br entrepreneurs with Brazils film and cultural network in a way that would not otherwise be possible.<span style="color: #333333;"> </span>

<span style="color: #333333;">Check out their website <a href="http://www.casadascaldeiras.com.br/" target="_blank">here</a></span><span style="color: #333333;">.</span>

<span style="color: #333333;"> </span>
<h2><strong>The Community Media Entrepreneurs</strong><span style="text-decoration: underline;"><strong>
</strong></span></h2>
The selection process for the first batch of VCU.br entrepreneurs took place from June-July 2009. They were selected from five different video/educational/social projects in So Paulo that run short-term video trainings for favela youth. Video Volunteers put down three non-negotiable qualifications: the entrepreneurs must be from disadvantaged backgrounds, they must have prior video experience, and they must have demonstrated that they had tried to find work in media but had failed to do so because they lacked sufficient business skills, networks or training. The candidates were truly impressive and inspiring. Finally, ten community media entrepreneurs were selected. These incredible young individuals brought enthusiasm and drive to the program.

You can find out more about the selected entrepreneurs <a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/programmes/brazil-livelihood-program-%E2%80%93-vcu-br-2/overview/the-community-media-entrepreneurs/" target="_self">here</a>.
<h2><strong>The Training</strong><span style="text-decoration: underline;"><strong><img class="size-full wp-image-1660 alignleft" style="margin: 10px 20px;" title="photo 5" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/12/photo-53.jpg" alt="" width="240" height="159" /></strong></span></h2>
Video Volunteers designed a curriculum on video and livelihood and Casa Das Caldeiras hired its own trainers, and brought in its own friends, to implement it. The training was a dynamic mix of technical training and creative workshops by media professionals and artists. Under the guidance of experienced trainers, the entrepreneurs each produced three final films over the course of eight months of training. Each film was of increased demand and difficulty. The first production focused solely on cultivating sharp technical and story telling abilities. The second, built on these skills and challenged the entrepreneurs to create productions for a (non-paying) client. The third film aimed to incorporate all the learnings from the previous months of training, train the entrepreneurs to garner contracts for their work and produce content for a paying client. Finally, the entrepreneurs worked with VCU.br staff to create a personal business plan for their video production work. This final piece helped carry their work forward after the conclusion of the program.

A selection of the entrepreneurs final films are <a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/programmes/brazil-livelihood-program-%E2%80%93-vcu-br/watch-the-videos" target="_self">here</a>.
<h2><strong>The Result  A Community Video Collective</strong></h2>
The livelihood program resulted in an exciting and innovative new venture  a video collective (Coletivo Cacamba) initiated and run by graduates of the VCU.br program. To find out about the innovative work of this group click <a href="http://coletivocacamba.wordpress.com/" target="_blank">here</a>.

The Bottom Line: Is Video and Entrepreneurship Possible?
<ul>
	<li><a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/programmes/brazil-livelihood-program-%E2%80%93-vcu-br-2/overview/the-community-media-entrepreneurs/" target="_self">The community media entrepreneurs</a></li>
	<li> <a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-admin/page.php?action=edit&amp;post=1706">Watch the videos</a></li>
</ul>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
