	</item>
	<item>
		<title>Community Correspondents (Page 2)</title>
		<link>http://www.videovolunteers.org/programmes/indiaunheard/community-correspondents-page-2/</link>
		<pubDate>Sat, 01 Dec 2012 14:34:48 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>vvadmin</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.videovolunteers.org/?page_id=2699</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p style="text-align: center;"><strong>IndiaUnheard Community Correspondents</strong></p>
<p style="text-align: center;"><a href="http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.videovolunteers.org%2Fprogrammes%2Findiaunheard%2Fcommunity-correspondents-2%2F&amp;sa=D&amp;sntz=1&amp;usg=AFQjCNGqm8EORB0JEmRu0JijwyVuMHJaOw" target="_blank">Page 1</a>,<a href="http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.videovolunteers.org%2Fprogrammes%2Findiaunheard%2Fcommunity-correspondents-page-2%2F&amp;sa=D&amp;sntz=1&amp;usg=AFQjCNEhHoj-JrvrVzPb2aXA7Jh4dykvrQ" target="_blank">Page 2</a>,<a href="http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.videovolunteers.org%2Fprogrammes%2Findiaunheard%2Fcommunity-corespondents-page-3%2F&amp;sa=D&amp;sntz=1&amp;usg=AFQjCNG1xBuqmmurAd6naQDKdFCB_56IpA" target="_blank">Page 3</a></p>
<a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/Saroj-Paraste.jpg"><img class="alignleft  wp-image-2738" title="Saroj Paraste" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/Saroj-Paraste-150x150.jpg" alt="" width="105" height="105" /></a>

<strong>Saroj Paraste, Madhya Pradesh</strong>

Saroj Paraste feels that one of the major problems for marginalized communities is the lack of communication. Awareness of basic human rights and government plans and schemes is lacking and the communities are left out of the decision making processes that affect them. For the last 15 years, Saroj has been going door-to-door spreading awareness among her tribal community in Jabalpur. She has been empowering and mobilizing the people to demand their right to health, hygiene and education. Video, she feels, will help the voices and concerns of her community reach kindred ears across the world.Watch her videos <a href="http://indiaunheard.videovolunteers.org/author/saroj/">here</a>.

<a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/Guddu_retouched.jpg"><img class="alignleft  wp-image-2701" title="Guddu_retouched" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/Guddu_retouched-150x150.jpg" alt="" width="105" height="105" /></a>

<strong>Guddu Lehre, Chhattisgarh</strong>

Guddu Lehre is dalit social activist with artistic leanings. Like every actor worth his salt, he spent three years struggling in Mumbai searching for film roles. A few small bits in serials came his away but he mostly came back to Chhattisgarh disappointed. Back home and with his friends, he tried to raise money for a homegrown Chhattisgarhi movie focusing on the urgent issue of mining. He describes his return from exile in Mumbai as his social awakening. Guddu associated himself with the Dalit groups in his community. He is an active campaigner against caste violence and a promoter of Dalit rights. He hopes that his work with IndiaUnheard can get his people and community talking on the issues that matter.Watch Ajeet's videos <a href="http://indiaunheard.videovolunteers.org/author/ajeet/">here</a>.

<a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/jeetendra_jurrey.jpg"><img class="alignleft  wp-image-2702" title="jeetendra_jurrey" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/jeetendra_jurrey-150x150.jpg" alt="" width="100" height="100" /></a>

<strong>Jitendra Khurrey, Chhattisgarh</strong>

Jitendra Khurrey is carrying on the legacy of social work that his father initiated into the family. As a child he grew up in poverty, relying for subsistence on the small farm the family owns and works on. Today, he is a youth leader in a dalit NGO. He works extensively with college students and young dalits across the country. On the eve of the IndiaUnheard, he became a proud father a little girl. He says that with his initiation into videoactivism and fatherhood, he begins a new life with a new purpose and full of hope for a brighter future.

<a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/kopa_retouched.jpg"><img class="alignleft  wp-image-2703" title="kopa_retouched" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/kopa_retouched-150x150.jpg" alt="" width="108" height="108" /></a>

<strong>K R Kunjam, Chhattisgarh</strong>

KR Kunjam is an adivasi from the conflict ridden Dantewada district of Chhattisgarh. He was arrested on the mere suspicion of being a Naxal. He was kept in jail for 22 months in unspeakable conditions. While in prison, his rights and his body were repeatedly violated by the state. He was released in October 2011. He still bears the scars of his prison terms. He complains of moments of disorientation. As an IndiaUnheard CC he says that he will be putting a spotlight on the two biggest issues that plague his region  education and health.

<a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/Madhukar_retouched.jpg"><img class="alignleft  wp-image-2704" title="Madhukar_retouched" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/Madhukar_retouched-150x150.jpg" alt="" width="105" height="105" /></a>

<strong>Madhukar Gorakh, Chhattisgarh</strong>

Madhukar has over 40 years of grassroots experience in activism, starting with his long career with the with India Peoples Theatre Association (IPTA) in the 70s. He has been relentless ever since. He rose in the ranks to become the secretary of IPTAs Chhattisgarh chapter and was also a party worker with the Communist Party of India. His duty, he says lies in freeing the people from a tyranny that has stolen their culture. This is what he hopes to achieve with his videos.

<a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/Savita_retouched.jpg"><img class="alignleft  wp-image-2705" title="Savita_retouched" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/Savita_retouched-150x150.jpg" alt="" width="105" height="105" /></a>

<strong>Savita Rath, Chhattisgarh</strong>

Savita has come a long way since when she was brought up as a quiet mouse in an oppressively parochial upper class neighbourhood under the iron hand of her father. When she realized that there was a wide world outside her house which she had never experienced, she rebelled. She spent the next turbulent decade mired in activism. As a leader of many popular movements against the unjust practices of the corporate and the state in the distressed region of Raigarh, Chhattisgarh, she has frequently faced arrest and harassment at the hands of the authorities. But Savitha is unperturbed. She describes video as yet another tool to further her and her communitys struggles and get their issues heard aloud and across the world

<a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/ashit_retouched.jpg"><img class="alignleft  wp-image-2706" title="ashit_retouched" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/ashit_retouched-150x150.jpg" alt="" width="105" height="105" /></a>

<strong>Ashit Kumar, Chhattisgarh</strong>

Ashit Kumar is father of one and veteran social activist with 7 years of field experience in rural Chhattisgarh. He conducts surveys of grassroots conditions regarding infrastructure and development. He says that his surveys reveal a depressing state of development that benefits a few while damning the rest. It also brings to light that awareness of laws and schemes and rights which can benefit and aid the marginalized is lacking. He holds the bureaucracy and red tape as responsible for the fact that a section of society has been kept economically, socially and politically deprived. He says that the need of the hour is straight talking. Something he hopes to achieve with his videos from the grassroots.

<a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/madhu_retouched.jpg"><img class="alignleft  wp-image-2707" title="madhu_retouched" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/madhu_retouched-150x150.jpg" alt="" width="105" height="105" /></a>

<strong>Madhu Tirki, Chhattisgarh</strong>

Madhu is an activetheaterworker from the tribal district of Jaspur in Chhattisgarh. She is only 23 and already has over 4 years of experience working for her community. The pressing need to contribute to family income forced her to drop out of education at the 12th grade and find work. Working for an ngo she was involved with important issues like health, displacement and forest rights by doing surveys and field visits. It was also when she was introduced to the art of theater for social empowerment and awareness. She found intheaterthe ability to drive home thoughts and ideas into the hearts and minds of her people but she feels that, that alone is not enough. She says that her videos aim to take the peoples issues above the heads of the authorities and connect with the hearts and minds all people across the world.

<a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/Reena_retouched.jpg"><img class="alignleft  wp-image-2708" title="Reena_retouched" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/Reena_retouched-150x150.jpg" alt="" width="105" height="105" /></a>

<strong>Reena Ramteke, Chhattisgarh</strong>

Reena Ramteke belongs to a remote village of 60 families in the district of Ghariabandh in the state of Chhattisgarh in Eastern India. The region that she lives in is heavily forested. Basic amenities like water, electricity, roads are lacking or altogether absent. Life is difficult. Poverty is rife. The state is hell bent on exploiting the forests and the mineral rich land. There is state violence and caste violence. The common person is disillusioned, she says. Addiction to alcohol and drugs is high. Her father is an addict, and the desire to change the root causes of his condition is what drove her to be an addict.

<a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/ranjeeta_retouched.jpg"><img class="alignleft  wp-image-2709" title="ranjeeta_retouched" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/ranjeeta_retouched-150x150.jpg" alt="" width="105" height="105" /></a>

<strong>Ranjeeta Tirki, Chhattisgarh</strong>

Ranjeeta is an adivasi from Jaspur. She is 22 and new to the field of social work. Her mother is a social worker and she is Ranjitas inspiration. She realizes that she has lot to catch up on but she says that she is learning quickly from the exposure she is getting at work. Shes starting and now with video, the possibilities ahead of her seem immense. The heart of her videos will be the issues and concerns of the marginalized adivasi communities in Jaspur.

<a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/naeem.jpg"><img class="alignleft  wp-image-2710" title="naeem" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/naeem-150x150.jpg" alt="" width="105" height="105" /></a>

<strong>Naeem Shah, Madhya Pradesh</strong>

Naeem belongs to the Ujjain district in Madhya Pradesh. He is a son of a muezzin in a mosque and is married with one child and another on the way. He works with <a href="http://www.jansahasindia.org/garima">Jan Sahas</a>, an organization which works with manual scavengers. He belongs to the fakir caste and works with the helas who have been traditionally kept oppressed in the role of manual scavengers. It is his work and passion to ensure that members of the hela community employed for this hellish job and who live in hellish conditions are rehabilitated. He calls fakirs and helas as brothers in woe. Together they languish in the most oppressed spaces in society. Naeem believes that together they will fight for a better future.

<a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/Warles.jpg"><img class="alignleft  wp-image-2739" title="Warles" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/Warles-150x150.jpg" alt="" width="105" height="105" /></a>

<strong>Warles Surin, Jharkhand</strong>

Warles Surin gave up his job at an IT warehouse and returned to his village, which is along the Red Corridoor, to open a playschool. He is a community person at heart and finds most of the stories for his videos from his Sunday congregation. He says that the region he lives in is so cut away and remote that even the simplest problems like access to clean drinking water are ignored. He believes that his video allow his people to communicate with the world outside. He and his community is hoping to find a kindred soul and kind ear who will listen and help bring about change. Watch his videos <a href="http://indiaunheard.videovolunteers.org/?s=warlus&amp;x=0&amp;y=0">here.</a>

<a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/Kamal-Kishope-Purthy.jpg"><img class="alignleft  wp-image-2740" title="Kamal Kishope Purthy" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/Kamal-Kishope-Purthy-150x150.jpg" alt="" width="105" height="105" /></a>

<strong>Kamal Kishor Purthy, Jharkhand</strong>

Kamal Kishor Purthy is an adivasi who has been working as a social activist for the last 15 years. The region he belongs to is remote. During the rains, his village sinks into floods. It is unconnected and almost inaccessible. Since becoming a Community Correspondent, Kamal Kishor has become a rare representative of the press in his region. Just the fact that he is making videos on the issues in his region and he has got the people to talk about has been enough to bring about many successes and social change. He describes himself as much more than a man with a camera. He is his peoples media, he says. Watch his videos <a href="http://indiaunheard.videovolunteers.org/?s=kamal&amp;x=25&amp;y=13">here</a>.

<strong><a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/Paul-Malto.jpg"><img class="alignleft  wp-image-2741" title="Paul Malto" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/Paul-Malto-150x150.jpg" alt="" width="105" height="105" /></a>Paul Malto, Jharkhand</strong>

Paul Malto is an adivasi school teacher from the remote hilly region of Sahibganj in Jharkhand. In a region that does not even receive a cell phone signal, Paul is a rare literate individual. He says that it puts him in a position of responsibility. He is representative and mouthpiece of his communitys voice, something that he hopes to amplify with his videos.Watch Paul'svideos <a href="http://indiaunheard.videovolunteers.org/?s=malto&amp;x=0&amp;y=0">here</a>.

<a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/DSC_0821.jpg"><img class="alignleft  wp-image-2746" title="DSC_0821" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/DSC_0821-150x150.jpg" alt="" width="105" height="105" /></a>

<strong>Xavier Hamsay, Jharkhand</strong>

Xavier Hamsays father was a local tribal leader who lost his life because of the central role he played in his tribal communitys struggle for rights and recognition. Xavier says that he inherited the torch of the struggle the day his father passed away. He remains an inspired independent champion of human rights, going from village to village, listening to the peoples issues, consoling them, helping them bring about change. He believes that one dedicated man can create social change. And having a camera helps.

&nbsp;

<a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/Chunnu.jpg"><img class="alignleft  wp-image-2742" title="Chunnu" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/Chunnu-150x150.jpg" alt="" width="105" height="105" /></a>

<strong>Chunnu Hansda, Jharkhand</strong>

Chunnu Hansda is a farmer and a seasonal daily wage laborer. He was busying eking out a difficult living when he heard that his closest friend had committed suicide because he had lost his all his money and savings as a result of governmental corruption. Chunnu says that this shocking moment made him reflect on the many injustices in his state of Jharkhand that take a toll on his people and community. It was moment that inspired him to dedicate his life to turn into a local activist. He hopes that his video can help others like him begin thinking and acting for themselves.Watch Chunnu's video<a href="http://indiaunheard.videovolunteers.org/?s=chunnu&amp;x=0&amp;y=0">here</a>.

<a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/Jitendra_retouched.jpg"><img class="alignleft  wp-image-2711" title="Jitendra_retouched" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/Jitendra_retouched-150x150.jpg" alt="" width="105" height="105" /></a>

<strong>Jeetendra Parmar, Madhya Pradesh</strong>

The first job interview that Jeetendra Parmar qualified for gave him immense purpose and passion to his life. He is a coordinator working for the rehabilitation of manual scavengers. His work has given him a great insight into how people are held oppressed, he says. Working with<a href="http://www.jansahasindia.org/garima">Jan Sahas</a>, he has successfully rehabilitated many manual scavengers with the help of his organization, Garima. His work has taught him patience, discipline and perseverance. It is with these skills that he intends to make video on Indias unheard and unseen.

<a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/Khirendra_retouched.jpg"><img class="alignleft  wp-image-2712" title="Khirendra_retouched" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/Khirendra_retouched-150x150.jpg" alt="" width="105" height="105" /></a>

<strong>Khirendra Yadav, Chhattisgarh</strong>

Khirendra who hails from the strife-ridden 'redcorridor' region of Bastar is an eccentric renaissance man. He is sculptor, a painter, a streettheaterartiste and an ex- football player for his district. He is a long distance runner by passion and claims impressive distances and impressive speeds. He is a dalit. The oppression that he experienced and witnessed while growing up now inspires him to help his community fight for their rights. As atheaterartiste he works best with awareness programs. His focus is on child rights, womens right and HIV. His videos, he says, will be an extension of passion for art and activism.

<a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/DSC_0593_resolution_75.jpg"><img class="alignleft  wp-image-2747" title="DSC_0593_resolution_75" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/DSC_0593_resolution_75-150x150.jpg" alt="" width="105" height="105" /></a>

<strong>Nirmala Jyothi Ekka, Jharkhand</strong>

Nirmala Jyoti Ekka works for the urban dispossessed. As her city of Ranchi sees unprecedented growth the rights of the people living on the margins are in the danger of being run over. But the most vulnerable, she says, are the women. The city is unsafe for them and they are vulnerable to exploitation and trafficking. As an activist she has been fighting against this all her life. She now wants to make videos which will do the same. Watch her videos <a href="http://indiaunheard.videovolunteers.org/?s=nirmala&amp;x=0&amp;y=0">here</a>.

.

<a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/Priyasheela.jpg"><img class="alignleft  wp-image-2743" title="Priyasheela" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/Priyasheela-150x150.jpg" alt="" width="105" height="105" /></a>

<strong>Priyasheela Besra, Jharkhand</strong>

Priyasheela is an adivasi and a mother of two. She has chosen to make her own decisions in life rather than being dependant on others. The trials she has faced has only inspired her to become a social activist, fighting for the rights of others. As an IndiaUnheard Community Correspondent from Ranchi district, Jharkhand she wants to report stories dedicated to the brave adivasi women of Jharkhand.Watch Priyasheela's videos <a href="http://indiaunheard.videovolunteers.org/?s=priyasheela&amp;x=0&amp;y=0">here</a>.

<a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/Mohan-Bhuiyan.jpg"><img class="alignleft  wp-image-2744" title="Mohan Bhuiyan" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/Mohan-Bhuiyan-150x150.jpg" alt="" width="105" height="105" /></a>

<strong>Mohan Bhuiyan, Jharkhand</strong>

In a rapidly changing world, there are some communities that struggling to keep their identities intact in trying to keep up. Mohan Kumar Bhuiyan belongs to one such adivasi community who live dangerously perched between the open minefields of Tata, on one side and Central Coalfields, on the other. He and his neighbors have already been given eviction notices and will be thrown out of their homes any day. He believes that as a community his people are losing their identities by being deprived of their land. That their homes have turned into mines has left people lost and disillusioned. Mohan wants to reclaim his communitys sense of being through his videos and wants to use them to fight for their rights.Watch Mohan's videos <a href="http://indiaunheard.videovolunteers.org/?s=mohan&amp;x=0&amp;y=0">here</a>.

<a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/Justin-Lakra.jpg"><img class="alignleft  wp-image-2745" title="Justin Lakra" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/Justin-Lakra-150x150.jpg" alt="" width="105" height="105" /></a>

<strong>Justin Lakra, Jharkhand</strong>

Justin Lakra is a simple farmer and firewood seller from the Latehar district of Jharkhand. For years he has been involved in a popular struggle for land rights which have successfully kept the corporates and the state from acquiring his land. The need of the hour, he says, is that his community be more aware of its rights and that the rest of the country and the world need to be aware of their issues. His videos, he feels, will be windows through which his community can look out and the world can look in.Watch Justin's videos <a href="http://indiaunheard.videovolunteers.org/?s=justin&amp;x=0&amp;y=0">here</a>.

<a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/VrindaAzad-01.jpg"><img class="alignleft  wp-image-2713" title="VrindaAzad-01" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/VrindaAzad-01-150x150.jpg" alt="" width="105" height="105" /></a>

<strong>Vrinda Azad, Chhattisgarh</strong>

Vrinda Azad is the former Sarpanch  or Chief  of her village, one of the most challenging positions that a woman, a dalit and a social worker can find herself in. She was elected Village Chief after more than a decade as an activist. As Sarpanch, her primary struggle was to bring electricity to her village, a quest that lasted three years. Electricity did come. Today her children study in the bright light of a bulb. But unable to balance the pressures of home and office, Vrinda resigned from office and continued her social work as a part of organizations and individually.

<a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/dina_retouched.jpg"><img class="alignleft  wp-image-2714" title="dina_retouched" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/dina_retouched-150x150.jpg" alt="" width="105" height="105" /></a>

<strong>Dina Ganvir, Chhattisgarh</strong>

Dina was born and brought up in Kanker district. But fate took her to Kawardha which she embraced as her community. When she first left her house for the field she says that she was horrified at the conditions in which the local adivasis were living in. But Dina persevered. Once a sickly city girl, afraid to venture out alone, she now lives as a single woman in a remote community that has claimed her as one of their own. Her videos highlight the issues of the community that found and embraced her.

<a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/ramjag_retouched.jpg"><img class="alignleft  wp-image-2715" title="ramjag_retouched" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/ramjag_retouched-150x150.jpg" alt="" width="105" height="105" /></a>

<strong>Ramjag Gaud, Chhattisgarh</strong>

Ramjag from Bastar is another correspondent who operates in the red corridor of Chattisgarh. For over 12 years, he has been working on various projects in this sensitive zone with both government and non-government organizations. He has worked on health, education, relief work and womans issues. But Ramjag relies on his homegrown instincts. He tells stories of his travels along roads that people are afraid to take. He has defended himself against the state and the insurgents and he has continued walking.

<a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/Halomunni.jpg"><img class="alignleft  wp-image-2716" title="Halomunni" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/Halomunni-150x150.jpg" alt="" width="105" height="105" /></a>

<strong>Halomuni Kuardar, Odisha</strong>

Halomuni grew up dreaming to change the conditions of the school in her village in Sundergarh district, Odisha. Right after college in 2010, she attended a public hearing to save her village from being evicted to make way for Rungta Mines. It made her see things in a broader perspective. With an eagerness to understand the issue better, she went on to do an internship with BIRSA Mines Monitoring Centre, Ranchi and is now an active member of an anti-mining organisation in her village. She is determined to highlight the real picture of her village and use video as a medium to bring about change.

<a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/Ashok.jpg"><img class="alignleft  wp-image-2717" title="Ashok" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/Ashok-150x150.jpg" alt="" width="105" height="105" /></a>

<strong>Ashok Kumar Samal, Odisha</strong>

After completing his graduation Ashok Kumar Samal from Cuttack, Odisha struggled to find a job. Most of his peers had given bribes to secure one. Despite his disillusionment, he had an urge to fight the inequality he had faced since childhood and he took up the cause of Dalit rights and gender equality. As an active member of the Dalit rightsorganisationAmbedkar Lohia Vichar Manch and National Alliance for Women, he has fought for two decades now and aims to use the IndiaUnheard platform to reach out to a national and international audience.

<a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/Ranjeet.jpg"><img class="alignleft  wp-image-2718" title="Ranjeet" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/Ranjeet-150x150.jpg" alt="" width="105" height="105" /></a>

<strong>Ranjit Dehury, Odisha</strong>

Ranjit Dehury from Dhenkanal district, Odisha, was forced to drop out of school when he was in the 10th grade . But it was his desire for change that found him in the middle of two protests at his workplace. He has now left his job and travels across villages trying to understand and solve problems related to land registration, Public Distribution Systems and sanitation among others. He wants to use the power of community video to hold concerned authorities accountable for their work.

<a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/Mamta.jpg"><img class="alignleft  wp-image-2719" title="Mamta" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/Mamta-150x150.jpg" alt="" width="105" height="105" /></a>

<strong>Mamta Patra, Odisha</strong>

Mamta Patra from Sambalpur district in Odisha felt the brunt of corruption when her father was arrested in a fake case. Determined to fight this problem, she got involved in the development sector at a young age. These early experiences have set the direction for her life and for the last two years she has been working independently against corruption and for farmers rights. She is also the founder member of Kosjit Vikas Sangathan which works towards this goal. Disappointed by the mainstream medias partiality, Mamta wants to use videos to capture real problems and work towards getting faster impacts.

<strong>
<a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/Saroj.jpg"><img class="alignleft  wp-image-2720" title="Saroj" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/Saroj-150x150.jpg" alt="" width="105" height="105" /></a>Saroj Kumar Suna, Odisha</strong>

Saroj Kumar Suna from Bargarh, Odisha has faced social inequality at close quarters. He first experienced caste discrimination when the village barber made excuses to avoid cutting his hair, because he didnt want to touch the hair of a Dalit. In 2000, he started reading Dalit literature which inspired him to work towards a solution to end this inequality. He is an active member of several local Dalit groups. Experience has taught him that well written letters and articles dont move the authorities as much as visual documentation does. He is eager to document the human rights violations &amp; other issues around his village using video and work towards changing these conditions.

<a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/Lambodar.jpg"><img class="alignleft  wp-image-2721" title="Lambodar" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/Lambodar-150x150.jpg" alt="" width="105" height="105" /></a>

<strong>Lambodar Takri, Odisha</strong>

Lambodar Takri belongs to Balangir District, Odisha. Like countless others, being a Dalit has meant facing a lot of discrimination on a day to day basis. Determined to end such treatment he created an organisation for Dalit Students which would help people like him. Lambodar is also extremely passionate about folk culture and is a popular folk singer. Through his videos he wants to empower people and help them take pride in their local culture which he feels is slowly being lost with urbanisation.

<a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/Coming_Soon_Icon.sm_.jpg"><img class="alignleft size-full wp-image-2700" title="Coming_Soon_Icon.sm" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/Coming_Soon_Icon.sm_.jpg" alt="" width="123" height="134" /></a>

<strong>Debendra Swain, Odisha</strong>

Debendra Swain from Jagatsinghpur district Odisha had led a peaceful life as a farmer in his village and wanted to continue doing just that. His life has taken a different turn as his village finds itself in the midst of a land-acquisition controversy with a steel company. Debendra and his people dont want a factory; they want their farmlands and their family homes. Through his videos he wants to tell the stories of their resistance and its often harsh consequences.

<a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/Abhishek.jpg"><img class="alignleft  wp-image-2722" title="Abhishek" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/Abhishek-150x150.jpg" alt="" width="105" height="105" /></a>

<strong>Abhishek Kumar Dash, Odisha</strong>

Abhishek Kumar Dash is the India Unheard Community Correspondent from Nuapada district, Odisha. His dream was to become an engineer. Though he enrolled in a B.Sc. program, he was forced to drop out half way through as his family faced dire financial circumstances. He then started and gave up a successful business[JM6] to become a social activist because he felt the need for a stronger leadership which would be able to work out the different issues prevalent in society. He sees video as a tool that can document the problems faced by his people and help them take action.

<a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/Gautam.jpg"><img class="alignleft  wp-image-2723" title="Gautam" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/Gautam-150x150.jpg" alt="" width="105" height="105" /></a>

<strong>Gautam Sahu, Odisha</strong>

Gautam Sahu is from Kendarapada, Odisha. He has a Masters degree in Journalism and is now studying Law. He has been involved in a number of organisations from a young age and is currently a volunteer at Nehu Yuva Kendra Sangathan, an organisation that involves rural youth in the process of nation-building. Through the India Unheard platform he wants to document the problems faced by his people on a daily basis so that they appear on the radar of the local officials.

<a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/Satya.jpg"><img class="alignleft  wp-image-2724" title="Satya" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/Satya-150x150.jpg" alt="" width="105" height="105" /></a>

<strong>Satya Mahar, Odisha</strong>

Satya Mahar in an activist who is involved in a number of movements in his area especially the Niyamgiri Andolan for tribal rights and land. He feels strongly about issues related to tribal, Dalit and farmers rights. Rather than being divided along caste and religious lines, he believes that people should be bound by the idea of a common humanity. He feels that alternative media can help him accomplish this goal.

<a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/Jayanti.jpg"><img class="alignleft  wp-image-2725" title="Jayanti" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/Jayanti-150x150.jpg" alt="" width="105" height="105" /></a>

<strong>Jayanti Naik, Odisha</strong>

Jayanti Naik comes from Keonjhar district in Odisha, an area where the people are heavily dependant on the forest land. That this land is going to be taken over to make way for mines is a matter of great concern for her community[JM9] . She says she will use the skills that she has gained through years of farming to help find a solution to this problem. Through her videos she wants to empower her community and bring their voice to the rest of the world.

<a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/programmes/indiaunheard/community-correspondents-2/">Click here for previous page</a>                                                                                <a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/programmes/indiaunheard/community-corespondents-page-3/">Click here for next page</a>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Sakshi Media Producer Profile - Noor</title>
		<link>http://www.videovolunteers.org/sakshi-media-producer-profile---noor/</link>

	<item>
		<title>Video Volunteers India - Opportunities </title>
		<link>http://www.videovolunteers.org/?p=991</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 04 Sep 2009 02:24:34 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>laina</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.videovolunteers.org/?p=991</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Video Volunteers India is looking to fill several positions to help lead our organization into the next phase.

The perfect candidates are creative, enthusiastic and driven, and looking for the experience of a life-time creating tangible and lasting solutions to the voicelessness of the disadvantaged in India. 

Were looking for passionate inspiring people. You will need to love the mission of Video Volunteers, because we are still a start up and need great ideas and dedicated people. But the possible rewards are huge  changing the media model as it is today.

<strong>Next Steps</strong>
Email CV, and a thoughtful cover letter that helps us know you better. Tell us where you think Video Volunteers can be in five or ten years, and how you can help us get there. Tell us your salary expectations, start date availability, what youre best at and what you want to learn. Let us know where you want to be career-wise in 5-10 years. Applicants who dont take the time to craft an enticing cover letter will not be considered.

Mail your applications to videovolunteersindia[at]gmail with the name of the position you are applying for in the cover letter.

VV India is growing and changing, and so is the media and social change space in India. This is the chance of a lifetime to be part of a young, entrepreneurial organization with a lot of passion.

Applications should be received no later than 1st October 2009.
Due to the volume of applicants anticipated, we will not be able to respond individually to each applicant and will only be contacting those applicants that we feel best meet our criteria.  

<strong>New Partnerships Director</strong>
This position will be responsible for creating partnerships for Video Volunteers with the mainstream media, government, NGOs, social movements, and universities. As VV India seeks to expand its programs and transform community media into a financially viable entity as well as a social movement, inspiring and involving other stakeholders becomes crucial. This is a position that will require strong communications skills for frequent meetings and presentations.
Responsibilities will include: 
	Research potential partners and key stakeholders
	Oversee the creation of marketing materials for all new initiatives
	Maintain the contacts database and carry out email correspondence with potential partners
	Create strategies and program ideas for how VV can work with each potential partner and draft proposals
	Organize regional events and meetings with new partners, such as colleges, social movements and the mainstream media

Qualifications
	At least five years work experience
	Great writing skills
	People from a business, social work or marketing can apply
	Proven ability to inspire others to follow your lead

<strong>Communications Director</strong>
This is a role is for someone who writes and speaks persuasively. Youll be writing program reports, working on our website, drafting correspondence with funders and partners, working on funders proposals. You will be responsible for documentation, and may undertake some research projects as well.

Responsibilities will include:
	Write program reports and gather and organize documentation for them 
	Write fund proposals along with the Director 
	Draft funding correspondence
	Write text for the websites and for publicity materials
	Post all updates, photos, videos on our websites, facebook, flickr, twitter, etc.
	Documentation  gather case studies and success stories from the field, oversee the documenting of impact stories within the projects and create periodic reports
	Research  maintain the research databases of learnings and best practices within our field. Conduct research projects on particular projects
	Qualifications
	At least three years work experience
	Great writing skills and great ability to tell stories

<strong .Senior Video Trainers Required</strong> 

Video Volunteers is a non-profit organization dedicated to empowering community voices and to democratization of media. We set up community media units where poor and disadvantaged people are trained to create their own media content as a step towards finding solutions to their problems. Members of these units learn to be powerful communicators, journalists, filmmakers, and advocates and leaders in their communities. If you are video/film maker experienced in teaching/training and interested in working with the underprivileged communities in India then do read on.

We are looking to employ Senior Video Trainers who are interested in being part of a growing community media movement. 

Qualifications:
	Proficient in all aspects of video production--shooting, writing and non-linear editing 
	Must have 4 to 5 years of video training experience, or experience working in human rights or development organization 
	Must have shot, written and edited your own videos 
	Must have strong creative and storytelling abilities 
	Must have leadership qualities to motivate and lead 
	Must have great communications skills and a desire to work with communities 
	Must be willing to travel to remote, rural area for sizeable amounts of time    
	Must be proficient in writing and reading English,  Hindi and third language preferable 
	Must show a reel of work you have shot, written and edited on your own 
	Only Indian Nationals may apply 

</strong><strong>Senior Administrator</strong>
The Senior Administrator will manage the office in Goa, making sure that things run smoothly and working to maintain a smooth, professional, positive office environment. He or she will be involved in all administrative and legal issues, including supervision of accounts and audits. She will play a key role in Human Resources, such as handling initial interviews with potential staff. The successful candidate will be someone who has been involved in HR, perhaps as an executive assistant or office manager in a company.

Responsiblities will include
	Identify and interface with key consultants/associates, such as lawyers, accountant, landlords, etc.
	Oversee the audit and maintain the basic accounts, such as the daily Petty Cash and Vouchers
	Oversee the hiring process in the office and basic HR issues such as monthly reporting and expenses of staff
	Manage all Office Correspondence - Letters, Emails, Telephone, etc.
	Manage Office Equipment, Office Space, books and video library
	Maintain the contacts database and mailing lists
	Manage Appointment Schedules, Meetings, Events/Conferences, Travel Arrangements and Logistics
	Undertake Governance Responsibilities , such as board meetings, minutes, etc.
	Manage and Update Maintenance of Common Services and Contracts
	Manage and Update Office and Personnel Insurances (Mediclaim and Personal Accident)
	Write and Send Donor Compliance Reports
	Purchase Office Supplies and Equipment as per Purchase Policy

<strong>Program Coordinators</strong>
The Program Coordinators manage the community video projects after they have been launched. They are very involved with the Community Video and Radio projects, and are in regular touch with the Community Video Producers and our NGO partners. The role involves trouble-shooting and problem-solving, as well as great organizational skills necessary for keeping projects on track. 

Responsibilities Include:
	Organize training schedules for video and radio training
	Create progress reports on each VV project, including maintaining the quantitative data
	Organize events such as Community Video Camps and regional trainings
	Handle all scheduling and logistics for program activities
	Create projects for volunteers and interns
	Update training manuals and review training reports

Qualifications
	Three years of work experience minimum
	Academic background in social work or management
	Extremely organized and enjoys working with data and creating management systems
	Great writing skills in English
	Great communications skills for building relationships with community producers and partner organizations
	Hindi and English

<strong>Video Editor</strong>
The video editor will assist the program staff in preparing videos for distribution online and occasionally via mainstream media. Every month, video will be received from numerous community producers around the country in raw form, with scripts attached. the Video Editor will cut from this material numerous short, 3-5 minute web videos. Since most video will be for the web, the key skill needed is the ability to work efficiently, producing several short three minute videos every day.  

Responsibilities include:
	Cutting half hour community videos into seven minute subtitled videos to show at conferences and presentations
	Taking lots of raw footage plus scripts and creating numerous short web videos 
	Subtitling videos into English and formatting them for the web

Qualifications
	At least one year experience working as a video editor
	Mastery of Final Cut Pro, Adobe Premier, compression softwares 
	Knowledge of matering for the web

<strong>Accounts Officer</strong>
The accounts officer will maintain the office accounts.

Responsibilities
	Prepare monthly expense reports
	Handle all vouchers
	Prepare the annual audit
	Enter all data into softwares such as Talley or Quickbooks

Qualifications
	At least two years work experience
	Degree related to accounting
	Knowledge of accounting softwares such as Talley or Quickbooks
]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>991</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2009-09-03 19:24:34</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2009-09-04 02:24:34</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>video-volunteers-india-opportunities</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>draft</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type>post</wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>
		<category domain="category" nicename="blog"><![CDATA[Blog]]></category>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_edit_last</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[7]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
	</item>
	<item>
		<title></title>
		<link>http://www.videovolunteers.org/?p=1022</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>nladmin</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.videovolunteers.org/?p=1022</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Stalin interview:

I just came back from Gujarat, a western state of India, after visiting two of our units. One is in the city of Ahmedabad, called Samvad, which means 'dialogue,' and the other unit is in rural Gujarat called Apna Malak Ma, which means 'in our land.'

At Apna Malak Ma I conducted a two day workshop on helping them figure out how to increase community participation. The unit suggested they'd work with women's committee and children'ts committee in the villages, to involve them in publicity for trainings as well as following up on call-to-actions at the end of each magazine.

I conducted a trial workshop with a set of women in one village, and another set of children in another village, where community producers and coordinators observed how i conducted meetings. Then we came back to the unit's office and drew points about how to conduct such meetings. For example, after the end of the workshop with the women in one village, we formed a women's committee. So 54 women gathered, and 16 gave their names to be a part of the women's committee for that village. I asked all women from that village to get up, come to the front side, and thanked them and clapped, for taking on this charge. Now ,based on that learning, Apna Malak Ma will go about setting up eight such committees (women's).

A similar process was conducted with 71 children. The idea was to set up a children's committee. After the workshop they will set up 8 children's committees in eight villages.

What do these committees do?

The committees will help the CVU get attending at their screenings. They will also play a strong role in following up the call-to-actions at the end of a magazine. For instance if a magazine says to solve our issue on a problem, say, on domestic violence, and you need to contact such and such NGO or state department, we need community members to keep an eye out and monitor, are people actually doing these cases? These committees will be the first point-of-contact for these villages.

Was it not possible to get a co-ed committee?

The reason why we zeroed in on women's committee is that if you look at the attending at the screenings at night, the number of women is lower, they're usually at the house. if women encourage other women to go, the number attending will go up. The other reason is the issues addressed by the magazine's are community issues, and it usually affects women, bc they run the families, they face the first brunt. So it's important for women to know how to solve these issues.

Children are from both genders. We thought of a childrens committee because there's an equal number of children and adults at the screenings. Children are always there to cheer and sit in the front row. The idea is to sit with them and figure out what issues they want to see in the magazines, and because they are always behind the distributor advertising these screenings, maybe they can help and can have more fun with it, and they're very enthusiastic.

This seems to be an extension of community involvement.

I would break up our work into three different phases. One is to find out issues and figure out how to solve these, through preproduction and research. The second phase is to present the issue and the solution - production and screening we call it. You make it, you put it in a form you can understand, you inspire people by putting presenting it in success stories. The third and most crucial phase is to have a discussion on how to solve thes issues, what steps can be done. If the third part is not done, the idea of community video is lost. We're empowering people not just to voice their problems, but to have solutions. Unless the solution is acted upon, tested, tried, and we know if it works or not, we're not completing the cycle of empowerment. For us the fact that the presentation or voicing their problems is not enough. Unless they lead to concrete solutions, communities themselves taking steps, it's an incomplete process.

Is this the first time you've formed community committees?

No. AMM has already formed four women's committees. This is the second time around. The children committee was formed for first time. in other cases, no other unit has formed such dedicated committees. Most units have volunteers that help them set up screenings and fill out feedback forms.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Assistant Video Trainer and Editor</title>
		<link>http://www.videovolunteers.org/?p=1681</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 09 Dec 2010 08:49:18 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>nladmin</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.videovolunteers.org/?p=1681</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>1681</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2010-12-09 01:49:18</wp:post_date>

	<item>
		<title>Draft created on 12/31/2010 at 6:59 am</title>
		<link>http://www.videovolunteers.org/?p=1766</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>nladmin</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.videovolunteers.org/?p=1766</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>1766</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2010-12-30 23:59:36</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>0000-00-00 00:00:00</wp:post_date_gmt>

	<item>
		<title></title>
		<link>http://www.videovolunteers.org/?p=2575</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>vvadmin</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.videovolunteers.org/?p=2575</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA["Video Volunteers was thrilled to win the EdelGive Awards. It was an honor to present to their jury, who asked great questions that we could learn from. I liked the very thorough due diligence they conducted including a site visit, as it shows how seriously the EdelGive Foundation takes these awards. It is a great recognition of the importance of community voices in driving social change in India."

Jessica Mayberry, Founding Director, Video Volunteers - Empowering Community Voices

&nbsp;

India's most prestigious award for innovation in the social sector  the EdelGive Social Innovation Honours (ESIH) was awarded toVideo Volunteers for the organizations "stellar work in Economic Security and Livelihoods and Rights and Representation respectively."

This year's eminent jury which chose the final winners included luminaries like Rakesh Jhunjhunwala, Partner, RaRe Enterprises; Anu Aga, ex-Chairperson, Thermax Ltd., Amit Chandra, MD, Bain Capital, Zia Mody, leading corporate lawyer and Founding Partner of AZB Partners, Sagarika Ghosh, Deputy Editor, CNN-IBN among others.

The EdelGive Social Innovation Honours (ESIH) was launched in 2008-09 with the vision to recognize, promote and support outstanding innovations that are catalysing positive social change across India.

Winners are awarded across four categories to include Education, Health &amp; Wellbeing, Economic Security &amp; Livelihood and Rights &amp; Representation.

Find Video Volunteers in the list of Winners <a href="http://www.edelgive.org/subcat.php?scid=12&amp;ccid=4">Here</a>

&nbsp;

&nbsp;]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>We Couldn&#039;t Have Done It Without You: Our Keys Stats &amp; Numbers as on 11th October, 2012</title>
		<link>http://www.videovolunteers.org/?p=2667</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>vvadmin</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.videovolunteers.org/?p=2667</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[&nbsp;

<a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/programmes/indiaunheard/community-correspondents-2/">100 Community Correspondents</a>.

<a href="http://youtu.be/gcPfSkgsCHk">23 States.</a>

<a href="http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nE1KWvjs-_g&amp;feature=youtu.be">81 districts.</a>

<a href="http://www.youtube.com/user/VideoVolunteers">Around 800 Published Community Videos.</a>

<a href="http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=o3584gJELBI">Approximately 50 hours of never before heard grassroots Voices from Across the Country.</a>

Heard by over a million people online

<a href="http://indiaunheard.videovolunteers.org/my-videos-my-voice-my-people/">Seen by more than 300,000 people in live outdoor screenings in slums and villages</a>

<a href="http://indiaunheard.videovolunteers.org/impact-iu-correspondent-puts-timber-mafia-behind-bars/">17,000 villagers and slumdwellers have taken concrete action towards social change after seeing our films</a>

Bringing direct benefit to more than 600,000 people

<a href="http://indiaunheard.videovolunteers.org/community-video-brings-wage-equality/">600 women farm labourers in rural Maharashtra began receiving equal pay after years of gender discrimination in wages</a>

<a href="http://indiaunheard.videovolunteers.org/indiaunheard-impact-corruption-ends-in-school/">Over 1000 children in rural Jharkhand have started receiving better quality education</a>

<a href="http://www.change.org/en-IN/petitions/40-fluorosis-victims-in-north-gujarat-get-free-medication-and-better-water-supply-provisions">40 fluorosis victims in Rural Gujarat have started getting regular treatment</a>

<a href="http://indiaunheard.videovolunteers.org/iu-impact-community-journalism-helps-promote-organic-farming/">8 villages in Rajasthan have shifted to organic farming practices after watching a video.</a>

<a href="http://indiaunheard.videovolunteers.org/videoactivist-brings-education-to-all/">Schools have been built for children of migrant workers in Haryana.</a>

<a href="http://indiaunheard.videovolunteers.org/help-end-pds-corruption-in-rural-jharkhand/">Over 200 families have started receiving their rations on time.</a>

<a href="http://www.change.org/en-IN/petitions/untouchability-abolished-in-dangariya-rajasthan">A video succeeds in bringing to light and ending 2000 year of untouchability practices in a Rajasthan village.</a>

<a href="http://indiaunheard.videovolunteers.org/all-work-and-no-pay-for-jharkhand-teachers/">In 7 days, a video on 2 teachers in Rural Jharkhand who were working unpaid for 4 years got them compensation of Rs. 90, 000/- each. Today they are receiving their monthly wages</a>.

<a href="http://indiaunheard.videovolunteers.org/teachers-in-jharkhand-breathe-a-sigh-of-relief/">You saw our video on the 2 teachers in rural Jharkhand. You made 800 calls in less then 2 days to the DC of HazariBaug.</a>

We Couldn't Do It Without You!]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title></title>
		<link>http://www.videovolunteers.org/?p=2696</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>vvadmin</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.videovolunteers.org/?p=2696</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Today we declare victory on a petition we started 3 months ago !!!

<a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/IMG_9221-1.jpg"><img class="alignleft size-medium wp-image-2697" title="IMG_9221 (1)" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/IMG_9221-1-300x200.jpg" alt="" width="300" height="200" /></a>

<a href="http://www.change.org/en-IN/petitions/rajasthan-state-pollution-control-board-shut-down-asphalt-factories-in-karauli-rajasthan" target="_blank">http://www.change.org/en-IN/<wbr>petitions/rajasthan-state-</wbr><wbr>pollution-control-board-shut-</wbr><wbr>down-asphalt-factories-in-</wbr><wbr>karauli-rajasthan</wbr></a>

In April 2012, India Unheard community correspondent Sunita Kasera made a video<a href="http://youtu.be/xBTxM0h0kLM" target="_blank">Cancerous dust smothers rural Rajasthan</a>. Seeing the blatant violation of licensing and pollution control norms and the fact that we had possession of an official letter from the Bharathpur Regional office of the RSPCB, stating that this particular plant along with 4 others had been functioning illegally , we knew we had a water tight case.

<!--more-->

<iframe src="http://www.youtube.com/embed/xBTxM0h0kLM" frameborder="0" width="560" height="315"></iframe>

We started the petition through Change.org and targeted the Member Secretary of the Rajasthan State Pollution Control Board. Mr. Pandey received thousands of emails through the petition and numerous calls from Tamseel (Change.org) and myself over the course of 3 months. Sunita backed us up with follow up on the ground with officers at the Regional Offices and even the DC of Karauli and Sewai Madhopur (a little).

After weeks of notices been sent out and waiting for the parties to respond, we now have confirmation from the RSPCB that all 5 factories have been shut down for non compliance with licensing norms and pollution control norms!

Sunita says " Working together with the Change.org and the Video Volunteers team has meant that I was able to show the authorities we will not give up and that we have supporters from all over the country. It would not have been possible without the support of the people who signed the petition and our team."

This victory is especially sweet for me because it showcases how using the law/ rules to strengthen your case will definitely lead to results. When there is merit in your claims, people will stand by you.

I would also like to extend our gratitude to the Member Secretary for being gracious and proactive in our interactions with his office. This victory would not have been possible without officials such as Mr. Pandey, Member Secretary, RSPCB and Officers of the Regional Office, Bharathpur, Rajasthan.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Community Correspondents (Page 3)</title>
		<link>http://www.videovolunteers.org/programmes/indiaunheard/community-corespondents-page-3/</link>
		<pubDate>Sat, 01 Dec 2012 15:23:55 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>vvadmin</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.videovolunteers.org/?page_id=2726</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p style="text-align: center;"><strong>IndiaUnheard Community Correspondents</strong></p>
<p style="text-align: center;"><a href="http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.videovolunteers.org%2Fprogrammes%2Findiaunheard%2Fcommunity-correspondents-2%2F&amp;sa=D&amp;sntz=1&amp;usg=AFQjCNGqm8EORB0JEmRu0JijwyVuMHJaOw" target="_blank">Page 1</a>,<a href="http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.videovolunteers.org%2Fprogrammes%2Findiaunheard%2Fcommunity-correspondents-page-2%2F&amp;sa=D&amp;sntz=1&amp;usg=AFQjCNEhHoj-JrvrVzPb2aXA7Jh4dykvrQ" target="_blank">Page 2</a>,<a href="http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.videovolunteers.org%2Fprogrammes%2Findiaunheard%2Fcommunity-corespondents-page-3%2F&amp;sa=D&amp;sntz=1&amp;usg=AFQjCNG1xBuqmmurAd6naQDKdFCB_56IpA" target="_blank">Page 3</a></p>
<a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/Shripati.jpg"><img class="alignleft  wp-image-2727" title="Shripati" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/Shripati-150x150.jpg" alt="" width="105" height="105" /></a>

<strong>Shripati Sinko, Odisha</strong>

Shripati Sinko is an adivasi activist from Angul district Odisha. He feels that government officials often look down on adivasis and therefore deny them basic rights such as education and healthcare. When the adivasis try to claim these rights, their protests fall on deaf ears. Shripati was inspired to join the India Unheard platform to take the work of his movement further. After the training he feels that he can make videos that will force the officials to listen to what his people have to say and take action.

<a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/Anupama.jpg"><img class="alignleft  wp-image-2728" title="Anupama" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/Anupama-150x150.jpg" alt="" width="105" height="105" /></a>

<strong>Anupama Sathi, Odisha</strong>

Anupama Sathi is a Community Correspondent from Jagatsinghpur district Odisha. She has been involved in helping organisations and students file RTIs in her area. She feels that her involvement in organisations like Mahila Ayog, a womens rights group, has given a massive boost to her self-confidence. On the India Unheard platform, she wants to make videos that highlight community level problems such as corruption and government inefficiency.

<a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/Rangadhar.jpg"><img class="alignleft  wp-image-2729" title="Rangadhar" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/Rangadhar-150x150.jpg" alt="" width="105" height="105" /></a>

<strong>Rangadhar Mahapatra, Odisha</strong>

Rangadhar Mahapatra is our IndiaUnheard Community Correspondent from Jagatsinghpur district Odisha. A few years ago he along with his village faced the prospect of being homeless. Since then he has been involved in a peoples movement which fights for peoples land rights. He wants to publicise issues that are in the villagers interest and sees video as a potent tool to do this.

<a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/Neetu.jpg"><img class="alignleft  wp-image-2730" title="Neetu" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/Neetu-150x150.jpg" alt="" width="105" height="105" /></a>

<strong>Nitu Chakiya, Odisha</strong>

Nitu Chakiyas primary area of interest is working with slum communities to help them deal with the problems they face regarding electricity, roads, water and drainage. She says that though political leaders claim that they have done work in these communities, the reality is different. She wants to document issues that have been neglected for years by the other media.

<a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/Dashariti.jpg"><img class="alignleft  wp-image-2731" title="Dashariti" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/Dashariti-150x150.jpg" alt="" width="105" height="105" /></a>

<strong>Dashrathi Behera, Odisha</strong>

Dashrathi Behera is an activist from Deogarh district, Odisha. He works on issues like farmers rights and wants to make videos that help take forward their cause. He is looking forward to using the skills that he has gained at the recent VV training, where he was able to exchange ideas with activists like him,, to bring the voices of his people to a wider public.

<a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/Purnachandra.jpg"><img class="alignleft  wp-image-2732" title="Purnachandra" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/Purnachandra-150x150.jpg" alt="" width="105" height="105" /></a>

<strong>Purna Chandra Nayak, Odisha</strong>

Purna Chandra Nayak is our IndiaUnheard Community correspondent from Sundargarh District, Odisha. He has been involved in social work with adivasis and Dalits for some time now and is proud that he has been able to use his education and exposure for this. The media, he says,doesn'tgo into the interiors of the country to report the issues there. He wants to change this situation and wants to make videos that reflect issues that are relevant to his community.

<strong>
<a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/IMAG0001.jpg"><img class="alignleft  wp-image-2748" title="IMAG0001" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/IMAG0001-150x150.jpg" alt="" width="105" height="105" /></a>Amit Topno, Jharkhand</strong>

In the escalating conflict between a draconian state and violent insurgency, Amit Topno believes that the ones who lose out most are the innocents caught in between. Amit is an adivasi inhabitant of the conflict-prone region of Khunti. He has witnessed a million violations that the state and insurgents have committed in the name of development and freedom[. It is a difficult region to work in but Amit has a decades worth of experience as a grassroots organizer and leader. As a Community Correspondent he says that it will be his responsibility that these injustices are heard, understood and redressed. You can watch Amit's video <a href="http://indiaunheard.videovolunteers.org/?s=amit+topno&amp;x=51&amp;y=25">here</a>.

<a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/Rejan.jpg"><img class="alignleft  wp-image-2749" title="Rejan" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/Rejan-150x150.jpg" alt="" width="105" height="105" /></a>

<strong>Rejan Gudia, Jharkhand</strong>

Rejan Gudia was born into conflict. His village was one of those threatened to be submerged by the Koel Karo dam project. His childhood was spent as a participant in the protest marches and sit-ins. At the age of 15 he became a card carrying member of the same popular movement. With his commitment to the cause, he rose in the ranks until he became the chief secretary of the movement which even after four decades, has successfully held off the government and its dubious development projects. Rejan believes that his videos document that spirit of his communitys struggle for their rights and identity. Watch Rejan's videos <a href="http://indiaunheard.videovolunteers.org/?s=rejan&amp;x=0&amp;y=0">here</a>.

<a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/AmitaTutti.jpg"><img class="alignleft  wp-image-2734" title="AmitaTutti" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/AmitaTutti-150x150.jpg" alt="" width="105" height="105" /></a>

<strong>Amita Tute, Jharkhand</strong>

Amita Tute is an adivasi activist from the Red Corridor in District Khunti, Jharkhand. She says she has lived a hard life and struggled to make ends meet. She had an awakening of social consciousness when she realized that struggle for food, clothes and shelter is also a struggle against corruption, injustice and apathy. For the last few years, she has been anintegralpart of the Jharkhand Jungle Bachao Andolan as a grassroots crusader for forest and tribal rights in her region. Amita has been instrumental in safeguarding and asserting the rights of the many innocents in her village who are constantly accused of being 'naxalites' or 'sympathetic' to the naxalite cause. Watch Amita's videos <a href="http://indiaunheard.videovolunteers.org/?s=amita&amp;x=0&amp;y=0">here</a>.

<a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/303955_10152087183570542_445990328_n3.jpg"><img class="alignleft  wp-image-2750" title="303955_10152087183570542_445990328_n3" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/303955_10152087183570542_445990328_n3-150x150.jpg" alt="" width="105" height="105" /></a>

<strong>Neeru Rathod, Gujarat</strong>

Neeru Rathod is the 8th child in a family of 11 girls born to a Dalit construction worker in Surendranagar district of Gujarat, one of the most feudal and caste-ridden regions of India. Circumstances were difficult growing up but she found her path in 2006, when Video Volunteers and the NGO Navsarjan selected her to be part of a Community Video Unit. As part of the Community Video Unit, Neeru found her vocation and passion. She became an expert producer and committed video activist, seeking to set right the social issues that she was highlighting and leading hundreds of people in protest. She has conducted hundreds of village video screenings, speaking into a microphone in front of a huge screen late in the evening to thousands of men, shattering their ideas about what a woman and a Dalit can do. Her work has brought water, roads, electricity  sea change to villages in her district. She has also made videos on sensitive issues like the AIDS epidemic and single women in rural India.

<a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/IMAG0064.jpg"><img class="alignleft  wp-image-2752" title="IMAG0064" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/IMAG0064-150x150.jpg" alt="" width="105" height="105" /></a>

<strong>Sanjay Parmar, Gujarat</strong>

Sanjay Parmar belongs to the Dalit Community. He found his passion in video and social change when he was trained by Video Volunteers and the NGO Navsarjan to be part of a Videoshala Education Community Video Unit. Sanjay began to use videos as an educational tool to teach and empower dalit children in his community. Later, he began to actively document continuing practices of untouchability and everyday discrimination against Dalits. He screens these videos back to his community and tries to get his people to talk about the 3000 year old atrocity that continues to oppress and stifle them. Watch his videos <a href="http://indiaunheard.videovolunteers.org/?s=sanjay+parmar&amp;x=0&amp;y=0">here</a>.

<a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/Jogendra-Singh.jpg"><img class="alignleft  wp-image-2753" title="Jogendra Singh" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/Jogendra-Singh-150x150.jpg" alt="" width="105" height="105" /></a>

<strong>Jogendra Singh, Kanpur</strong>

The slums of Kanpur were where Jogendra Singh was born and brought up. It was difficult but Jogendra calls himself a persistent and even stubborn individual. Against all odds, he completed his education with a masters degree in social service. He then returned to give back to his community and his people. He started by helping the children of the slum with their education. As an IndiaUnheard correspondent he speaks for the long due recognition of their fundamental rights. Watch his videos <a href="http://indiaunheard.videovolunteers.org/?s=jogendra&amp;x=0&amp;y=0">here</a>.

<strong><a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/Shankarlal-Raikwar.jpg"><img class="alignleft  wp-image-2754" title="Shankarlal Raikwar" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/Shankarlal-Raikwar-150x150.jpg" alt="" width="105" height="105" /></a>Shankarlal Raikwar, Uttar Pradesh</strong>

Shankarlal Raikwar belongs to a community that dances at festivals and carnivals for a living. Shankarlal is an expert in performing feminine roles especially from mythological texts like the Mahabharata. He is proud of his art but unfortunately it makes him a point of ridicule in society. He is also worried about getting older, and about the ridicule his children may face as other children learn of his dancing profession. He looks at IndiaUnheard as a new beginning, a platform that he intends to use to spotlight the issues of marginalized and ostracized communities like the one he belongs to.Watch his videos <a href="http://indiaunheard.videovolunteers.org/?s=shankarlal&amp;x=0&amp;y=0">here</a>.

<a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/programmes/indiaunheard/community-correspondents-page-2/">Click here for previous page</a>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Coordinator (Training and Mentoring) </title>
		<link>http://www.videovolunteers.org/about/work-with-us/coordinator-training-and-mentoring/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 01 Feb 2013 10:45:37 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>vvadmin</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.videovolunteers.org/?page_id=2831</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<strong>Co-ordinator (Training and Mentoring)</strong>

Video Volunteers is seeking a Coordinator (Training and Mentoring).The person would be responsible for building and supporting the growth of a vibrant Community Correspondent network across different states of India and strengthening the position of video volunteers as a key human rights and media organization representing issues of social justice, rights and entitlements, human rights violations. The coordinator will train, mentor and provide all issue based and technical support needed for the community correspondents on a day to day basis for producing videos and creating positive change in the communities they live in.

&nbsp;

<strong></strong><strong>Key responsibilities:</strong>

<strong>1.</strong><strong>Coordination with community correspondent network</strong>
<ul>
	<li>Mentor community correspondents on all aspects of conceptualization, production and dissemination of videos/information.</li>
	<li>Train potential CCs as trainers and mentors.</li>
	<li>Communicate/coordinate regularly with the state coordinators, editors and community correspondents.</li>
	<li>Coordinate with the impacts manager in following up with all impact stories and work with the state advocacy coordinators or directly with key decision makers  at the village, district, state levels  who can take action and draw up an impacts, lobbying and advocacy plan as suited for the issue.</li>
	<li>Ensure that community correspondents are supported in engaging with communities in a two way process of information sharing using participatory ways of working.</li>
	<li>Manage program MIS: Maintain all documentation related to production of stories, tracking impact and all other data pertaining to our community correspondents.</li>
	<li>Research on key issues that we work on.</li>
</ul>
<strong>2. Advocacy &amp; Networking</strong><strong></strong>
<ul>
	<li>Identify potential impacts from all the videos, either locally or nationally and discuss on how to maximize this with the State advocacy manager and Impacts manager.</li>
	<li>Contribute to designing and implementing an advocacy plan for the different states on identified issues in consultation with the Impacts Manager.</li>
	<li>Contribute to designing and implementing campaign ideas on the identified issues</li>
</ul>
<strong>3. Other coordination </strong>
<ul>
	<li>Assist in communications and fundraising and partnerships work as and when required</li>
	<li>Upload the daily IndiaUnheard video/write articles and blogs when required</li>
	<li>Coordinate workshops, conferences and meetings for recruitment, training, partnership and funding related work</li>
	<li>Assist in office management and handle admin for the program as and when required</li>
</ul>
&nbsp;

<strong>Qualifications/Experience</strong>: Atleast 2-3 years experience in the development sector. Must have great communication skills and interested in working with communities. Experience with community media will be an added advantage.

To apply, please fill in an online application from <strong><a href="http://videovolunteersindia.wufoo.com/forms/video-volunteers-online-job-application/">here</a></strong>.]]></content:encoded>
