	</item>
	<item>
		<title>Support Acid Attack Survivor Chanchal&#039;s Fight for Justice</title>
		<link>http://www.videovolunteers.org/support-acid-attack-survivor-chanchals-fight-for-justice/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 04 Mar 2013 13:02:02 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>vvadmin</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.videovolunteers.org/?p=2936</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<b>On 21/10/2012, four men threw acid on Chanchal Paswan, 19 and her sister, 15 while they were asleep on their terrace.</b> The attack was a direct result of Chanchals opposition to continuous sexual harassment by the men. <strong>The below video report</strong><b>by Video Volunteers Community Correspondent and womens rights activist, Varsha Jawalgekar shows</b> <b>Chanchal and her family talking about the incident. They want their appeal for justice to go public.</b>

<iframe src="http://www.youtube.com/embed/6oBpqgFsOfY" height="315" width="560" allowfullscreen="" frameborder="0"></iframe>

&nbsp;

Anil, Ghanshyam, Baadal and Raj had been harassing Chanchal and her family for a long time. They would follow her on the streets, in auto-rickshaws, would pass vulgar comments and sexuallyharass her. When she refused to give in to their demands, they threw acid on her.

The <b>four perpetrators have been arrested by the police</b>.Chanchal is 19 years old and an earning member of the family. Almost five months after the incident the Paswan family is still waiting for a speedy trial. They also spending money on Chanchal's medicines, instead of the state and both the sisters have got less compensation than they deserve- because the police hasn't taken her official statement under section 164 yet.

<b>For the last four months the Paswan family has been waiting for justice, going from one court to another, Chanchal needs your support in getting speedy justice and compensation.</b>Especially in light of the fact that after the Justice Verma Committee report and last years Delhi gang rape case, the Chief Justice of India has asked for stricter laws against women atrocities.

The video report by Video Volunteers Community Correspondent and womens rights activist, Varsha Jawalgekar was used to launch an online petition in partnership with Change.org (<a href="http://www.change.org/en-IN/petitions/dm-patna-ensure-justice-for-chanchal-paswan-chanchalacidattack">DM Patna: ensure justice for Chanchal Paswan</a>). The petition has received more than 28000 signatures from all over the world. Chanchal wishes to fight for justice and Video Volunteers along with local advocacy groups like <i>Parivarthan Jan Andolan, Parivarthan Kendra</i> and Change.org, amongst others will stand by her.

<a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/support-us/donate-for-chanchal/"><b>PLEASE DONATE TO SUPPORT CHANCHAL'S FIGHT FOR JUSTICE BY FOLLOWING THIS LINK</b></a>

On the 6th of March, Chanchal and her family addressed a press conference in Patna, Bihar. The press conference, organized by VideoVolunteers, Parivarthan Jan Andolan and Change.org, was attended by over 40 journalists from print and electronic media. Here is what Chanchal had to say.

<iframe src="http://www.youtube.com/embed/eZBh3jmiPwo?list=UU6Q4keA57cC0kPU8rQQG2CA" height="315" width="560" allowfullscreen="" frameborder="0"></iframe>

&nbsp;

<b>Chanchal's Current Medical Status:</b>
1. PMCH has done a very basic skin graft, which has not healed properly.

2. Her eyes are stretched, as the grafting was not properly done. She cannot close her eyes properly.

3. On her neck, the burnt tissue has formed a mass and wound.

4. The wound on her chest are still serious and the ones on her back have not healed.

5. PMCH discharged her at the end of January 2013 hurriedly. They even misguided the family saying she will get infection in the hospital. They did this, as there was increasing pressure on them by <i>Parivartan Jan Andolan/ Parivartan Kendra </i>and on the police as well.

6. Chanchals family has been purchasing medication with their limited finances ever since the incident. On 2nd March, Varsha Jawalgekar and other activists visited PMCH and asked why the hospital was not able to provide Chanchal and her sister the medication that they had prescribed. After much discussion with local medical representatives (who take commission on sale of medication), they forced the administration to give Chanchal's parents some of the prescribed medications free of cost.

7. The family has been receiving threats from some people in the community and have been unable to resume their livelihood activities.

<b>B. Current Status of Chanchal's case with Police and Court:</b>
1. We have reports from reliable sources that the DIG, Weaker Sections, has given directions to the police station not to take Chanchals statement under Section 164.

2. Chanchal has been treated as a minor when she is a major and also treated as a non-earner when she was an earning member of her family. By misrepresenting her age and earning capacity, the state has awarded her less compensation than what she is entitled to under the SC/ST Prevention of Atrocities Act.

3. There has been no direction from the Police to the Court recommending Chanchals case for a speedy trial.

4. Chanchal's father, Shailesh Paswan has tried to follow up on the case in Court. The Danapur Magistrates Court said it has been transferred to the District Court. When he reached the District court, they said it is still with the lower court. Till date, there is no trace of Chanchals case file.

<b>Immediate Intervention Required:</b>
1. Chanchals statement must be recorded under Section 164, as it will ensure that the names of the accused are included in the FIR. Her previous statement was recorded just after the attack when she was in too much pain to speak clearly and name her attackers.

2. The case must be sent for swift trial.

3. Funds need to be raised for Chanchals treatment, plastic surgery and legal fees.

4. The Court and the State must ensure proper compensation and rehabilitation for Chanchal and her family.

Many have offered various forms of support to Chanchals family. But more needs to be done.It is with this in mind that we are trying to <a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/support-us/donate-for-chanchal/">mobilise more resources</a> for Chanchal her sister and her family. We hope you will join us in doing so.

&nbsp;]]></content:encoded>

		<wp:post_id>2936</wp:post_id>

		<wp:post_date_gmt>2013-03-04 13:02:02</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>closed</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>support-acid-attack-survivor-chanchals-fight-for-justice</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>publish</wp:status>

		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>Bringing Change, One Video at a Time</title>
		<link>http://www.videovolunteers.org/bringing-change-one-video-at-a-time/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 08 Mar 2013 06:59:19 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>vvadmin</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.videovolunteers.org/?p=2964</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Every year on Womens Day, in Karauli District, in Indias Rajsthan, the state transport authority allows women to travel for free wherever they want.

Women leap at the opportunity to leave their husbands at home and go out. In an otherwise deeply chauvinistic society this is one of those rare days when the ladies get a taste of empowerment, says community correspondent Sunita Kasera who lives in Karauli and made a video on this last year.

What does it mean to be an empowered woman? Is it the ability to go out and earn? Is it the freedom to speak your mind? Is a woman who has these two but is sexually harassed every time she walks out on the street empowered?

At <a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/">Video Volunteers</a>, we have been mulling over these questions this week. As a human rights and media NGO we see some pretty hard hitting material but few have touched us like the recent story of an acid attack survivor, Chanchal, which we have been reporting on for three weeks now.

On 21 October, 2012, four men threw acid on Chanchal, 19, and her sister, 15, while they were asleep.

This was a direct result of Chanchal's bold move to oppose continuous sexual harassment by these men who belong to a 'higher caste' than her. Five months later, the girls and their family are still waiting for justicethey havent received adequate description, the state hasnt covered their medical bills, and the police still havent taken an official statement from them. Despite this, Chanchal refuses to give up.

<iframe src="http://www.youtube.com/embed/g1v68W3ckes" height="315" width="420" allowfullscreen="" frameborder="0"></iframe>

In this video she speaks out and demands justice for herself.

Varsha Jawalgekar, a community journalist and womens rights activist made a video report in January 2013documenting the trauma faced by the Paswan family.

<iframe src="http://www.youtube.com/embed/6oBpqgFsOfY" height="315" width="420" allowfullscreen="" frameborder="0"></iframe>

Varsha started working as a community correspondent with Video Volunteers in 2010. Having emerged victorious from a bitter personal battle against domestic violence, she now makes videos about womens issues and ensures that no other woman is silenced like she had been.

Varsha and Chanchal are just two women we have had the privilege of working with over the last 6 years at Video Volunteers. Gender has been at the heart of VVs work since the beginning.

&nbsp;

One of our earliest projects was to train 11 rural women who had all been married as children to make a film on child marriage.

<iframe src="http://www.youtube.com/embed/ke3SHTmKilw" height="315" width="420" allowfullscreen="" frameborder="0"></iframe>

The video was screened in their villages on wide screen projectors.

Nearly all of us women were married as children. Yet none of us have ever spoken about it before tonight, said one of our community producers as she spoke to the 800 people in her village who had come to see the film.

This video and project were the beginning of Video Volunteers' Community Video Unit Program. Within about 10 months, six more had been launched across India. It was the beginning of a spectacular journey for all involved, one that were still on.

Women's issues are hardly talked about in public forums in villages. Community media can change this.

Community media has a special power because those who make the content have almost always personally experienced what they document. This empathy adds an authenticity, urgency and a personal perspective, which makes it very different from traditional journalism.

Female correspondents find that women in their communities feel comfortable talking to them as they feel that the journalists can relate to them. Here are some issues that our women correspondents have reported on.

<b>Child Marriage</b>

Rohini Pawar, VVs community correspondent in Walhe district, Maharashtra, was only 15 when she got married. She didnt want to. For the longest time she had hoped to study and become a doctor.

I felt all my dreams would crash and end there but I was lucky in that I had good in-laws. Being 15 and married is not easy, she says. I was scared, everything was different. I wanted to make sure that other girls didnt have to face the same problems.

Now working not only as a correspondent but also as a video trainer and mentor of newer community correspondents, she says: I want to change things in my society for women-- get them equal wages, stop child marriages, help them speak up and stand up for themselves.

And shes done just that. With each video that she has made she has ensured that the voices of the women in her community are heard and taken on board.

<iframe src="http://www.youtube.com/embed/ItiQGV5kg28" height="315" width="420" allowfullscreen="" frameborder="0"></iframe>

In her video, Child Brides in Maharashtra,she interviews two girls who recently saw their friend getting married. Both are thankful that it wasn't them. Rohini hopes that in time more people will become more aware of the problems of child marriage and that they will stop.

<b>Women in politics</b>

There are countless women in India who have broken out of the roles that society had cast for them. Some have become community journalists, others village chiefs.

The Village councils in India are primary levels of governance in the country. While there are many instances where women have become heads of these Councils, their decisions are often governed by the men in their family.

Community Correspondent Bhan Sahu, from the Rajnandgaon district of Chhattisgarh, went in search of a female village head who had stepped out of the shadows of familial pressure.

<iframe src="http://www.youtube.com/embed/Tur5TiK6Rc8" height="315" width="420" allowfullscreen="" frameborder="0"></iframe>

Woman Sarpanch Brings Change to Rural India<b></b>is the story of Sukhvanti Bai, a Gond tribal woman who represents 300 villagers in Handitola, in Chhattisgarh state. She has become a well-respected community member who has established her reputation as someone who doesnt mince her words and reaches her goals against all odds.

When she sees problems, she will find a way to solve them. It is this self-confidence that women need, so that they can act on their own terms without being influenced by their husbands or other people, Bhan says.

I hope that women will see that their voice is important to the community...I have certainly been deeply touched and inspired by Sukhvanti'scourage and self-reliance.

&nbsp;

<b>Inspiring others</b>

Sunita Kasera is one our most active community correspondents and has been instrumental in bringing massive changes to her district Karauli, in Rajasthan.

Her video Citizen Journalist Turns Symbol of Women's Hope' documents how Sunita helped a group of women, who were former bootleggers, get money they had been promised by the government to start a new business.

<iframe src="http://www.youtube.com/embed/UTdRksS-mAc" height="315" width="420" allowfullscreen="" frameborder="0"></iframe>

Sunita was probably one of the first women to enter the excise office in Karauli, a deeply chauvinistic society. She has repeatedly walked into public offices, demanded co-operation from officials and received it.

As Video Volunteers builds up a network of community correspondents across India, we have strived to ensure that women make up half the numbers.

At the moment 33 percent of our correspondents are women but we find that on an average they make more videos per month than the male correspondents.

One reason for this is probably the fact that being given the opportunity to speak out is that much more important for women and that much more transformative, given how long they have been silenced.

With each video they make, they change stereotypical ideas about what rural women in India are like. They come a little a little closer to achieving their goal of extending that empowerment to other women like themselves.

&nbsp;]]></content:encoded>

			<wp:comment_author_email></wp:comment_author_email>
			<wp:comment_author_url>http://indiaunheard.videovolunteers.org/changing-attitudes-on-child-marriage/</wp:comment_author_url>
			<wp:comment_author_IP>64.79.88.42</wp:comment_author_IP>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>Spotting the Story: Learning to identify issues in the community through IndiaUnheard training</title>
		<link>http://www.videovolunteers.org/spotting-the-story-learning-to-identify-issues-in-the-community-through-indiaunheard-training/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 07 Mar 2011 05:03:35 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.videovolunteers.org/?p=1999</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<strong>VV's IndiaUnheard produces videos on 11 themes: Art&amp;Culture, Corruption, Conflict, Caste&amp;Identity, Development, Education, Environment, Gender, Health, Infrastructure and Technology. At the ongoing IndiaUnheard training camp, director Stalin K has been conducting a common session every morning that is based on one of these themes. During the session, he trains the CCs in identifying stories related to the theme and its multiple sub themes in their own communities. Often, the discussion turns into a self-discovery for the CCs. Here is a narrative of the session on Art&amp; Culture. <a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2011/03/2-20-IU-Camp-Day-2-038.jpg"><img class="alignleft size-medium wp-image-2000" style="margin: 5px; border: 5px solid black;" title="2-20 IU Camp Day 2 038" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2011/03/2-20-IU-Camp-Day-2-038-300x225.jpg" alt="" width="340" height="300" /></a>
</strong>

The mornings common session on Art&amp; Culture begins with the screening of a video on the same theme. It is a video by IndiaUnheard CC Roshan Saroliya. Titled Tribals Seek Harmony, the video is about certain tribal rituals practiced by Roshan's community. Stalin wants to know if the CCs like the video. Most of them say not quite. Why? asks Stalin. The CCs repliy, Because the video was incomplete. From intro to end, it felt as though there was more to say than what was shown.

So, how would you make it differently? asks Stalin again.

Anand Pagare, a CC from Nashik, Maharashtra says that he would show why it was important to preserve the tribal culture. You will also need to explain how the cultural customs of the tribal communities bind people together, Stalin adds. Everyone nods in agreement to that.

Next, the CCs watch a video by Rohini Pawar. It is the video about the Potraj community. According to the government, the Potraj people do not exist as no census has ever included them. Therefore, the community is totally left out of any government  scheme.  Like nomads, they move from place to place, performing on the street and begging.

Do you have nomadic tribes in your area? Stalin wants to know. They take a minute or two before saying yes. Pandu Maddala, the CC from Hyderabad is very quiet. Were there no nomads in his area? First, he says no. But when Stalin asks if there are people wearing colorful clothes, speaking a mix of Gujarati and Telugu and doing odd jobs in his locality, Pandu smiles and says oh yes! There are gypsies! Well the gypsies are the nomadic tribes, explains Stalin. At this, Pandu comes out with names of 4 gypsy communities!

The video screened next is Renchanos Wave of Korean culture in Nagaland. The video has been watched by over 20,000 viewers across the globe and has caught the attention of a number of bloggers and journalists. Surprisingly though, the CCs find it an ok video. The reason? Most of them cant relate to the video. However, the CCs from NE states look amused, as though they just watched themselves on the tv screen. When Stalin asks if they also watch Korean channel at home, they say yes. Why? Because they are realistic, they reply.  Do they ever watch Hindi serials like the saas-bahu saga? No, they say, and add they feel so alien. Stalin explains, its because of the physical and the cultural resemblance.

The next video of the day is Devidas Gaonkars video on tribal womens dance. In the video tribal women celebrate Dillo  a festival. On the day they sing, dance and play different games  things that otherwise considered a taboo. The CCs find the video fascinating. They notice the great B-rolls, the ambience, the interviews and the celebration. Can you tell me one technical difference between this video and the video of Rohini? They think hard, but cant name any. Its the ambience, Stalin explains, In Devidas video, you can hear the women laugh, sing and shout. So, you can feel the environment. But, in Rohinis video you cant even hear the whip rising and falling. That is because Rohini spoke while shooting the B-rolls. So, when you take your B-rolls, remember not to speak in between. Otherwise, the editor has to edit the sound out.

The screening being over, the discussion now moves to listing of the sub themes under Art&amp; Culture. The broad categories are Music, Dance, Painting, Performance and Traditional attire.

<a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2011/03/art-n-culture.jpg"><img class="alignleft size-medium wp-image-2004" style="margin: 5px; border: 5px solid black;" title="art n culture" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2011/03/art-n-culture-300x201.jpg" alt="" width="300" height="201" /></a>Surprisingly, when Stalin asks them to name different types of music, CCs cant think of more than 1 or 2. This helps them realize that the theme that they thought they knew well was actually the least known of all. Another realization hits them: They probably needed to develop a deeper connection with their communities.

Stalin now asks the CCs to think of the names separately. Which songs do you sing when a child is born? What do you hear people sing when someone dies? Do people repeat the same songs when someone is getting married or when they work in the farms?
The next questions are, what are the different dances? Do men and women dance in similar style, or are their different dance styles? When someone in community sings or dances, what musical instrument is played? What are these instruments made of? Wood? Bamboo? leather?

Now, the CCs have so much to say. Information starts to flow out as they come up with name after name. They also seem to enjoy this whole process of rediscovering their own communities and almost everyone starts to smile now.

Next Stalin moves on to festivals and celebrations. Most CCs are now feeling very active. Each one of them can remember about 10 festivals. Stalin asks them, do you celebrate it personally? Yes, they say. So, Stalin tells them you know the names, because you are personally connected to them.

Next, Stalin asks the CCs to name the traditional occupations that their communities practice. Anupama Das of Assam says, There were many occupations once. But they are not practiced anymore. Stalin points at the gamocha - a hand woven cotton shawl wrapped around his neck. The gamocha is one of the symbols of the Assamese culture. Who do you think of this gamocha? Where do you think it came from? he asks. At this, Any exclaims, yes! There is the gamocha! Who makes them? Women, says Anu and smiles broadly. Now, before anyone could say anything, she spells out half a dozen occupations: Weaving, pottery, bamboo craft, cane craft, fishing and, to everyones amusement, elephant catching.

The last occupation helps the CCs to think of the uniqueness in their communities. Mercy Kamei of Manipur reads out a list that includes bone-drying and poison making. The bone drier dries the head of a buffalo or a barasinga deer that the community members hang above their doors. The poison maker makes the poison of local herbs that the tribesmen use in hunting. The later throws light the unique identity of Mercys tribe: They are the Rongmei Nagas, a hunter tribe.

<a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2011/03/stalin-in-art-n-culture.jpg"><img class="alignleft size-medium wp-image-2005" style="margin: 5px; border: 5px solid black;" title="stalin in art n culture" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2011/03/stalin-in-art-n-culture-300x195.jpg" alt="" width="300" height="195" /></a>Finally, Stalin asks the CCs to go through their respective list of the occupations and pick up one for making a video. Kumar Mukesh of Haryana has one: In Haryana, on the day of Holi (the festival of colors), women chase men up and whip them. Most of these women are victims of domestic violence. All through the year, they are often beaten up by their husbands. On Holi, they let their anger out, explains Mukesh. Mercy Kamei is fascinated with the idea. She tells Mukesh, Please, let me have a copy of the video as soon as you make it. I want to show it to everyone in my community, she sounds very sincere. Why do you want to do this, Mercy?, asks Stalin.

Mercy replies, In my community, women are treated very badly. We are not allowed to be in the village panchayat. If we ever go to the panchayat with a complaint, men tell us, shut up woman, you know nothing. We are humiliated like this very often. I want to show Mukeshs video and tell them to beware. Though she says this with a smile, the pain is clear enough to be felt by all.

Stalin wraps up the session by asking each CC to cap that emotion in the video. Save that anger and the joy. Let it out in your video, so viewers can feel it, he adds.

- <strong>Stella Paul</strong>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Echoes Of Gender Equality In IndiaUnheard Training</title>
		<link>http://www.videovolunteers.org/echoes-of-gender-equality-in-indiaunheard-training/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 08 Mar 2011 09:35:32 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.videovolunteers.org/?p=2006</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2011/03/Equality.jpg"><img class="alignleft size-medium wp-image-2007" style="margin: 5px; border: 5px solid black;" title="Equality" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2011/03/Equality-300x200.jpg" alt="" width="400" height="300" /></a>Todays morning session was on gender, a subject very important to Stalin, who is leading the training. His own mother was a victimof domestic violence, and he says quietly to the group, if youve seen your own mother dodging a flying plate at the age of three, you cant help but become a feminist.

Stalin opens the session by asking the Community Correspondents whether they think men and women are equal. The male CCs remain silent, while the women answerpositively.

So, Stalin starts explaining what he meant. When he is talking about equality, CCs should not understand it as sameness. Equality does not mean physical equality, but equal opportunity, equal rights, equal probity.

Stalin then asks them to think about who grants them these equal rights, to which Amol answered, We do. As an answer, Stalin writes on the board the first three words of the Indian constitution, We, the people, and then asks what was the difference between We and Us. Sajad Rsool  a Community Correspondent from Kashmir, answered that We is inclusive, whereas us may also be restricted to a group. <a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2011/03/110303_02.jpg"><img class="alignleft size-medium wp-image-2009" style="margin: 5px; border: 5px solid black;" title="110303_02" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2011/03/110303_02-300x207.jpg" alt="" width="400" height="300" /></a>

Here, Stalin explains the impact that using We has, in terms of rights, for every Indian citizens. Indeed, using We means a complete change in the structure of rights: it is not people giving rights to each other, but granting rights to themselves.

Stalin is a very committed human rights activist, and so he puts a lot of focus in his trainings on both empowering trainees with their own rights, and trying to bring a rights perspective into their videos.

The discussion then moves on to gender. An important goal of these sessions is to help CCs in adopting a reflexive attitude, on their own lives and positions. Thus, the discussion started by addressing them: What are the areas in which you see gender inequality? The CCs were fast to answer this, and soon a long list is written on the whiteboard: job, income, work, education, politics, property rights, sexual freedom of women. Stalin wants to know whether they know any community where women can choose one or more partner, i.e., polygamy. Anupama  the CC from Korajhar of Assam - mentions a community from the state of Arunachal Pradesh; Mercy of Manipur has heard about a community in Maghalaya;Vipin of Uttarakhand also talks of a community in Jaunsar where women are allowed to practice polygamy. Unfortunately, none of them can name these communities. Stalin underlines that if they could find the names, it would be an interesting material for a video story. Indeed, these cases are rare in todays India, and merit being documented.

Funeral rights are then discussed, since they constitute another area in which women rights are often denied. Stalin asks why women are kept out of funeral processions. Amit says that women used to be emotional and had to be kept out of the procession. Stalin asks him who decided that women were emotional, and made him understand that the desire to protect women, often against their will, is part of the patriarchal system. The discussion now gets increasingly heated. Sajad, from Kashmir, brings up the issue of purdah (wearing the veil), which is practiced in his community. According to him, purdah helped decreasing the rape ratio. Again, Stalin insisted, the claim of protecting women is often one aspect of patriarchy. Stalin says he believes we should respect every religion, but also, that every religion should respects human rights. Stalin thus finds a balance between respecting all the CCsvalues and beliefs, and encouraging them to reflect on every aspect of their lives in a new way: I wont take try to take your right to believe in Goa, and in return, dont take away my right to be critical about things I dont believe in. Be tolerant, be democratic. If you believe in a system deeply, go, make a video, get your communitys perspective and put it before the world.

<a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2011/03/luxmi1.jpg"><img class="alignleft size-medium wp-image-2011" style="margin: 5px; border: 5px solid black;" title="lux,mi" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2011/03/luxmi1-300x200.jpg" alt="" width="300" height="200" /></a>Mercy of Manipur now wants the discussion to address the denial of power that women face in churches. Indeed, Mercy is a Baptist, and she feels affected by the fact that in her church, women cannot become priests or even address the church from the alter. Here, everyone realises that the situation is similar in his or her community, and that women being excluded from major parts of social life is a very common phenomenon in India. Stalin further encourages the discussion, underlining that there is no woman priest ortemple head. And also, that women practicing magic or medicine are called witches, thus reflecting the fear that women provoke once they access power.

Marriageis the next topic they discuss. The CCs enumerate the various visible markers that identify married women:Bindi, toe rings, bangles and necklace. Whatever the accessory is, its only for a married woman to wear. After this the CCs start being really active and enthusiastic. Avdesh, the CC from Himachal Pradesh thinks aloud, why dont we men have a sign of being married?Stalin tells him and others that,each of these ideas, questions and experiences is a great material for a story.

The discussion goes on, touching upon areas like dowry, abortion, birth control, foeticide... All the discriminations faced by girls and women in India are brought up and openly debated. CCs  men and women- share their experience, relate the discussion to their community, and start apprehending things in a new light. Situations that were assumed to be normal get questioned.

The CCs have now plenty of material in their hands. So, Stalin tells them that they now have to write up stories, and that these stories have to get anchored in their experience. As IndiaUnheardCCs, they are not making fictional videos, but are echoing the voices of their communities.

- <strong>Stella Paul</strong>]]></content:encoded>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>Jor Se Bol! - Learning Voice Modulation In IndiaUnheard</title>
		<link>http://www.videovolunteers.org/jo-se-bol-learning-voice-modulation-in-indiaunheard/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 09 Mar 2011 06:43:58 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.videovolunteers.org/?p=2014</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2011/03/MVI_2359.jpg"><img class="alignleft size-medium wp-image-2015" style="margin: 5px; border: 5px solid black;" title="MVI_2359" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2011/03/MVI_2359-300x203.jpg" alt="" width="400" height="300" /></a>The three-week long training program for IndiaUnheards new Community Correspondents is slowly nearing its end. In last 2 weeks, the CCs have been trained in various aspects of video journalism: Camera, B-roll, interviews, research, Story ideas, Paper edit and so on. They have also shot 2 stories each which have been edited by their trainers and screened for all in the camp. After each screening, trainers have pointed out the errors, strength and weakness that their videos have. Most of them have reported a common problem: Low volume, and lack of clarity in the P2C, i.e., the piece to camera/anchor pieceswhich they deliver at the beginning and end of the video. Also, the main feedback from NewsX, the channel with which we have a weekly half hour show, has been around the delivery of their pieces to camera. Now, its time to work on that. Its time for another common session.

This is going to be a theatre and music session. Stalin calls everyone in the hall. They stand in a circle. Stalin joins them with a drum. He beats the drum and starts humming in a low pitch. Everyone follows. The pitch slowly rises higher. Now it sounds like hundred people chanting loudly.

About 7-8 minutes, Stalin makes everyone sit on one side of the hall. He then starts calling out the names of the CCs one by one. Every time a name is called, the CC has to walk to the other side of the hall. The distance between the CC and the group is about 30 feet. Now, the CC has to say the P2C which should be loud and clear, so that the group at the other end can hear and understand.

Nadeem of Kashmir is the first to walk to the other side. I am the camera. You are talking to me. You have a story. Now, look at me and say the P2C for that story, says Stalin. Nadeem talks about killing of Kashmiri youths by army, in fake encounters. Stalin beats his drum and says higher. It means, Nadeem needs to increase his pitch.

Next person to speak is Mudassar. Mudassar says that even 10 years after riots in Gujarat, people still fear the violence.

Stalin: Who are you talking about? Mudassar: victims in Gujarat. Stalin: How are you connected to this? Mudassar: Im one of them.

<a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2011/03/mercy.jpg"><img class="alignleft size-medium wp-image-2016" style="margin: 5px; border: 5px solid black;" title="mercy" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2011/03/mercy-300x168.jpg" alt="" width="300" height="240" /></a>Now Stalin wants Mudassar to make him understand that personal connection through his P2C. As Mudassar starts to talk, he breaks down in tears. Stalin tells him that every story should have this inner emotion, that there is nothing wrong or embarrassing about being soft and sentimental before the camera.

The next participant in the exercise is Labin, who is known as the most soft-spoken person in the group. Now, he speaks loudly, his voice flying across the group sitting 30 feet away from him. When Stalin asks him how he feels, Labin answers with a broad smile that he is feeling like a real journalist.

Then it is Jyotis turn. She says that in her village, women work in field all day, but that even afterwards they get beaten up at home. Jyotis voice is steady, her pitch is high, her eyes look full of passion. Why? Because she is feeling one with the subject she addresses: the evil of domestic violence.

Mercy is facing the group now. She is not looking at Stalin. The reason, she says, is that she feels uncomfortable to make eye contact. Now Stalin walks straight u pto her and stands a feet away. Mercy has no option but to look in his eyes. It first unnerves her a little, but then steadies her. With the fear behind her, she now looks at the camera and says her lines. She is talking of loss of land due to army oppression. There is a nervous, fidgety smile on her face. Stalin asks her: How did you feel towards this oppression? Mercy: Angry and frustrated. Stalin: Then, it should shows on your face. Without that, your story will appear weak, you will not appear as engaged in the story and viewers will not get engaged either.

In the next 10 minutes that follow, every CC walks to the other side of the hall, speaks to the group, says the P2C loudly, clearly, and learns to stand straight and stay focused on the camera  and beyond the camera, at their audience, the people they want to compel to action. In short, everyone has learnt to overcome his/her demon of speaking in public.

Stalin looks quite happy. He asks the CCs, So, what did you learn today? The reply is quick and clear: Speak in high volume. Low volume means less energy, less energy means lack of attachment. If it is an emotional issue, speak slow, but keep the volume high. Look straight into the camera, in to the eyes. Also keep your accent. Its your identity.

With this, the session comes to an end.

- <strong>Stella Paul</strong>]]></content:encoded>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>University of Virginia Teacher Meets IU CC, Gets Insight Into Community Media In India</title>
		<link>http://www.videovolunteers.org/university-of-virginia-teacher-meets-iu-cc-gets-insight-into-community-media-in-india/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 15 Mar 2011 11:34:53 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.videovolunteers.org/?p=2056</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Lisa Goff is an American journalist, currently teaching journalism in the University of Virginia. Last week she was in India, to learn about community journalism. During her visit, Lisa met with our Community Correspondent Mani Manickem in Chennai. Here is an account of their meeting.

[caption id="attachment_2057" align="alignleft" width="300" caption="Lisa Goff with M Mani"]<a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2011/03/100_2464.jpg"><img class="size-medium wp-image-2057   " style="margin: 5px;" title="100_2464" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2011/03/100_2464-300x225.jpg" alt="" width="300" height="225" /></a>[/caption]

Indias emerging community media movement has caught the attention of thousands of people across the world. Lisa Goff  a professor of journalism in the University of Virginia, US is one of them. Lisa was in India with a group of students who were participating in a unique program called the Semester at Sea. The program is a semester-long sea voyage during which students travel to various countries and learn of different subjects. For their 2011 Semester at Sea, Lisa chose for her students to learn of the community media movement in India. As she planned her voyage, Lisa thought of Video Volunteers. Because, says Lisa, Video Volunteers symbolizes the entire community movement. Therefore, during her visit, she wanted to meet someone from the VV team.

The only city Lisa would visit was Chennai. So, it was decided that she could meet Mani, our correspondent who lived in Chennai.<!--more-->

Accordingly, on 11<sup>th</sup> March, Lisa called on Mani. She and her students  about 700 of them - wanted to meet him. They wanted to hear him speak about his work as a community journalist; how he produced the videos; what he hoped to accomplish as a community journalist; and how people in poor communities get local and national news.
For Mani, giving a presentation is not a new task. He is associated with an NGO called Aid India that designs posters and other such materials to make science easier to learn. He has given several presentations before science students and teachers explaining how they could learn difficult lessons from their science text books effortlessly. Yet, Mani was excited to meet Lisa and her students. Because, says Mani, it was the first time that I was going to talk about something that was so close to my heart: The videos that I shot on my own. The people in the video were from my own community and it felt as though I was going to present my own family to so many people who came from so far away. I was excited and even a bit nervous.

[caption id="attachment_2058" align="alignleft" width="300" caption="Lisa Goff listens with interest as Mani speaks enthusiastically about his work as a community correspondent "]<a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2011/03/Mani1.jpg"><img class="size-medium wp-image-2058   " style="margin: 5px; border: 0px initial initial;" title="Mani1" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2011/03/Mani1-300x225.jpg" alt="" width="300" height="225" /></a>[/caption]

However, by the time Mani met Lisas class, his nervousness had vanished. Despite his problems with the English language  Manis native language is Tamil  he did a splendid job of explaining the entire production process of IndiaUnheard. So, the students learnt of how a Community Correspondent did his research; how he found a story idea within his community; how he discussed with the VV team in Goa through phone and got the idea approved; how he shot the video; how he brought a personal connection to each video; burnt a dvd and sent it to the Goa office. It left a deep impression on Lisa. I am so very impressed with his work and with the mission of India Unheard and Video Volunteers. I hope that the connections we made will continue with future voyages of Semester at Sea, she says.

During the presentation Mani showed two of his videos. One of them was on the poor sanitation in his slum, while the other was on the citys transgender community. Lisa found this video fascinating, especially the fact that Mani chose to do a video on a community that is normally left untouched by the mainstream media. After the presentation was over, Lisa asked Mani if she could meet the person that he interviewed in his video. So, Mani accompanied them to the office of Gomthi  the Transgender person from Mani's video. During the visit that lasted for 2 hours, Lisa had an insight into Chennais Transgender people, the difficulties that they undergo and their fight for a dignified life. Gomthi also praised Mani for caring to share their stories with the world through his video.

After Gomthi, Lisa met a journalist from Dina Malar  one of the leading newspapers of the state. Meeting Mani and Dina Malar helped Lisa understand the differences between the two media, their audience and the issues they represented.

[caption id="attachment_2062" align="alignleft" width="300" caption="Lisa Goff with members of Chennai&#39;s Transgender community. Lisa came to know about the community through a video that Mani produced for IndiaUnheard  "]<a href="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2011/03/100_24563.jpg"><img class="size-medium wp-image-2062" style="margin: 5px;" title="100_2456" src="http://www.videovolunteers.org/wp-content/uploads/2011/03/100_24563-300x225.jpg" alt="" width="300" height="225" /></a>[/caption]

Before parting, Mani had a gift for Lisa: A DVD compilation of several IndiaUnheard videos. Visibly excited, Lisa said that the videos were going to be a part of the library of University of Virginia and would be used as reference videos for every class of journalism. She then also told Mani, Next year, when our sea voyage will come to India again, we would love you to come on board and present before the class about your work and about IndiaUnheard. For Mani  a Dalit boy living in a slum, that would be an opportunity worth looking forward to.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>2056</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2011-03-15 04:34:53</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2011-03-15 11:34:53</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>closed</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>university-of-virginia-teacher-meets-iu-cc-gets-insight-into-community-media-in-india</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>trash</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type>post</wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>
		<category domain="category" nicename="blog"><![CDATA[Blog]]></category>
		<category domain="post_tag" nicename="chennai"><![CDATA[Chennai]]></category>
		<category domain="post_tag" nicename="community-media"><![CDATA[Community Media]]></category>
		<category domain="post_tag" nicename="indiaunheard"><![CDATA[IndiaUnheard]]></category>
		<category domain="post_tag" nicename="lisa-goff"><![CDATA[Lisa Goff]]></category>
		<category domain="post_tag" nicename="mani"><![CDATA[Mani]]></category>
		<category domain="post_tag" nicename="mani-manickem"><![CDATA[Mani Manickem]]></category>
		<category domain="post_tag" nicename="semester-at-sea"><![CDATA[Semester at Sea]]></category>
		<category domain="post_tag" nicename="transgender-community"><![CDATA[Transgender community]]></category>
		<category domain="post_tag" nicename="university-of-virginia"><![CDATA[University of Virginia]]></category>
		<wp:postmeta>

			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[28]]></wp:meta_value>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>Narmada Dam: Land For Some, Hope For Others </title>
		<link>http://www.videovolunteers.org/narmada-dam-land-for-some-displaced-families-hope-for-others/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 22 Mar 2011 05:13:15 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.videovolunteers.org/?p=2076</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<div id="_mcePaste">After 3 decades of relentless fighting for rehabilitation, 113 tribal families displaced by Sardar Sarovar Dam on the River Narmada in India's Madhya Pradesh have finally had their demand fulfilled. The families have received land on which they can now build their homes again. VV's community correspondent Rakesh Khanna is one of the displaced people. In his latest video, Rakesh shares the good news of land distribution and says that the development has raised the hopes of thousands of others like him who are still awaiting resettlement.</div>
<div>Watch the video here</div>
<object classid="clsid:d27cdb6e-ae6d-11cf-96b8-444553540000" width="640" height="390" codebase="http://download.macromedia.com/pub/shockwave/cabs/flash/swflash.cab#version=6,0,40,0"><param name="src" value="http://blip.tv/play/heBfgqydAwA" /><param name="allowfullscreen" value="true" /><embed type="application/x-shockwave-flash" width="640" height="390" src="http://blip.tv/play/heBfgqydAwA" allowfullscreen="true"></embed></object> <!--more-->
<div id="_mcePaste">113 tribal families are rehabilitated after 30 years of struggle against the dam project in Chirodh.</div>
<div id="_mcePaste">Rakesh knows a lot about the Narmada Dams. Indeed, his own family has been a victim of this gigantic project  the construction of 30 dams on the Narmada river  that has displaced thousands of villagers, and remains as a symbol of the destructive impact of massive development projects. So, from the start of his collaboration with Video Volunteers, Rakesh has used his videos as a means to voice about his experience and his fight, in parallel with his engagement in the Narmada Bachao Andolan movement. Since I became an IndiaUnheard Community Correspondent, I realized that there is a specific platform for me to tell all my personal stories of struggle.</div>
<div id="_mcePaste">The Omkareshwar dam was constructed as part of the Narmada valley project, and has caused the displacement of more than 3000 families. Among them, many tribal people have not been relocated  contrarily to what was granted to them  because they did not possess the required documents attesting to their property rights over their lands. They had to struggle against the government for 30 years, but todays video proves that their fight was not in vain. Indeed, 113 families were eventually relocated, on plots where they can live in decent conditions.</div>
<div id="_mcePaste">Rakesh considers this relocation as a big success for the Narmada Bachao Andolan movement, and for tribals, whose rights are widely denied. He hopes his video will give everyone facing similar situations the courage to keep on fighting.</div>
After 2 decades of relentless fighting for rehabilitation, families displaced by Sardar Sarovar Dam on the River Narmada in India's Madhya Pradesh have finally got some relief. 113 tribal familes who had been homeless by the mega dam, have received land. IndiaUnheard community correspondent Rakesh Khanna is one of the displaced people. In a recent video he shares the good news that has raised the hopes of thousands of tribals still waiting for resettlement.

113 tribal families are rehabilitated after 30 years of struggle against the dam project in Chirodh.
Rakesh knows a lot about the Narmada Dams. Indeed, his own family has been a victim of this gigantic project  the construction of 30 dams on the Narmada river  that has displaced thousands of villagers, and remains as a symbol of the destructive impact of massive development projects. So, from the start of his collaboration with Video Volunteers, Rakesh has used his videos as a means to voice about his experience and his fight, in parallel with his engagement in the Narmada Bachao Andolan movement. Since I became an IndiaUnheard Community Correspondent, I realized that there is a specific platform for me to tell all my personal stories of struggle.
The Omkareshwar dam was constructed as part of the Narmada valley project, and has caused the displacement of more than 3000 families. Among them, many tribal people have not been relocated  contrarily to what was granted to them  because they did not possess the required documents attesting to their property rights over their lands. They had to struggle against the government for 30 years, but todays video proves that their fight was not in vain. Indeed, 113 families were eventually relocated, on plots where they can live in decent conditions.
Rakesh considers this relocation as a big success for the Narmada Bachao Andolan movement, and for tribals, whose rights are widely denied. He hopes his video will give everyone facing similar situations the courage to keep on fighting.]]></content:encoded>
